choices.text: Episcleral vessel inflammation without scleral involvement
Fibrovascular conjunctival growth encroaching onto the cornea
Deep scleral inflammation extending beyond conjunctiva

questions.text: An ophthalmic image reveals multiple shallow depressions near the limbus, located in the superior part of the cornea, just beneath the upper eyelid. Based on this image finding alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Post-inflammatory limbal follicular scarring pits

 

  • The correct diagnosis based on the image is Herbert pits, which are shallow, oval or round depressions found in the limbal conjunctiva, specifically in the superior limbus.
  • These pits represent the scars left after resolution of limbal follicles, often seen in trachoma, a chronic follicular conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • The follicles involve the limbal conjunctiva, and upon healing, they leave behind characteristic crater-like defects—Herbert pits.

  • These are non-inflammatory, and no scleral or conjunctival vascular congestion is seen in isolated cases.
  • Recognition of these pits is important for diagnosing previous trachomatous inflammation, especially in endemic regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Episcleral vessel inflammation without scleral involvement (Episcleritis): Episcleritis presents with sectoral redness, mild discomfort, and may blanch with phenylephrine drops. It does not cause limbal scarring or depressions, and would present with active inflammation, which is absent in the image.

 

 

Option B. Fibrovascular conjunctival growth encroaching onto the cornea (Pterygium): A pterygium is a wing-shaped conjunctival overgrowth, extending toward the cornea, typically nasally. It is not seen as discrete pits and does not resemble the limbal follicular scarring seen here.

 

 

Option D. Deep scleral inflammation extending beyond conjunctiva (Scleritis): Scleritis presents with severe pain, violaceous hue, and deep vascular congestion that does not blanch with vasoconstrictors. It does not manifest with pits and would show active inflammatory signs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herbert pits are diagnostic of previous trachomatous infection and appear as limbal scars due to resolved limbal follicles; they are typically seen in the superior limbus and are not associated with active inflammation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with established rheumatoid arthritis has joint pain and swelling. Which joint is most commonly affected in established RA?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wrist

 

  • RA typically involves small joints like wrists, MCPs, and PIPs. 
  • DIP involvement is rare and suggests psoriatic or osteoarthritis. 
  • Wrist involvement is characteristic of chronic RA.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A Distal interphalangeal joint: Uncommon in RA. This is involved in psoriatic arthritis and osteoarthritis. 
 

Option B. Hip: Can occur but is not common early.
 

Option C. Knee: Remember this is most common large joint involved in RA. But its not the most common joint involved over all. 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The wrist, MCP, and PIP joints are the hallmark locations of RA involvement, especially in chronic disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoing cisplatin-based chemotherapy for metastatic lung cancer develops severe nausea and vomiting shortly after treatment. The oncology team initiates antiemetic prophylaxis to control these symptoms. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for managing this chemotherapy and radiotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granisetron

 

  • Granisetron is a 5-HT₃ receptor antagonist that blocks serotonin receptors in the central nervous system and gastrointestinal tract, which are activated during chemotherapy and radiotherapy. 
  • It is highly effective in controlling acute emesis associated with highly emetogenic agents like cisplatin.
  • Granisetron is part of the standard antiemetic regimen used in cancer patients, often in combination with dexamethasone and neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) for optimal control of both acute and delayed nausea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: A neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor antagonist, useful for delayed-phase chemotherapy-induced nausea, but not first-line monotherapy for acute nausea. Often used in combination with granisetron.

 

Option C. Hyoscine: An anticholinergic used primarily for motion sickness, not effective for chemo- or radiotherapy-induced nausea.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: A dopamine receptor antagonist used in mild to moderate nausea and gastroparesis but is less effective than 5-HT₃ antagonists in chemotherapy-induced nausea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granisetron, a 5-HT₃ receptor antagonist, is the drug of choice for managing nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

questions.text: The shown clinical test is seen in the following swellings except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cyst

 

  • Transillumination is a clinical test where a bright light is used to shine through a swelling to determine whether it is fluid-filled or solid. It is typically seen in cystic swellings containing clear fluid.
  • Out of the options given, sebaceous cyst does not show transillumination, as it contains thick, sebaceous material rather than clear fluid.
  • A sebaceous cyst is a benign, slow-growing swelling that arises from blocked sebaceous glands.
  • It contains thick, cheesy, and greasy material rather than clear fluid, so it does not transilluminate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic Hygroma: A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation caused by abnormal lymphatic system development. It contains clear lymphatic fluid and therefore shows transillumination.

 

Option C. Ranula: A ranula is a mucous retention cyst found in the floor of the mouth, usually due to blockage of salivary ducts. Since it contains clear mucous fluid, it transilluminates.

 

Option D. Spermatocele: A fluid-filled cyst in the epididymis, which transilluminates due to its clear serous content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cyst does not transilluminate.
  • Cystic hygroma, ranula, and spermatocele transilluminate due to their clear fluid content.

choices.text: Immediate gastrointestinal symptoms followed by prolonged cholinergic crisis and seizures
Delayed gastrointestinal symptoms, temporary improvement, then fulminant hepatic and possible renal failure
Rapid-onset neurotoxicity with mydriasis, hallucinations, and central anticholinergic syndrome
Persistent vomiting and diarrhea with complete recovery within 24 hours and no systemic toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the clinical features of Amanita phalloides (Death Cap mushroom) poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delayed gastrointestinal symptoms, temporary improvement, then fulminant hepatic and possible renal failure

 

  • Amanita phalloides poisoning follows a triphasic pattern:
    1. Latent Phase (6–12 hrs): No symptoms.
    2. GI Phase (12–24 hrs): Profuse vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps.
    3. Apparent Recovery (24–48 hrs): Patient feels better — false recovery.
    4. Hepatic Phase (2–6 days): Fulminant hepatic failure, jaundice, coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and renal failure may follow.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate gastrointestinal symptoms followed by prolonged cholinergic crisis and seizures: This describes organophosphate or muscarine poisoning, not amanitin.

 

Option C. Rapid-onset neurotoxicity with mydriasis, hallucinations, and central anticholinergic syndrome: This suggests Amanita muscaria or Atropa belladonna (anticholinergic syndrome).

 

Option D. Persistent vomiting and diarrhea with complete recovery within 24 hours and no systemic toxicity: This fits non-lethal GI irritant mushrooms (e.g., Agaricus species).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amanita phalloides poisoning follows a triphasic course: initial delayed GI symptoms, a deceptive recovery phase, and eventual fulminant hepatic failure often accompanied by renal dysfunction. 
  • Early recognition is critical to initiate aggressive supportive care and consider antidotal therapy (e.g., silibinin).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling just below his left knee. He reports that the pain has been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially after playing basketball and running. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness and swelling over the tibial tuberosity, and the patient experiences pain with active knee extension against resistance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osgood-Schlatter disease

 

  • Osgood-Schlatter disease is a traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle due to repetitive strain from the quadriceps muscle via the patellar tendon.
  • Common in adolescent boys during growth spurts, especially those active in sports involving running, jumping, or squatting (like basketball).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling over the tibial tuberosity
    • Pain with knee extension against resistance
    • Worse with activity, improves with rest
  • Self-limiting, managed conservatively with rest, ice, stretching, and NSAIDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Patellar tendinitis:

 

  • Also known as jumper’s knee.
  • Involves inflammation of the patellar tendon itself.
  • Pain is localized to the inferior pole of the patella.
  • Common in athletes, but more often seen in older adolescents or young adults.

 

Option C. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear:

 

  • Usually follows acute trauma, often with a sudden pop, pain, and joint instability.
  • Swelling occurs rapidly (hemarthrosis), and there may be difficulty weight-bearing.
  • Not a gradual onset condition and not typically localized over the tibial tubercle.
  • A 12-year-old with gradual pain and no trauma history is not typical for ACL injury.

 

Option D. Osteochondritis dissecans:

 

  • Affects the subchondral bone and cartilage, usually of the femoral condyle.
  • Presents with vague knee pain, swelling, and sometimes mechanical symptoms like locking or catching.
  • Not specifically associated with tenderness over the tibial tuberosity.
  • More common in older adolescents, and localized pain is usually deeper inside the joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Osgood-Schlatter disease is the best fit given the age, gradual onset, tibial tuberosity pain, and activity-related symptoms.
  • It is a self-limited condition associated with growth spurts and responds well to conservative treatment.

choices.text: The plan aims to eliminate snakebite deaths entirely by 2025
It proposes a 70% reduction in deaths and disability by 2030
It aims to halve deaths and disability due to snakebites by 2030
The target year for outcome evaluation is aligned with the 2047 Health@100 vision

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the National Action Plan for Prevention and Control of Snakebite Envenoming (NAP-SE) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It aims to halve deaths and disability due to snakebites by 2030

 

  • The National Action Plan for Snakebite Envenoming (NAP-SE) is India’s official strategy to address the often neglected but deadly issue of snakebite envenoming. The key aim of NAP-SE is to prevent and control snakebite envenoming in order to halve the number of deaths and cases of disability it causes by 2030.
  • This aligns with WHO’s global strategy and Sustainable Development Goal targets focused on reducing avoidable mortality due to neglected tropical diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The plan aims to eliminate snakebite deaths entirely by 2025: Incorrect. The plan does not aim for complete elimination of deaths, and certainly not by 2025. The goal is to reduce (not eliminate) mortality and morbidity by 50% by 2030.

 

Option B. It proposes a 70% reduction in deaths and disability by 2030: Incorrect. The actual target is to halve (i.e., 50%) the cases of death and disability — not 70%.

 

Option D. The target year for outcome evaluation is aligned with the 2047 Health@100 vision: Incorrect. NAP-SE is not aligned with the 2047 vision. Its concrete target year is 2030, which is aligned with WHO's global strategy and India's medium-term health goals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NAP-SE (National Action Plan for Snakebite Envenoming) aims to halve the number of deaths and disability caused by snakebite envenoming in India by the year 2030, focusing on antivenom access, surveillance, emergency care, and a One Health approach.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to OPD with severe cachexia and dysphagia to solids. Endoscopy shows a lumen-occluding growth at the mid-esophagus. While he is being investigated, you start him on TPN. After one day, the patient gets seizures and tetany. What likely abnormality is responsible for the above event?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypophosphatemia

 

  • Hypophosphatemia is a known complication of refeeding syndrome, which can occur when nutrition is suddenly introduced to a malnourished patient. It can cause seizures, tetany, muscle weakness, and cardiac dysfunction, and is the most likely cause in this context.
  • The patient is suffering from refeeding syndrome typically seen after sudden institution of feeds in a chronically starved patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastasis to brain: While metastases to the brain can cause seizures, the acute onset of seizures and tetany after starting TPN suggests a metabolic cause rather than new brain metastases.

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Hyponatremia can cause seizures due to an osmotic imbalance across the neuronal membrane, but it is not typically associated with the acute onset of tetany.

 

Option D. Hyperglycemia: Hyperglycemia can result from TPN due to the high glucose content in the solution; however, it is less likely to cause acute seizures and tetany compared to electrolyte disturbances like hypophosphatemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.

choices.text: Colostrum has lower protein content than mature milk
Colostrum has higher fat content than mature milk
Colostrum is richer in immunoglobulin A (IgA) than mature milk
Colostrum has higher lactose concentration than mature milk

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding colostrum compared to mature breast milk is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colostrum is richer in immunoglobulin A (IgA) than mature milk

 

  • Colostrum is the early milk secreted by the mother during the first 3–5 days postpartum, and it is specifically adapted to meet the immunologic needs of the newborn.
  • Let’s compare colostrum and mature milk on the major components:

 

 

  • Secretory IgA (sIgA) is the dominant immunoglobulin in human milk, and its concentration is highest in colostrum.
  • It provides mucosal immunity to the neonate, protecting the gut from pathogens without inducing inflammation.
  • sIgA also prevents microbial adherence and neutralizes toxins/viruses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colostrum has lower protein content than mature milk: Incorrect. Colostrum has higher protein content than mature milk, especially due to immunologic proteins like lactoferrin and sIgA.

 

Option B. Colostrum has higher fat content than mature milk: Incorrect. Colostrum has lower fat content compared to mature milk. Fat increases in mature milk, especially in the hindmilk.

 

Option D. Colostrum has higher lactose concentration than mature milk: Incorrect. Lactose is lower in colostrum and increases in mature milk, where it serves as the primary carbohydrate and energy source.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colostrum, the early milk produced postpartum, is rich in immunoglobulin A (IgA), providing essential mucosal immunity to the newborn.

questions.text: Match the following Brodmann areas with their corresponding functional cortical regions:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A–2, B–3, C–1, D–4

 

A-2. Area 4 → Primary motor cortex (precentral gyrus): responsible for voluntary movements

 

B-3. Area 6 → Premotor cortex and supplementary motor area: involved in motor planning

 

C-1. Areas 41, 42 → Primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus)

 

D-4. Area 17 → Primary visual cortex (calcarine cortex in occipital lobe)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Area 4 → Primary motor cortex (precentral gyrus): Responsible for voluntary movements
  • Area 6 → Premotor cortex and supplementary motor area: Involved in motor planning
  • Areas 41, 42 → Primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus)
  • Area 17 → Primary visual cortex (calcarine cortex in occipital lobe)

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure presents for routine follow-up. He reports some improvement in exertional dyspnea but continues to experience episodes of angina pectoris. His current therapy includes a beta-blocker and a loop diuretic. A drug is added that inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), leading to vasodilation and reduced cardiac workload. After a few weeks, he develops hypotension and angioedema. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omapatrilat

 

  • Omapatrilat is a dual-acting inhibitor that targets both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE).
  • This dual inhibition leads to accumulation of natriuretic peptides and reduction of angiotensin II, resulting in potent vasodilation, natriuresis, and decreased cardiac preload and afterload.
  • It was investigated for use in heart failure and angina pectoris, demonstrating hemodynamic benefits.
  • However, the use of omapatrilat was discontinued due to a high risk of angioedema, especially in Black patients, as both ACE inhibition and neprilysin inhibition increase bradykinin levels, a known trigger for angioedema. 
  • Hypotension is another common adverse effect due to enhanced vasodilatory action.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levosimendan: Levosimendan is a calcium sensitizer and K-ATP channel opener used in acute decompensated heart failure. It enhances myocardial contractility without increasing intracellular calcium. It does not inhibit neprilysin or ACE, and angioedema is not a known side effect.

 

Option C. ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor): This refers to sacubitril/valsartan, which combines a neprilysin inhibitor (sacubitril) with an angiotensin receptor blocker (valsartan), not an ACE inhibitor. This combination avoids excess bradykinin buildup, hence lower risk of angioedema compared to omapatrilat. ARNI is approved for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) but not typically used for angina pectoris.

 

Option D. Ivabradine: Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny (If) current in the sinoatrial node, lowering heart rate without affecting blood pressure or myocardial contractility. It is used in HFrEF and sometimes stable angina. It does not affect neprilysin or ACE and does not cause angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat is a dual inhibitor of neprilysin and ACE that lowers cardiac workload via vasodilation but is associated with a high risk of angioedema due to bradykinin accumulation.

questions.text: Which of the following labeled muscles in the diagram performs extension of knee and flexion of hip joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

  • Label A → Rectus Femoris: This is the only quadriceps muscle that crosses both the hip and knee joints. It contributes to extension of the knee and flexion of the hip.
  • Label B → Vastus Intermedius: Acts solely on the knee joint for extension.
  • Label C → Vastus Medialis:  Also, a knee extensor only.
  • Label D → Vastus Lateralis: Functions in knee extension.
  • All the 4 muscles unite to form Quadriceps Femoris (also called Footballer’s muscle/Kick muscle). If this muscle is injured, it is responsible for hand-to-knee gait.
  • All vasti (intermedius, medialis, and lateralis) extend the knee, but do not cross the hip joint, and hence do not aid in hip flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Among the four muscles that make up the quadriceps femoris group, only the rectus femoris crosses both the hip and knee joints, allowing it to perform hip flexion in addition to knee extension. 
  • The other three (vastus medialis, vastus intermedius, and vastus lateralis) are confined to knee extension.

choices.text: Start LMWH for suspected spinal thrombosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with Stage 4 lung cancer presents with bilateral leg weakness, incontinence, and numbness below the umbilicus. Examination shows hyperreflexia and decreased anal tone. What is the most appropriate immediate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start intravenous dexamethasone

 

  • This is malignant spinal cord compression, a medical emergency. 
  • IV dexamethasone reduces edema and preserves neurologic function.
  • MRI of the spine should follow. 
  • Delay in steroids can lead to irreversible deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Order MRI of the brain: Not indicated with clear spinal localization. MRI of whole spinal cord not brain, is the investigation of choice

 

Option C. Refer to physiotherapy: Not appropriate without treatment.

 

Option D. Start LMWH for suspected spinal thrombosis: No evidence of venous thrombosis; risks bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cord compression, give IV corticosteroids immediately to prevent permanent neurologic damage.

choices.text: It can be done for superficial wounds
It derives nutrition from the recipient bed
It is used after oral malignancy for reconstruction
It can be used to cover large wounds

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about the procedure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used after oral malignancy for reconstruction

 

  • Split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs) are generally not the preferred choice for oral cavity reconstruction. After oral malignancies we need bulk of tissue.
  • Instead, flaps (such as free flaps or pedicled flaps) are commonly used in oral malignancy cases, as they provide better vascular supply, thickness, and durability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be done for superficial wounds:

 

  • STSGs are commonly used for superficial and partial-thickness wounds, such as burns, ulcers, and skin defects.
  • They integrate well with the wound bed and promote epithelialization over large surfaces.

 

Option B. It derives nutrition from the recipient bed: 

 

  • STSGs initially survive via plasmatic imbibition, where they absorb nutrients from the wound bed.
  • Later, vascular inosculation occurs, where new blood vessels form to support graft survival.

 

Option D. It can be used to cover large wounds:

 

  • STSGs are commonly used for large wound coverage, especially in burn cases and traumatic skin loss.
  • They provide rapid epithelialization and can adhere to large surface areas effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • STSGs are not typically used for oral malignancy reconstruction; flaps are preferred.
  • STSGs work for superficial wounds, derive nutrition from the recipient bed, and cover large wounds effectively.

questions.text: During beta-oxidation of fatty acids in peroxisomes, which of the following is the final product formed as a result of the metabolic breakdown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Octanoyl CoA

 

  • In peroxisomal beta-oxidation, very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and branched-chain fatty acids are partially broken down. 
  • The peroxisomes initiate the oxidation process by shortening the fatty acid chains through successive removal of two-carbon units, similar to mitochondrial beta-oxidation, but with some key differences:
    • The final product of peroxisomal beta-oxidation is typically medium-chain fatty acyl-CoA molecules, most commonly octanoyl CoA (C8).
    • These medium-chain fatty acids are then transferred to mitochondria, where beta-oxidation is completed, yielding acetyl CoA for entry into the citric acid cycle.
  • This division of labor allows peroxisomes to specialize in initial chain-shortening of long and branched fatty acids, while mitochondria handle the final complete oxidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Butyryl CoA: Butyryl CoA is not the end product of l beta-oxidation in peroxisomal. In peroxisomes, oxidation stops at medium-chain lengths, which are then transferred to mitochondria for complete breakdown to acetyl CoA.

 

Option C. Acetoacetyl CoA: This is an intermediate in ketone body metabolism and certain amino acid degradation pathways. It is not a typical product of peroxisomal beta-oxidation.

 

Option D. Palmitoyl CoA: Palmitoyl CoA (C16) is a long-chain fatty acyl-CoA, which is a substrate for beta-oxidation, not a product. It is one of the fatty acids that gets shortened in peroxisomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peroxisomal beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids ends with the formation of medium-chain fatty acyl-CoAs, most notably octanoyl CoA, which are then transferred to mitochondria for further oxidation.

choices.text: Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis
Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid oxidation
Citric acid cycle, Pentose phosphate pathway

questions.text: A metabolic deficiency leads to impairment in a primary pathway, which in turn causes a secondary defect due to the deficiency of one of its key substrates. Which of the following correctly identifies the primary pathway affected and the secondary pathway compromised as a result?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis

 

  • The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP) is the primary source of NADPH, a crucial reducing agent required for biosynthetic processes, especially:
    • Fatty acid synthesis
    • Cholesterol synthesis
    • Maintenance of reduced glutathione in red blood cells
  • If there is a deficiency in the pentose phosphate pathway (e.g., due to glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency), the cell will have reduced NADPH levels. This leads to a secondary effect on any pathway that requires NADPH, most notably fatty acid synthesis, which is NADPH-dependent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid oxidation: Incorrect. Fatty acid oxidation does not depend on NADPH. It primarily generates NADH and FADH₂, not affected by PPP deficiency.

 

Option C. Citric acid cycle, Pentose phosphate pathway: Incorrect. The citric acid cycle primarily produces NADH, FADH₂, and GTP. It is not directly linked to the PPP, and PPP is not secondarily affected by TCA cycle deficiency.

 

Option D. Citric acid cycle, glycolysis: Incorrect. Although glycolysis provides pyruvate for the TCA cycle, the reverse is not energy substrate-dependent in this context. Glycolysis is not secondarily affected in the way fatty acid synthesis is dependent on NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A deficiency in the pentose phosphate pathway leads to decreased NADPH, which secondarily impairs fatty acid synthesis, a pathway that requires NADPH as a reducing equivalent.

choices.text: No R wave in lead aVR
Monomorphic R wave pattern in precordial leads V1–V6
Structural heart disease seen on prior studies

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with prior myocardial infarction presents with dizziness. On exam, he has a regular wide-complex tachycardia at 170/min. ECG is shown below. Which of the following findings suggests supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) with aberrancy rather than a ventricular tachycardia (VT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) No R wave in lead aVR

 

  • In wide complex tachycardia, absence of a dominant R wave in lead aVR suggests SVT with aberrancy. 
  • VT is more likely if there is AV dissociation, structural heart disease, or concordant R waves in precordial leads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Findings consistent with AV dissociation: Strongly suggests VT.

 

Option C. Monomorphic R wave pattern in precordial leads V1–V6: Suggests VT with concordant morphology.

 

Option D. Structural heart disease seen on prior studies: Increases likelihood of VT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ECG clues like absence of dominant R in aVR may favor SVT.
  • Presence of AV dissociation and structural heart disease suggest VT.

questions.text:
Match the Growth Factor Receptors with Their Functions:

 

 

Choose the correct matching:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A–3, B–1, C–2
 

A–3. ERBB2 [HER2/neu] → Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR): It is a receptor tyrosine kinase involved in cell proliferation and is implicated in breast cancer when overexpressed. 

 

B–1. RET → Neural growth factor receptor: RET mutations are associated with neural crest-derived tumors such as medullary thyroid carcinoma, MEN2A/2B, and Hirschsprung disease. Therefore, is correct.

 

C–2. KIT → Stem cell growth factor receptor (also known as CD117): It plays a key role in hematopoietic stem cell maintenance and is commonly mutated in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

ERBB2 [HER2/neu] is an epidermal growth factor receptor, RET is a neural growth factor receptor, and KIT is a stem cell growth factor receptor—understanding these associations is essential for recognizing molecular mechanisms in cancer biology.

choices.text: Antibody-mediated IgG attack on enterocytes triggered by gluten exposure
Direct cytotoxic effects of gliadin on intestinal epithelial cells
Delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by MHC class I molecules and CD8+ T cells
Helper T-cell–mediated damage following gliadin presentation via MHC class II molecules

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of bloating and chronic diarrhea. She denies recent travel, antibiotic use, or sick contacts. Physical examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen. On dermatologic examination, there are clustered vesicular lesions on the extensor surfaces of her elbows and knees. A skin biopsy shows IgA deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae. An upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy reveals villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia. The patient is started on a gluten-free diet, after which her symptoms and rash resolve. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of her disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Helper T-cell–mediated damage following gliadin presentation via MHC class II molecules

 

  • This patient has celiac disease, an immune-mediated disorder caused by gluten exposure in genetically susceptible individuals (typically those with HLA-DQ2 or DQ8):
    • Gliadin, a component of gluten (found in wheat and grains), is the most pathogenic trigger.
    • After absorption, gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG).
    • Deamidated gliadin is then presented by antigen-presenting cells via MHC class II to CD4+ helper T cells.
    • These helper T cells mediate tissue damage, resulting in villous atrophy in the small bowel.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis, the skin manifestation seen here, is caused by IgA deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae, and it typically resolves with a gluten-free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibody-mediated IgG attack on enterocytes triggered by gluten exposure: Incorrect. The response involves IgA in skin and T-cell–mediated mucosal injury, not IgG antibodies against enterocytes.

 

Option B. Direct cytotoxic effects of gliadin on intestinal epithelial cells: Incorrect. Gliadin is not directly cytotoxic; it requires deamidation and immune presentation to initiate inflammation.

 

Option C. Delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by MHC class I molecules and CD8+ T cells: Incorrect. This would describe a type IV reaction, but celiac disease involves CD4+ T cells and MHC class II.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Celiac disease is triggered by gliadin, the immunogenic component of gluten. Deamidated gliadin is presented via MHC class II molecules, leading to CD4+ T-cell–mediated mucosal damage. 
  • The condition is associated with HLA-DQ2/DQ8 and may present with dermatitis herpetiformis due to IgA deposition at the dermal papillae.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man diagnosed with schizophrenia is being evaluated for long-term antipsychotic treatment. He has a strong family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia, and he expresses concern about weight gain and metabolic side effects associated with psychiatric medications. Which of the following antipsychotic agents is least likely to cause metabolic adverse effects such as weight gain, hyperglycemia, or dyslipidemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

  • Ziprasidone is an atypical (second-generation) antipsychotic with a relatively favorable metabolic profile. It has minimal impact on:
    • Weight gain
    • Glucose metabolism
    • Lipid profile
  • This makes it particularly suitable for patients at risk of metabolic syndrome. Although it may cause QT prolongation, it is least associated with the common metabolic disturbances seen in other atypical antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: While better than clozapine or olanzapine, risperidone is still associated with moderate risk of weight gain, hyperlipidemia, and glucose intolerance. It may also cause hyperprolactinemia.

 

Option B. Clozapine: One of the most metabolically adverse antipsychotics, clozapine is strongly linked to significant weight gain, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia, and metabolic syndrome. It is reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: A typical (first-generation) antipsychotic, haloperidol has less metabolic risk than atypicals but is not preferred due to its high risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and tardive dyskinesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone and Aripiprazole are the antipsychotic agent least associated with metabolic side effects such as weight gain and dyslipidemia, making it a suitable option in patients at risk for metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is evaluated for exercise-induced muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria. He reports symptoms starting after short bursts of physical activity. Lab findings reveal elevated serum CK, myoglobin in urine, and hemolytic anemia. Further analysis identifies a deficiency in an enzyme involved in glycolysis, specifically affecting skeletal muscle and erythrocytes. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphofructokinase-1

 

  • This patient presents with clinical features of Glycogen Storage Disease Type VII (Tarui’s disease), a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) in muscle and red blood cells.
  • PFK-1 is a key rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis, catalyzing the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
  • In muscles, deficiency impairs glycolysis leading to:
    • Muscle pain and cramps
    • Exercise intolerance
    • Myoglobinuria
  • In erythrocytes, impaired glycolysis results in hemolysis, leading to hemolytic anemia.
  • Unlike McArdle’s disease (type V), which spares red blood cells, Tarui’s disease affects both muscle and erythrocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase: Incorrect. Deficiency leads to McArdle’s disease (GSD V), which causes exercise intolerance but does not cause hemolysis, as erythrocytes are unaffected.

 

Option B. Phosphoglucomutase: Incorrect. Involved in glycogen metabolism, not glycolysis. 

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Incorrect. Deficiency causes chronic hemolytic anemia, but not exercise-induced myopathy or myoglobinuria, since skeletal muscle has alternative compensatory mechanisms. This is the second most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. (First most common is G6PD deficiency)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tarui’s disease (GSD VII) results from phosphofructokinase-1 deficiency, leading to impaired glycolysis in skeletal muscle and red blood cells, manifesting as exercise-induced cramps, myoglobinuria, and hemolytic anemia.

choices.text: Anemia and malnutrition contribute to its development
The most common site is the heel
A bedsore can be expected if erythema appears that does not change color on pressure

questions.text: All of these are true regarding decubitus ulcers except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The most common site is the heel

 

  • Decubitus ulcers means bed sore or pressure sore.
  • The most common sites for decubitus ulcers are bony prominences under prolonged pressure, especially in immobilized patients, such as the ischium and greater trochanter or the lateral thigh. The heel can be a common site but is not the most common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia and malnutrition contribute to its development: This statement is true. Anemia and malnutrition are systemic factors that can impair wound healing and contribute to the development of decubitus ulcers.

 

Option C. A bedsore can be expected if erythema appears that does not change colour on pressure: This is true. Persistent erythema that does not blanch with pressure indicates the start of a pressure ulcer (stage 1).

 

Option D. Skin grafting should be avoided: This statement is generally true. Skin grafting is not the first-line treatment for bedsores, given the high risk of failure due to the compromised tissue health at the ulcer site. Skin grafting is avoided in deep wounds. Other interventions like flaps are typically preferred.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most common site for decubitus ulcers is over the ischial tuberosity, not the heel, and management often requires regular repositioning, use of pressure-distributing devices, and optimizing the local environment for wound healing.

choices.text: Virus isolation in cell culture from cerebrospinal fluid
Immunofluorescence assay of corneal smear or nape of neck skin biopsy
Detection of rabies antibody in serum
Identification of Negri bodies on brain biopsy

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, agitation, and hydrophobia. He reports being bitten by a stray dog 3 weeks ago and did not receive post-exposure prophylaxis. Rabies is suspected. Which of the following diagnostic methods is most appropriate for demonstration of rabies antigen in a living patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunofluorescence assay of corneal smear or nape of neck skin biopsy

 

  • In suspected rabies infection, immunofluorescence staining is a rapid, sensitive method used to detect rabies antigen in:
    • Corneal epithelial cells, and
    • Cutaneous nerves around hair follicles from the nape of the neck
  • This test is especially valuable because:
    • It can be done ante-mortem (before death)
    • It avoids the need for invasive CNS procedures
    • It directly detects viral antigen, offering early diagnostic confirmation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus isolation in cell culture from cerebrospinal fluid: Rabies virus is rarely isolated from CSF, and culture is slow and insensitive. Not useful for rapid clinical diagnosis.

 

Option C. Detection of rabies antibody in serum: Antibody response may be delayed or absent in unvaccinated individuals, especially during early stages. Hence, not reliable as a first-line diagnostic test.

 

Option D. Identification of Negri bodies on brain biopsy: Although Negri bodies (cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons) are pathognomonic, brain biopsy is invasive and typically done postmortem, not in living patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunofluorescence staining of corneal epithelial cells or nape of neck skin biopsy is a key ante-mortem diagnostic method for detecting rabies virus antigen in living patients.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with advanced endometrial carcinoma that has progressed despite first-line chemotherapy. Molecular profiling of the tumor reveals microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) status. Her oncologist considers immunotherapy as a second-line option. Which of the following immune checkpoint inhibitors is FDA-approved for use in such advanced endometrial cancer cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pembrolizumab

 

  • Pembrolizumab is a PD-1 (programmed death receptor-1) immune checkpoint inhibitor that has received FDA approval for use in patients with advanced endometrial cancer, particularly those with MSI-H (microsatellite instability-high) or dMMR (deficient mismatch repair) tumors, and whose disease has progressed following prior systemic therapy
  • Pembrolizumab works by restoring T-cell immune response against tumor cells, making it effective in immunogenic tumors such as those with MSI-H features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: Another PD-1 inhibitor, FDA-approved for several malignancies (e.g., melanoma, NSCLC, RCC), but not specifically approved for advanced endometrial cancer.

 

Option B. Atezolizumab: A PD-L1 inhibitor, used in cancers such as triple-negative breast cancer, urothelial cancer and NSCLC, but not FDA-approved for endometrial carcinoma.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: A CTLA-4 inhibitor, primarily used in malignant melanoma and combination regimens in some other cancers but not approved for endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the FDA-approved PD-1 inhibitor for advanced endometrial cancer, especially in tumors with microsatellite instability or mismatch repair deficiency.

choices.text: Melioidosis is a Category B threat due to its low human-to-human transmissibility and potential environmental persistence
Nipah virus is Category C due to its emerging status and potential for genetic engineering
Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks
Ricin toxin is Category B due to its potential for use as an aerosolizable toxin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks

 

  • According to CDC classification of bioterrorism agent they are divided in 3 categories:
    • Category A: Most easy to spread and more dangerous. It has 6 agents → Small Pox, Anthrax, Botulism, Plague, Tularemia and Viral Hemorrhagic Fever (Ebola, Marburg). In this smallpox is most dangerous; Anthrax is more easy to spread and most commonly used; Botulism is more lethal toxin wise
    • Category B: They are less dangerous and less easy to spread. It includes Food safety threats, water safety threats, Melioidosis, Psittacosis, Glanders, Brucellosis, Clostridium perfringens, Typhus fever, Q fever, recent toxin, Staphylococcal entertoxin
    • Category C: This is new emerging pathogens. E.g: Nipah virus, Hantavirus
  • Clostridium perfringens, particularly its Epsilon toxin, is classified under Category B, not Category A.
  • It is listed among agents with moderate morbidity and lower mortality, requiring enhanced diagnostics, but not posing the same level of national threat as Category A agents.
  • Also, alpha toxin is not considered a primary agent for bioterrorism use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melioidosis is a Category B threat due to its low human-to-human transmissibility and potential environmental persistence: Melioidosis – Category B. Correct. Caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, melioidosis is a Category B agent due to its environmental resilience, low transmission, and potential for water/soil-based contamination.

 

Option B. Nipah virus is Category C due to its emerging status and potential for genetic engineering: Nipah virus – Category C. Correct. Nipah virus is a Category C agent—emerging, high-fatality pathogen with zoonotic origin, no vaccine, and potential for aerosolization or genetic manipulation.

 

Option D. Ricin toxin is Category B due to its potential for use as an aerosolizable toxin: Ricin – Category B. Correct. Ricin is a plant-derived toxin (from Ricinus communis) that can be aerosolized and causes respiratory distress and death. It is a Category B bioterror agent due to ease of production and inhalational toxicity, though it is not infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clostridium perfringens is a Category B agent, not Category A. 
  • Only agents like Anthrax, Botulism, Plague, Tularemia, Smallpox, and viral hemorrhagic fevers are in Category A, posing the highest risk to national security due to their potential for mass transmission and mortality.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with uncontrolled diabetes complains of foot and ankle pain interfering with work. He stands all day at a factory and seeks relief. Which medication is most suitable for his painful neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duloxetine

 

  • Duloxetine, an SNRI, is effective for diabetic neuropathy with fewer anticholinergic and sedative side effects, making it safer in elderly patients. 
  • TCAs are effective but pose safety concerns due to orthostatic hypotension and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nortriptyline: Less sedating than others but still risky.

 

Option B. Amitriptyline: Highest sedation and anticholinergic burden.

 

Option C. Doxepin: High sedative and anticholinergic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duloxetine is preferred for diabetic neuropathy in elderly due to its efficacy and lower adverse effect profile compared to TCAs.

questions.text: At what minimum endometrial thickness should an endometrial biopsy be considered to rule out endometrial malignancy in a postmenopausal patient with abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 mm

 

  • In postmenopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, transvaginal ultrasound is used to assess endometrial thickness. 
  • The threshold for further evaluation, including endometrial biopsy, is an endometrial thickness ≥4 mm.
  • An endometrial stripe measuring 4 mm or greater is considered abnormal in this population and may indicate endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. 
  • Even in the absence of other symptoms or findings, this measurement warrants further histopathological assessment to rule out malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding, an endometrial thickness of ≥4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound warrants endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy.

choices.text: Obese, since any one site > 12 mm

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl has the following skinfold thickness values at 4 sites: 14 mm, 12 mm, 13 mm, and 11 mm. What is the clinical interpretation regarding obesity using SFT (Skinfold Thickness) guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obese, since total is ≥ 50 mm

 

  • According to standard public health guidelines for assessing obesity using skinfold thickness, for girls, a total skinfold thickness (SFT) ≥ 50 mm, and for boys, ≥ 40mm across four standard sites indicates obesity.
  • Harpenden caliper is used to measure skinfold thickness at 4 sites:
    • Mid-triceps
    • Biceps
    • Sub-scapular
    • Supra-iliac region

  • Single best measurement site is triceps
    • ≥ 18mm in boys and ≥ 32 mm in girls indicates obesity
  • In this question:
    • The 4-site sum = 14 + 12 + 13 + 11 = 50 mm
    • This exactly meets the threshold for obesity diagnosis via SFT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal, since average is < 32 mm: Incorrect. The average SFT is not the criterion used; it's the sum across four sites that matters.

 

Option B. Obese, since any one site > 12 mm: Incorrect. There is no guideline that says a single site >12 mm defines obesity.

 

Option D. Cannot comment without WHR: Incorrect. While waist-hip ratio (WHR) is another measure, SFT-based criteria can independently diagnose obesity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In adolescent girls, a sum of skinfold thickness ≥ 50 mm (measured across mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular, and suprailiac regions) is diagnostic of obesity. 
  • Accurate measurement and site selection are essential for proper clinical interpretation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves are incorrect? 

 

  1. A test with an AUC (Area Under Curve) of 0.5 performs no better than chance.
  2. AUC values >1 indicate perfect diagnostic accuracy.
  3. ROC curve is independent of disease prevalence.
  4. ROC curve plots Specificity vs. (1 - Sensitivity).
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4 only

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. AUC values >1 indicate perfect diagnostic accuracy: Incorrect. The maximum possible AUC is 1.0, indicating a perfect test. AUC cannot exceed 1.0; values >1 are not possible and indicate an error in calculation or interpretation.

 

Statement 4. ROC curve plots Specificity vs. (1 - Sensitivity): Incorrect. ROC curves plot Sensitivity (True Positive Rate) on the Y-axis versus (1 - Specificity) (False Positive Rate) on the X-axis — not Specificity vs (1 - Sensitivity).

 

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. A test with an AUC (Area Under Curve) of 0.5 performs no better than chance: Correct. An AUC of 0.5 indicates that the test is no better than chance, i.e., it cannot discriminate between diseased and non-diseased individuals.

 

Statement 3. ROC curve is independent of disease prevalence: Correct. The ROC curve is independent of disease prevalence. It is constructed purely from the sensitivity and specificity values of a test at different thresholds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ROC curves are powerful tools to evaluate diagnostic accuracy independent of disease prevalence. The Area Under the Curve (AUC) ranges from 0.5 (chance) to 1.0 (perfect). ROC plots use sensitivity and 1-specificity, not specificity or prevalence.

questions.text:
Which of the following are absolute contraindications to administering regional anesthesia?

 

  1. Patient refusal
  2. Platelet count < 70,000
  3. Localized skin infection at the injection site
  4. Raised intracranial pressure with midline shift
  5. Uncorrected Hypovolemic shock
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Statement 1. Patient refusal: Absolute contraindication. Autonomy is paramount; regional anesthesia must never be forced or done without informed consent.

 

Statement 2. Platelet count < 70,000: Absolute. contraindication. It significantly increases the risk of epidural or spinal hematoma, which can cause permanent neurological damage.

 

Statement 3. Localized skin infection: Absolute contraindication Performing a block through infected skin can introduce bacteria to deeper tissues or the CNS.

 

Statement 4. Raised ICP with midline shift: Absolute. Increases the risk of brainstem herniation, especially with neuraxial blocks.

 

Statement 5. Uncorrected Hypovolemic shock: Absolute contraindication. Due to the high risk of life-threatening hypotension after sympathetic blockade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regional anesthesia requires careful patient selection. 
  • Absolute contraindications include:
    • Patient refusal
    • Infection at the site 
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised ICP with midline shift
    • Uncorrected hypovolemia/shock
  • Ignoring these can lead to catastrophic outcomes like herniation, hematoma, or cardiovascular collapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macular edema

 

  • Macular edema is a complication of diabetic retinopathy due to retinal capillary leakage. It falls under microvascular complications, which also include nephropathy and neuropathy. 
  • Others like cheiroarthropathy and gastroparesis are nonvascular or autonomic complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cheiroarthropathy: Connective tissue stiffening and limited joint mobility; nonvascular.

 

Option B. Gastroparesis: Due to autonomic neuropathy, not directly microvascular.

 

Option D. Peripheral arterial disease: Macrovascular complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microvascular complications of diabetes include retinopathy (macular edema), nephropathy, and neuropathy due to small vessel damage.

choices.text: High heterogeneity among the included studies
Low risk of bias across all included studies
Increased precision due to the substantial weight of the large study
Overestimation of the effect size due to random error

questions.text: In a meta-analysis, a forest plot reveals that one large study significantly influences the pooled effect estimate, resulting in a narrow confidence interval. What does this narrow confidence interval primarily indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased precision due to the substantial weight of the large study

 

  • In meta-analyses, each study contributes to the pooled effect estimate proportionally to its weight, which is often determined by the inverse of its variance. Larger studies typically have smaller variances, granting them more weight in the analysis. When a large study dominates the meta-analysis, it exerts a significant influence on the pooled estimate.
  • A narrow confidence interval (CI) around the pooled estimate suggests high precision, indicating that the true effect size is likely close to the estimated value. This increased precision is primarily due to the substantial weight of the large study, which reduces the overall variance of the pooled estimate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High heterogeneity among the included studies: High heterogeneity among studies usually leads to wider confidence intervals, reflecting variability in effect sizes across studies. A narrow CI suggests the opposite.

 

Option B. Low risk of bias across all included studies: While a low risk of bias is desirable, it doesn't directly result in a narrow CI. The CI width is more influenced by study weights and variances.

 

Option D. Overestimation of the effect size due to random error: Random error typically increases variability, leading to wider CIs. An overestimation due to random error would not result in a narrow CI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In meta-analyses, a narrow confidence interval around the pooled effect estimate often reflects increased precision, commonly due to the significant weight of a large study. 
  • This emphasizes the importance of considering study sizes and their influence on the overall results when interpreting forest plots.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric neurology clinic by his parents due to progressive difficulty walking and frequent falls. His parents report that he used to be physically active but now has worsening balance issues. Neurologic examination reveals gait ataxia, loss of vibratory sense and proprioception, muscle weakness in the lower extremities, and absent deep tendon reflexes. An echocardiogram is performed as part of the workup and shows hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Genetic testing reveals an autosomal recessive disorder involving an expanded GAA trinucleotide repeat in a gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Friedreich ataxia

 

  • This patient presents with a combination of ataxia, sensory deficits, muscle weakness, areflexia, and cardiac involvement, which are hallmark features of Friedreich ataxia, a degenerative disorder of the cerebellum and spinal cord. The disease:
    • Involves degeneration of the cerebellum, leading to ataxia
    • Causes degeneration of multiple spinal cord tracts, resulting in:
      • Loss of vibratory sense and proprioception
      • Muscle weakness in the lower extremities
      • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene. 
  • Frataxin plays a key role in mitochondrial iron regulation, and its loss leads to iron buildup and free radical–induced damage.
  • Friedreich ataxia typically presents in early childhood, and patients become wheelchair-bound within a few years. 
  • One of the serious systemic associations is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can be fatal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Involves progressive proximal muscle weakness in boys, usually presents by age 3–5, and lacks sensory deficits, ataxia, or loss of vibratory sense. It is X-linked recessive, not autosomal recessive.

 

Option B. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease: Causes peripheral neuropathy, foot deformities, and distal muscle wasting, but typically lacks cerebellar involvement, ataxia, or cardiac manifestations like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Ataxia-telangiectasia: Presents with ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency. While there is cerebellar involvement, it is not caused by frataxin mutation, and cardiomyopathy is not a typical feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene, leading to degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord, ataxia, loss of vibratory sense, muscle weakness, areflexia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
  • It presents in early childhood, and affected patients are typically wheelchair-bound within a few years.

questions.text: Fibropeptidase A and B are characterized by a highly negative charge. This property is primarily due to the presence of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamate and Aspartate

 

The highly negative charge of fibropeptidase A and B is due to the high content of acidic amino acids:

 

  • Glutamate (Glu) and Aspartate (Asp) possess carboxyl side chains, which are negatively charged at physiological pH.
  • These residues confer a strong net negative charge to the protein, influencing interactions such as electrostatic binding, solubility, and regulation of clot formation in the fibrinogen cascade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histidine and Alanine: Histidine is a weakly basic amino acid, and alanine is nonpolar. Neither significantly contributes to a strong negative charge on proteins.

 

Option C. Tyrosine and Phenylalanine: Both are nonpolar aromatic amino acids. They do not carry a net negative charge and do not influence protein charge in the way acidic residues do.

 

Option D. Valine and Lysine: Valine is nonpolar, and lysine is basic and positively charged. This pair would not contribute to a negative charge on a protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutamate and Aspartate, due to their acidic side chains, are responsible for the highly negative charge seen in fibropeptidase A and B, a property crucial to their biological function.

 

Basic amino acids (positively charged): Histidine, Arginine and Lysine

choices.text: Defer treatment until ALT is higher

questions.text: A 48-year-old ex-IV drug user is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C, genotype 2. Viral load is high, and transient elastography shows significant fibrosis. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sofosbuvir + velpatasvir

 

  • All HCV patients with detectable RNA are eligible for DAA (Direct acting antivirals) therapy regardless of enzyme levels. 
  • Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is effective across all genotypes and is first line for genotype 2, given for 12 weeks. 
  • Liver biopsy is not needed with noninvasive fibrosis assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ribavirin + interferon: Obsolete due to toxicity.

 

Option B. Liver biopsy before treatment: Unnecessary if fibrosis is confirmed by elastography.

 

Option D. Defer treatment until ALT is higher: Does not guide treatment initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HCV with active replication should be treated with pan-genotypic DAA regimens like sofosbuvir/velpatasvir.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Eosinophilic Granuloma are true?

 

  1. Eosinophilic Granuloma is a malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells typically involving visceral organs.
  2. A common clinical presentation is a pathologic bone fracture in an adolescent without associated skin lesions.
  3. Histology reveals a mixture of Langerhans cells and inflammatory cells, prominently featuring eosinophils.
  4. Immunohistochemistry typically shows Langerhans cells expressing CD1a and S100 markers.
  5. The condition frequently presents with widespread skin rash and lymphadenopathy in early childhood.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 2, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 2. A common clinical presentation is a pathologic bone fracture in an adolescent without associated skin lesions: Correct. The classic presentation is pathologic fracture in adolescents, with no skin involvement.

 

Statement 3. Histology reveals a mixture of Langerhans cells and inflammatory cells, prominently featuring eosinophils: Correct. Biopsy shows Langerhans cells with numerous eosinophils in a mixed inflammatory background.

 

Statement 4. Immunohistochemistry typically shows Langerhans cells expressing CD1a and S100 markers: Correct. Langerhans cells express CD1a, S100, and Langerin (CD207).
 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Eosinophilic Granuloma is a malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells typically involving visceral organs: Incorrect. Eosinophilic Granuloma is benign, not malignant, and primarily affects bone.

 

Statement 5. The condition frequently presents with widespread skin rash and lymphadenopathy in early childhood: Incorrect. This describes Letterer-Siwe disease, a multisystem form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic granuloma is a localized and benign form of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis that most commonly presents with lytic bone lesions and pathological fractures in children and adolescents. The hallmark of diagnosis includes Langerhans cells on biopsy with eosinophilic infiltrate, and immunohistochemical staining positive for CD1a and S100.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is evaluated due to reduced passage of stools and progressive abdominal distension. Examination reveals a distended abdomen. Abdominal imaging is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hirschsprung disease

 

  • Hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition caused by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, resulting in a functional obstruction. Affected neonates often present within the first week of life with:
    • Bilious vomiting (due to obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater)
    • Severe abdominal distension
    • Barium enema shows megacolon with narrowing at rectum
  • These signs point toward a low intestinal obstruction, which is classic for Hirschsprung disease. Diagnosis is confirmed via rectal biopsy showing absence of ganglion cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia:

 

  • Presents within the first 24–48 hours after birth, not typically at 7 days.
  • Characterized by non-bilious or bilious vomiting, but the classic radiographic sign is a “double bubble” with no gas in distal bowel, not multiple gas-filled loops.
  • The absence of abdominal distension and the early presentation differentiate it from Hirschsprung.

 

Option B. Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

 

  • Commonly presents between 4–8 weeks of age, not at 7 days.
  • It will show single bubble.
  • Vomiting is non-bilious because the obstruction is proximal to the duodenum, at the pylorus.
  • Physical exam often reveals an olive-like mass in the epigastrium, and imaging shows a thickened pylorus on ultrasound, not gas-filled loops on X-ray.

 

Option C. Malrotation of the gut:

 

  • Can present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension, but a hallmark complication is midgut volvulus, which often leads to acute deterioration and signs of peritonitis.
  • It would show small bowl obstruction, multiple air fluid levels
  • Imaging may show a corkscrew pattern or misplaced ligament of Treitz, not typically multiple gas-filled loops.
  • Can be difficult to distinguish early on, but the absence of peritoneal signs and more chronic course point away from malrotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a neonate with severe abdominal distension, absence of bowel sounds, and dilated colon on barium enema, Hirschsprung disease must be suspected as a cause of distal bowel obstruction.

choices.text: It typically develops 48-72 hours after cessation of alcohol intake
Visual hallucinations are more common than auditory hallucinations
It is considered a non-emergent condition that can be managed on an outpatient basis
Benzodiazepines are the first-line pharmacological treatment

questions.text: All of the following statements about delirium tremens are correct except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is considered a non-emergent condition that can be managed on an outpatient basis

 

  • Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome that represents a true medical emergency requiring immediate hospitalization and intervention. 
  • It cannot be safely managed on an outpatient basis due to the risk of severe complications including seizures, extreme autonomic instability, and potential cardiovascular collapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It typically develops 48-72 hours after cessation of alcohol intake: Correct. Delirium tremens typically develops 48-72 hours after the last alcohol intake, as stated in the main notes: "After 48-72 hours: Delirium tremens."

 

Option B. Visual hallucinations are more common than auditory hallucinations: Correct. In delirium tremens, visual hallucinations (such as seeing insects, animals, or people) are indeed more common than auditory hallucinations. This is characteristic of withdrawal delirium and helps differentiate it from primary psychotic disorders where auditory hallucinations predominate.

 

Option D. Benzodiazepines are the first-line pharmacological treatment: Correct. Benzodiazepines, particularly lorazepam, are the first-line pharmacological treatment for delirium tremens. As mentioned in the notes: "For delirium tremens- Intravenous benzodiazepines are the drugs of choice."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that typically occurs 48-72 hours after alcohol cessation, presenting with visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, and confusion, requiring hospitalization and aggressive treatment with benzodiazepines.

choices.text: High risk – Syrup Nevirapine + Zidovudine till 12 weeks
Low risk – Syrup Nevirapine till 6 weeks
High risk – Syrup Nevirapine only till 6 weeks
Low risk – Syrup Nevirapine + Zidovudine till 6 weeks

questions.text: A term infant is born to a 32-year-old woman living with HIV who has been adherent to antiretroviral therapy (ART). Her HIV viral load, measured at 34 weeks gestation, was 800 copies/mL. The delivery was uneventful, and she intends to breastfeed the infant. What is the infant's ARV risk category and appropriate prophylaxis according to national guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low risk – Syrup Nevirapine till 6 weeks

 

  • According to the Infant ARV prophylaxis guidelines, the risk category is determined primarily by the maternal viral load after 32 weeks of gestation.
  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with viral load <1000 copies/mL anytime after 32 weeks up to delivery.
  • In such cases, the infant receives monotherapy:
    • Syrup Nevirapine (preferred) or
    • Syrup Zidovudine (if Nevirapine is contraindicated)
  • Duration of prophylaxis: From birth till 6 weeks of age, regardless of feeding type.
  • In this case, the mother had a suppressed viral load (800 copies/mL at 34 weeks), qualifying the newborn as low risk, and hence only Nevirapine monotherapy for 6 weeks is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High risk – Syrup Nevirapine + Zidovudine till 12 weeks: This would apply if the infant was at high risk, especially in the case of exclusive breastfeeding. However, this mother had a suppressed viral load, so this does not apply.

 

Option C. High risk – Syrup Nevirapine only till 6 weeks: High-risk infants always require dual therapy (NVP + Zidovudine), not monotherapy, and the duration depends on feeding practices.

 

Option D. Low risk – Syrup Nevirapine + Zidovudine till 6 weeks: Dual therapy is not indicated for low-risk infants; this is an overtreatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For infant ARV prophylaxis, low-risk infants (maternal VL <1000 copies/mL after 32 weeks) receive Nevirapine monotherapy for 6 weeks, regardless of feeding type.
  • High-risk infants require Nevirapine + Zidovudine, with duration based on whether feeding is exclusive breastfeeding (12 weeks) or replacement feeding (6 weeks).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a component of the biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

  • The biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive tool used to assess fetal well-being, typically in the third trimester, especially in high-risk pregnancies. It evaluates five specific components:
    1. Amniotic fluid volume
    2. Fetal tone
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal breathing movements
    5. Non-stress test (NST)
  • Each component is scored as either 0 (absent/abnormal) or 2 (normal/present), making the total possible score 10.
  • Daily fetal movement count, also known as kick count, is a maternal perception-based method to monitor fetal activity, but it is not a formal component of the BPP. 
  • It is often used as a preliminary or adjunctive tool to monitor fetal well-being, especially in outpatient settings, but is not included in the BPP scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: This is a key parameter in the BPP. Low amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios) can indicate chronic fetal compromise, and normal volume supports adequate placental function.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone assesses flexion and extension of fetal limbs or spine. Normal tone reflects a well-oxygenated central nervous system and is an essential BPP component.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: The NST monitors fetal heart rate in response to fetal movement. A reactive NST suggests normal fetal autonomic function and is a core part of the BPP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Daily fetal movement count is not a component of the biophysical profile; the BPP includes non-stress test, amniotic fluid volume, fetal tone, fetal movements, and fetal breathing movements.

questions.text: A primigravida arrives in labor and reports painful uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced. Uterine contractions are regular and increasing in intensity. Which of the following best describes the stage of labor she is currently in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase of maximum slope

 

  • Labor is divided into three stages, and the first stage is further subdivided into latent and active phases. 
  • The active phase of the first stage of labor is typically defined as starting at 6 cm dilation, particularly in a primigravida with regular, progressive contractions.
  • Within the active phase, Friedman’s curve describes three sub-phases based on cervical dilation rate:
    1. Acceleration phase: Begins around 6 cm and marks the initial slow progression.
    2. Phase of maximum slope: This is the period of rapid cervical dilation, typically occurring between 6–8 cm to 9 cm, and is where 7 cm dilation lies.
    3. Deceleration phase: Occurs near the end of the active phase as the cervix approaches full dilation (around 9–10 cm), and the rate of dilation slows down.
  • Thus, a cervix that is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced indicates the phase of maximum slope—a time of most rapid cervical dilation within the active phase.

 

 

  • We don’t follow this now. We follow labour care guide where active labour starts at 5 cm

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deceleration phase: This occurs later in the active phase, usually between 9–10 cm dilation, when the rate of dilation slows down again. The patient has not yet reached this stage.

 

Option B. Acceleration phase: This phase occurs just after 6 cm dilation begins and is typically characterized by slower dilation than the maximum slope phase. At 7 cm, the patient is beyond the acceleration phase.

 

Option D. Latent phase: The latent phase is the earlier part of the first stage of labor, occurring from 0 to approximately 6 cm dilation. Since this patient is at 7 cm, she has clearly transitioned into the active phase, beyond the latent phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phase of maximum slope during labor corresponds to 6–9 cm dilation and represents the period of most rapid cervical change within the active phase.

choices.text: Frequent change of speaker keeps attention
Final summary is delivered by the chairman

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely characteristic or limitation of a symposium as a group education method?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Audience discussion happens throughout

 

  • In a symposium, multiple experts speak sequentially on different aspects of a topic, (health topics) in front of audience, often without interacting with each other.  
  • The format is formal and pre-structured, with minimal interaction between speakers or the audience during presentations. 
  • Audience discussion typically occurs at the end, if at all, often after the chairperson’s summary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lack of crosstalk among speakers: True. There is usually no cross-discussion between speakers during a symposium.

 

Option B. Frequent change of speaker keeps attention: True. The frequent change of speaker can help maintain audience attention.

 

Option D. Final summary is delivered by the chairman: True: It is common for the chairperson to deliver a summary at the end, synthesizing the talks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A symposium involves a series of structured expert presentations with limited audience interaction during the session and no crosstalk among speakers. Audience engagement typically occurs after all presentations conclude.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding otitis media with effusion (OME) and acute otitis media (AOM/ASOM) are true?

 

  1. In ASOM, "light house sign" or pulsatile otorrhoea is a hallmark of tympanic membrane perforation.
  2. In OME, pain is a common presenting complaint due to active infection and inflammation.
  3. The most common organisms implicated in ASOM are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.
  4. Grommet insertion through myringotomy is commonly performed in OME for permanent drainage.
  5. The most common site for myringotomy is the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. In ASOM, "light house sign" or pulsatile otorrhoea is a hallmark of tympanic membrane perforation: True. The "light house sign" (pulsating discharge through perforation) is classically described in ASOM.

 

Statement 3. The most common organisms implicated in ASOM are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae: True. These are the most common pathogens involved in ASOM.

 

Statement 4. Grommet insertion through myringotomy is commonly performed in OME for permanent drainage: True. Grommet insertion via myringotomy is a standard treatment for chronic or recurrent OME.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. In OME, pain is a common presenting complaint due to active infection and inflammation: False. OME is a non-infective condition characterized by fluid behind the tympanic membrane without inflammation or pain.

 

Statement 5. The most common site for myringotomy is the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane: False. Myringotomy is typically performed in the anteroinferior quadrant for optimal drainage and safety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "light house sign," which refers to pulsating discharge through a tympanic membrane perforation, is a characteristic feature seen during the suppurative stage of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). 
  • In contrast, otitis media with effusion (OME) is a non-infective condition marked by sterile fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane, typically without associated pain or inflammation. 
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are the most commonly implicated pathogens in ASOM. 
  • For chronic or recurrent OME, grommet insertion via myringotomy is a standard therapeutic approach. 
  • Importantly, myringotomy is usually performed in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane to ensure optimal drainage and avoid injury to important middle ear structures.

questions.text:
A tertiary hospital screens for a rare autosomal disorder using two tests in series to confirm diagnosis. 

 

  • Test A has sensitivity = 90% and specificity = 85%.
  • Test B has sensitivity = 80% and specificity = 95%. 

 

What is the combined sensitivity of these two tests when used in series?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.72

 

  • In series testing, a person must test positive on both tests to be considered truly positive.
  • The combined sensitivity in series is calculated as:
    • Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)
      = 0.90 × 0.80
      = 0.72
  • This means only 72% of actual cases will test positive on both tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When screening tests are used in series, combined sensitivity decreases because both tests must detect the disease. Use this strategy when specificity and PPV are more critical than sensitivity.

questions.text: A patient presents with macrocytic anemia and neurological disturbances. Initial labs reveal elevated homocysteine levels. To determine whether the cause is a folate deficiency or a vitamin B12 deficiency, which of the following investigations would provide the most specific distinction between the two?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood level of methylmalonate

 

  • Both folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies can cause macrocytic (megaloblastic) anemia and lead to elevated homocysteine levels, as both are required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. 
  • Therefore, homocysteine elevation cannot distinguish between the two.
  • However, methylmalonic acid (methylmalonate) levels are only elevated in vitamin B12 deficiency, because:
    • Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.
    • In vitamin B12 deficiency, this enzyme is impaired, causing methylmalonate accumulation in the blood.
    • Folate is not involved in this reaction, so methylmalonate levels remain normal in folate deficiency.
  • Thus, measuring blood methylmalonate is the best test to differentiate between folate and B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood level of methionine: Incorrect. Methionine levels may decrease in either folate or B12 deficiency due to impaired remethylation of homocysteine. It is not specific to distinguish between the two deficiencies.
