  • C3R works by increasing the stiffness of the corneal tissue, preventing further degradation of the corneal structure, and stabilizing the condition. 
  • This procedure has been shown to effectively halt disease progression and even improve corneal shape in some cases. 
  • It is particularly beneficial in patients with moderate keratoconus, like the one described in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. INTACS: INTACS are intrastromal corneal ring segments used to correct mild to moderate keratoconus by reshaping the cornea. PMMA rings are placed inside the corneal stroma. While they can improve vision, they do not address the underlying disease progression. C3R is the treatment of choice to halt progression, whereas INTACS may be used as a secondary option after stabilizing the disease or in patients with less severe keratoconus.

 

 

Option C. Penetrating keratoplasty: Penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) is a corneal transplant typically reserved for advanced keratoconus cases with significant scarring or thinning that cannot be corrected by less invasive methods. This procedure is usually considered when the condition is no longer manageable with non-surgical options, but it does not halt disease progression in the same way C3R does. PKP is a treatment for end-stage keratoconus, not for halting progression.

 

Option D. Spectacles: While spectacles can be used to correct the refractive errors in early stages of keratoconus, they do not halt disease progression. As the condition worsens, spectacles often become insufficient in providing adequate vision correction. C3R is required to stabilize the cornea and prevent further deterioration, making it the more appropriate choice in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective treatment to halt the progression of keratoconus is corneal collagen cross-linking (C3R), which strengthens and stabilizes the corneal tissue to prevent further degeneration. 
  • This is especially important in patients with moderate keratoconus, as it can slow or stop disease progression, making it a key intervention for managing this condition.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with early breast development and intermittent vaginal bleeding for the past 3 months. Physical exam confirms Tanner stage III breast development. Pelvic MRI reveals the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Juvenile granulosa cell tumor

 

  • The clinical triad of precocious puberty, ovarian mass, and MRI features of a hemorrhagic, solid-cystic lesion with sponge-like appearance is characteristic of a juvenile granulosa cell tumor (JGCT).
  • JGCT is a sex cord-stromal tumor that secretes estrogen, leading to isosexual precocious puberty in young girls.
  • On MRI, JGCT typically appears as a large, unilateral, complex mass with cystic and hemorrhagic components, often showing T1 hyperintensity due to internal hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor that is usually unilocular and purely cystic, without hemorrhage or hormonal activity. Uncommon in children.

 

Option C. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor: An androgen-secreting tumor that causes virilization (e.g., hirsutism, deep voice, clitoromegaly), not estrogenic effects like breast development and bleeding.

 

Option D. Mature cystic teratoma: Typically shows fat-fluid levels, calcifications, and tooth- or hair-like structures on imaging (best seen on CT), but does not cause estrogen-related symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile granulosa cell tumors present in prepubertal girls with estrogen excess and precocious puberty. 
  • On imaging, they are complex hemorrhagic masses with solid and cystic elements. Inhibin is a useful tumor marker.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother is brought for early diagnostic evaluation of possible perinatal HIV infection. Which of the following diagnostic tests is not appropriate for confirming HIV infection in this age group?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV ELISA

 

  • In infants under 18 months, especially in the first few months of life, HIV antibody-based tests like ELISA are not reliable for diagnosis becausematernal IgG antibodies cross the placenta and can remain in the infant’s circulation for up to 18 months, leading to false-positive results. Therefore, HIV ELISA is not used for diagnosis in infants ≤18 months old.
  • Instead, diagnosis relies on direct detection of the virus or its components.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p24 antigen detection: This method detects the viral core antigen and can be used early in infection, including in infants. It's especsially useful where PCR is unavailable.

 

Option B. HIV DNA PCR: Preferred diagnostic method for infants <18 months, as it directly detects integrated proviral DNA within host cells, unaffected by maternal antibodies.

 

Option D. Viral culture: Though not routinely used due to being time-consuming and labor-intensive, it can detect live virus and is technically valid in infants for research or confirmatory purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV ELISA is not used for diagnosis in infants under 18 months due to the presence of maternal antibodies; DNA PCR or p24 antigen detection are the preferred tests.

choices.text: Inhibits leukocyte migration to inflamed joints

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling of the right great toe. Joint aspiration confirms negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals, consistent with acute gouty arthritis. He is prescribed colchicine for symptom control. What is the primary mechanism of action of colchicine in treating acute gout?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibits leukocyte migration to inflamed joints

 

  • Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory agent used in acute gout attacks. Its primary mechanism is inhibition of microtubule polymerization, which blocks:
    • Neutrophil chemotaxis
    • Degranulation
    • Phagocytosis of urate crystals
  • This ultimately reduces the inflammatory response and relieves acute joint pain and swelling. 
  • It does not affect uric acid levels, but rather interrupts the inflammatory cascade associated with crystal-induced arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits phospholipase A2: This is the mechanism of glucocorticoids, not colchicine. Phospholipase A2 inhibition blocks arachidonic acid release, which reduces prostaglandin and leukotriene synthesis.

 

Option C. Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis: This describes the action of NSAIDs like indomethacin. Colchicine does not inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes involved in prostaglandin synthesis.

 

Option D. Inhibits DNA polymerase activity: This mechanism is unrelated to gout therapy. It is seen with drugs like acyclovir or methotrexate, but not colchicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine is a mitotic spindle inhibitor, treats acute gout by inhibiting microtubule polymerization, thereby suppressing neutrophil migration and the inflammatory response.

questions.text: A 16-year-old individual is evaluated for primary amenorrhea. On physical examination, normal breast development and external genitalia are observed. There is no history of menstruation. Laboratory testing confirms a diagnosis of 5-alpha reductase deficiency. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • 5-alpha reductase deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive condition that affects individuals with a 46, XY karyotype (genetic males). 
  • This enzyme converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is crucial for the development of male external genitalia in utero.
  • In its absence, affected individuals:
    • Are genetically male (XY)
    • Have normal testes (undescended or intra-abdominal)
    • Lack DHT, resulting in ambiguous or female-appearing external genitalia at birth
    • Have no uterus or fallopian tubes due to the action of Müllerian-inhibiting substance
    • At puberty, testosterone levels increase, which can lead to virilization
  • Hermaphroditism means disorders of sexual differentiation.
  • Since these individuals are genetically male but have female external genitalia at birth, they are classified as male pseudohermaphrodites—those with male gonads but incomplete masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True hermaphroditism: Also known as ovotesticular disorder of sexual development, this rare condition involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue. It is not related to 5-alpha reductase deficiency, and individuals typically have ambiguous genitalia, not normal female genitalia with breast development as in this case.

 

Option B. Concealed sex: This term is not a standard medical diagnosis. It may colloquially refer to deliberate masking of biological sex, but it is not used to describe intersex conditions such as 5-alpha reductase deficiency and does not apply in clinical diagnostics.

 

Option D. Female pseudohermaphrodite: This refers to individuals with 46, XX karyotype (genetic females) who are exposed to androgens in utero, causing virilized external genitalia, while internal reproductive structures remain female. This is not consistent with 5-alpha reductase deficiency, which occurs in genetic males (46, XY).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism, as seen in 5-alpha reductase deficiency, involves individuals with 46, XY karyotype, male gonads, and female or ambiguous external genitalia due to impaired DHT production.

questions.text: A 16-year-old child presents with refractory seizures. MRI brain shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions as shown in the image. MR spectroscopy shows elevated choline, alanine and lactate levels. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurocysticercosis

 

  • Neurocysticercosis is the most common parasitic infection of the central nervous system and a leading cause of seizures in children and young adults, especially in endemic areas.
  • Etiology: Caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs (pork tapeworm).
  • Imaging Findings: Classically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI or CT. (starry sky appearance -head of T. solium)
  • These lesions can be cystic, colloidal, granular-nodular, or calcified depending on the stage of the parasite.
  • MR Spectroscopy: In neurocysticercosis, especially during the colloidal vesicular stage, metabolic peaks may show:
    • Lactate (anaerobic metabolism)
    • Choline (cell membrane turnover)
    • Alanine can also be seen in degenerating cysts due to protein breakdown.
  • These findings, in the context of a teenager with seizures and classic imaging, point toward neurocysticercosis as the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasmosis: Incorrect. Common in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. Lesions are typically larger, often found in the basal ganglia, and MR spectroscopy typically does not show alanine.

 

Option B. Cryptococcosis: Incorrect. Also seen in immunocompromised patients. Shows gelatinous pseudocysts, not ring-enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy does not show alanine peaks.

 

Option D. Multiple tuberculomas: Incorrect. While tuberculomas also show ring-enhancing lesions and may show alanine, neurocysticercosis is more commonly associated with seizures in endemic regions and matches the typical imaging pattern in this age group more closely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurocysticercosis commonly presents with seizures and multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions. 
  • MR spectroscopy may show elevated choline, lactate, and alanine depending on the stage of cyst degeneration.

questions.text: In this figure, at which labeled point on the action potential the relative refractory period is located?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 & 5

 

  • The relative refractory period occurs during the repolarization and hyperpolarization phases of an action potential, where the membrane potential is returning toward resting levels but is still more negative than the normal resting potential. During this period, a stronger-than-normal stimulus is required to generate another action potential.
  • Phase 3 (Peak depolarization): At this stage, voltage-gated sodium (Na⁺) channels are inactivated, and potassium (K⁺) channels start to open, leading to repolarization. This phase corresponds to the absolute refractory period, where no new action potential can be initiated regardless of stimulus strength.
  • Phase 4 (Repolarization): The membrane potential begins to return toward the resting potential as K⁺ exits the cell through voltage-gated K⁺ channels.
  • Phase 5 (Hyperpolarization): The membrane potential temporarily becomes more negative than the resting membrane potential, as K⁺ channels remain open longer than necessary. This is the relative refractory period, where an action potential can only be triggered by a stronger-than-normal stimulus.
  • Since the relative refractory period is located during repolarization and hyperpolarization phases, the correct answer is points 4 & 5.

 

Note: Phase 1 & 2 – These correspond to the resting state and depolarization onset, respectively. The neuron is excitable here, not refractory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The relative refractory period occurs during repolarization and hyperpolarization when voltage-gated K⁺ channels remain open. 
  • A stronger stimulus than usual is required to depolarize the membrane and generate another action potential. 
  • This ensures the unidirectional propagation of nerve impulses.

choices.text: Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: A patient is fitted with a vaginal pessary as part of her management for pelvic organ prolapse. After placement, you need to assess whether the pessary is adequately retained and fits properly. Which of the following is the first step in evaluating proper retention of the pessary?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

  • After inserting a vaginal pessary, the first and most important step to assess whether it is properly retained is to ask the patient to perform a Valsalva maneuver.
  • This maneuver simulates increased intra-abdominal pressure, similar to what occurs during daily activities like coughing, straining, or lifting. If pessary is coming down, then the pessary is too loose and if she is uncomfortable or having pain during the Valsalva the pessary is too tight.
  • If the pessary remains in place during the Valsalva maneuver, it indicates proper fit and adequate retention.
  • This functional test helps assess whether the pessary will remain effective during normal physical stress and prevents expulsion during daily movements. 
  • It also helps in determining if further adjustments in size or type are necessary.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Discomfort may actually indicate that the pessary is too large or improperly positioned, not necessarily that it is adequately retained. Comfort is important, but it is not a primary method of assessing retention.

 

Option C. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: Although voiding can assess for urinary obstruction or discomfort caused by the pessary, it is not the first test to evaluate retention. This step comes later in the sequence after checking structural support and fit.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard measure to assess pessary fit or retention. In fact, excessive space may indicate a pessary that is too small and prone to falling out. This approach does not provide reliable feedback about retention under physiological conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After fitting a vaginal pessary, the first step to assess adequate retention is asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and observe if the pessary remains in place.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents at 20 weeks gestation with concerns of cervical insufficiency. Evaluation is underway for possible cerclage placement. Which of the following findings is a complete contraindication to cerclage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ruptured membranes

 

  • Cervical cerclage is a surgical procedure used to treat cervical insufficiency, typically performed between 12 and 24 weeks of gestation. 
  • Its goal is to prevent painless cervical dilation and second-trimester pregnancy loss or preterm birth.
  • We would not use cerclage whenever there is any leakage, bleeding, infection, if cervix is more than 4 cm, if there are active contractions and if the baby is dead/ anomalous.
  • Ruptured membranes (i.e., preterm premature rupture of membranes, PPROM) is considered a complete contraindication to cerclage.
  • The presence of amniotic fluid leakage significantly increases the risk of intra-amniotic infection, chorioamnionitis, and preterm labor. 
  • Placing a suture in this scenario can exacerbate infection risk, worsen maternal and fetal outcomes, and is therefore contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced maternal age: While advanced maternal age may increase the risk of pregnancy complications, it is not a contraindication to cerclage. In fact, older patients with a history of cervical insufficiency may still benefit from the procedure.

 

Option C. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin (fFN) test suggests a risk of preterm labor, but does not contraindicate cerclage. It may increase caution in decision-making, but cerclage may still be considered based on other factors like cervical length and obstetric history.

 

Option D. Membranes bulging into the vagina: Although this is a relative contraindication, and cerclage is technically more challenging, it is not an absolute or complete contraindication. Some cases may still benefit from rescue cerclage under carefully controlled conditions, especially in the absence of infection or ruptured membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage due to the high risk of infection and poor pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding somatomedins is/are true?
 

  1. Somatomedins are produced primarily by the liver in response to growth hormone stimulation.
  2. The most important somatomedin is somatomedin C, also known as IGF-1.
  3. IGF-1 has a shorter half-life than growth hormone and is rapidly cleared from circulation.
  4. IGF-1 binds to carrier proteins in the blood, which prolong its half-life.
  5. The growth-promoting effects of growth hormone are largely due to the action of somatomedins on peripheral tissues.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5 only

 

Statement 1. Somatomedins are produced primarily by the liver in response to growth hormone stimulation: True. Growth hormone stimulates the liver to produce somatomedins (mainly IGF-1).

 

Statement 2. The most important somatomedin is somatomedin C, also known as IGF-1: True. Somatomedin C (IGF-1) is the most significant among the somatomedins.

 

Statement 4. IGF-1 binds to carrier proteins in the blood, which prolong its half-life: True. IGF-1 binds to carrier proteins, extending its half-life and effects.

 

Statement 5. The growth-promoting effects of growth hormone are largely due to the action of somatomedins on peripheral tissues: True. The growth-promoting effects of GH are mainly via IGF-1 acting on bones and peripheral tissues.


Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. IGF-1 has a shorter half-life than growth hormone and is rapidly cleared from circulation: False. IGF-1 has a longer half-life (~10-15 hours) compared to growth hormone (~20-30 minutes), due to binding with carrier proteins.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Somatomedins, especially IGF-1, are key mediators of growth hormone action. Produced by the liver, they enhance bone and tissue growth, with a longer half-life than GH due to binding with plasma proteins. 
  • This mechanism is crucial for evaluating growth disorders and interpreting GH/IGF-1 lab results.

choices.text: Cuffed Endotracheal Tube is not preferred due to chance of Tracheal Stenosis
Depth of Chest Compressions is equal to A-P diameter
First Shock Energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg
In Infants, after Intubation, Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths/min

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Pediatric ACLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In Infants, after Intubation, Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths/min

 

After intubation in infants, the recommended Respiratory Rate to maintain Adequate Ventilation without over-ventilation is 20-30 Breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cuffed Endotracheal Tube is not preferred due to chance of Tracheal Stenosis: Incorrect. Current Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) guidelines indicate the use of cuffed endotracheal tubes can be beneficial in pediatrics to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent aspiration, with proper sizing and cuff pressure monitoring to minimize the risk of tracheal injury.

 

Option B. Depth of Chest Compressions is equal to A-P diameter: Incorrect. The depth of chest compressions in pediatric patients should be at least one third the anteroposterior (A-P) diameter of the chest, not equal to it.

 

Option C. First Shock Energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg: Incorrect. In pediatric advanced life support, the initial dose for defibrillation is 2 J/kg. Subsequent shock energy is 4 J/kg. Maximum shock energy given in pediatrics is 10 J/kg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Pediatric Advanced Life Support, it is recommended to use cuffed endotracheal tubes with careful monitoring, provide chest compressions at a depth of at least one third the A-P diameter of the chest, deliver the first defibrillation shock at 2-4 J/kg, and maintain a respiratory rate of 20-30 breaths per minute for infant’s post-intubation.

questions.text: A sociologist argues that the concept of "mental illness" is not just a medical diagnosis but a tool to label individuals who do not conform to institutional norms. This classification, they claim, facilitates societal control through institutional structures. Which theory is most aligned with this viewpoint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foucaultian Theory

 

  • Foucaultian Theory (by Michel Foucault) views institutions like psychiatry, prisons, and schools as mechanisms of power and social control. Foucault argued that medical classification — including the diagnosis of mental illness — is used to regulate, normalize, and discipline individuals whose behaviors diverge from accepted norms. 
  • Thus, mental illness becomes a tool of surveillance and control, not merely a biomedical issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marxist Theory: Putting profit ahead of health leads to disease. Emphasizes class conflict and economic inequality, focusing on how capitalism contributes to alienation and stress. It doesn't specifically frame mental illness as a tool of institutional surveillance.

 

Option C. Feminist Theory: Disease occur due to role of females in the society as enforced by males. Analyzes gender-based oppression and may critique psychiatric labeling of women, but it doesn’t broadly frame mental illness as a universal institutional control mechanism.

 

Option D. Parsonian Theory (Functionalism): Disease occur due to social constrains or limitations in the family or the society. Proposed by Talcott Parsons, it sees illness (including mental illness) as a form of social deviance, but it views the sick role as a way of maintaining social stability, not oppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foucaultian theory conceptualizes mental illness as a socially constructed label used to discipline and regulate deviant behavior through institutional power.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman undergoes abdominal MRI after an incidental liver lesion was discovered on ultrasound. She has no significant history. T2-weighted MRI image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic cavernous hemangioma

 

  • The MRI image shows a T2 hyperintense lesion with a well-circumscribed margin. 
  • The hallmark features of a hepatic cavernous hemangioma include:
    • Marked T2 hyperintensity (“light bulb” sign)
    • Peripheral, nodular enhancement in the arterial phase
    • Progressive centripetal fill-in in delayed phases
  • These imaging findings are diagnostic of cavernous hemangioma and do not require biopsy or follow-up if the lesion is asymptomatic and has typical features.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH): Typically iso- or slightly hyperintense on T2, shows homogeneous arterial enhancement and may have a central scar visible on delayed images.

 

Option B. Hepatic adenoma: Tends to be hypervascular, may contain fat or hemorrhage, and is often T1 hyperintense. Risk of rupture or malignant transformation exists, especially in oral contraceptive users.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): Classically shows arterial phase enhancement with rapid washout in the portal venous or delayed phase. HCC may be associated with cirrhosis, which is absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign liver lesion and shows a characteristic imaging pattern on MRI: T2 hyperintensity with peripheral nodular enhancement and progressive centripetal fill-in on post-contrast sequences.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with coronary artery disease is newly diagnosed with hypothyroidism. Which of the following cardiovascular changes occurs in hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stroke volume is reduced

 

Hypothyroidism leads to bradycardia, decreased myocardial contractility, reduced cardiac output, and increased peripheral vascular resistance. Since the heart does not contract properly, there is a reduced stroke volume. Pericardial effusions are common, and extremities are cold due to vasoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood flow to skin increases: Decreased, not increased.

 

Option C. Myocardial contractility is enhanced: Reduced, not enhanced.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion is extremely rare: Common in hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism causes bradycardia, reduced stroke volume, and increased vascular resistance; pericardial effusion is not rare.

choices.text: Accelerate transition from Stage 2 to Stage 3 by reducing fertility rates
Delay progression to Stage 4 due to increased workforce participation
Cause a regression to Stage 1 due to shifting cultural values
Have minimal impact on demographic trends

questions.text: A low–middle-income country has recently invested heavily in programs that promote female literacy, access to higher education, and reproductive autonomy. Which of the following best describes the expected demographic consequence of these developments?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accelerate transition from Stage 2 to Stage 3 by reducing fertility rates

 

  • The Demographic Transition Model (DTM) describes the transition from high birth and death rates to lower birth and death rates as a country develops economically and socially.
  • Stage 2 is marked by declining death rates but persistently high fertility, leading to rapid population growth.
  • Stage 3 begins when birth rates also start to decline, primarily due to improved education, urbanization, and access to family planning, especially among women.
  • Increased female education and empowerment leads to:
    • Delayed marriage and childbirth
    • Greater workforce participation
    • Increased use of contraception
    • Smaller desired family size
  • This combination directly lowers fertility rates, thus accelerating the shift from Stage 2 to Stage 3 of demographic transition.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delay progression to Stage 4 due to increased workforce participation: Incorrect. Increased female workforce participation typically supports continued demographic transition by reinforcing lower fertility trends, not delaying it.

 

Option C. Cause a regression to Stage 1 due to shifting cultural values: Incorrect. Stage 1 is pre-modern with high birth and death rates. No country "regresses" to this stage based on cultural shifts alone.

 

Option D. Have minimal impact on demographic trends: Incorrect. Female education is one of the most powerful levers for reducing fertility and transforming demographic patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Improving female education and reproductive autonomy is a key driver of fertility decline and facilitates a country’s progression through the demographic transition, particularly from Stage 2 to Stage 3.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the below device are true? 

 

 

  1. BAHA consists of a titanium screw, abutment, and sound processor.
  2. The titanium screw is immediately connected to the processor after insertion.
  3. BAHA is suitable for patients with congenital aural atresia or external auditory canal abnormalities.
  4. Osseointegration of the screw into the skull bone typically requires a period of around 6 months.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. BAHA consists of a titanium screw, abutment, and sound processor: True. BAHA consists of three main components – a titanium implant (screw), an abutment, and a sound processor.


Statement 3. BAHA is suitable for patients with congenital aural atresia or external auditory canal abnormalities: True. BAHA is especially useful in patients with external auditory canal problems or congenital aural atresia.


Statement 4. Osseointegration of the screw into the skull bone typically requires a period of around 6 months: True. Osseointegration usually takes about 6 months before the processor can be attached.

 

Incorrect Statement:


Statement 2. The titanium screw is immediately connected to the processor after insertion: False. The titanium screw is not connected to the processor immediately. A waiting period of around 6 months is required for osseointegration (the implant becoming integrated with the bone).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BAHA consists of three main components – a titanium implant (screw), an abutment, and a sound processor.
  • The titanium screw is not connected to the processor immediately. 
  • A waiting period of around 6 months is required for osseointegration (the implant becoming integrated with the bone).
  • BAHA is especially useful in patients with external auditory canal problems or congenital aural atresia.
  • Osseointegration usually takes about 6 months before the processor can be attached.

choices.text: Overexpression of BCL-2 preventing apoptosis of myeloblasts
Translocation of the retinoic acid receptor leading to blocked maturation of promyelocytes
Mutation in the JAK2 gene resulting in constitutive tyrosine kinase activity
Chromosomal inversion leading to abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with fatigue, easy bruising, and persistent nosebleeds over the past few weeks. On physical examination, petechiae are noted on the lower extremities. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia and prolonged PT and aPTT. Peripheral blood smear shows a predominance of blasts with numerous primary granules. Cytogenetic analysis confirms a t(15;17) translocation. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Translocation of the retinoic acid receptor leading to blocked maturation of promyelocytes

 

  • This patient has Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL), a distinct subtype of acute myeloid leukemia characterized by:
    • A t(15;17) translocation, which involves movement of the retinoic acid receptor (RAR) gene on chromosome 17 to chromosome 15.
    • This leads to formation of a PML-RARα fusion protein, which disrupts normal RAR signaling, resulting in a block in the maturation of myeloid precursors.
    • As a result, promyelocytes (blasts) accumulate in the bone marrow and blood.
    • These abnormal promyelocytes contain numerous primary granules, which can trigger disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) due to release of procoagulant substances.
  • Prompt recognition is critical, as DIC is a life-threatening complication. All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used therapeutically to overcome the maturation block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overexpression of BCL-2 preventing apoptosis of myeloblasts: Seen in follicular lymphoma, not APL. It involves t(14;18) and prevents apoptosis rather than blocking maturation.

 

Option C. Mutation in the JAK2 gene resulting in constitutive tyrosine kinase activity: Associated with myeloproliferative disorders like polycythemia vera, not APL.

 

Option D. Chromosomal inversion leading to abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation: Describes AML-M7 (megakaryoblastic leukemia) or some MPNs, not APL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL) is defined by t(15;17) translocation causing a PML-RARα fusion protein. 
  • This blocks maturation of promyelocytes, leading to accumulation of abnormal blasts with primary granules, which can trigger DIC.

questions.text: Mr. Ram, a 45-year-old man with metastatic adenocarcinoma, presents with hypotension. ECG is shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LVEDV (Left ventricular end diastolic volume)

 

  • ECG shows electrical alternans which is a classic feature of cardiac tamponade. 
  • In cardiac tamponade, rising intrapericardial pressure restricts diastolic filling, reducing left ventricular end-diastolic volume despite elevated chamber pressures. 
  • Classic signs include hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left atrial pressure: Typically increased.

 

Option C. Jugular venous pressure: Elevated due to impaired right heart filling. The ECG shows a prominent x-descent and a blunt y-descent.

 

Option D. Intrapericardial pressure: Increased in tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamponade restricts cardiac filling, lowering end-diastolic volumes despite elevated pressures.

questions.text: Match the vocal cord position with its clinical context:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A–3, B–2, C–4, D–1


A-3. Median → Seen during speech or swallowing: The median position is seen during phonation or swallowing.

 

B-2. Paramedian → Seen in recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: The paramedian position indicates recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.


C-4. Intermediate/Cadaveric→ Seen in complete paralysis: The intermediate/cadaveric position is classic for bilateral complete laryngeal paralysis.


D-1. Slight abduction → Seen during normal respiration: Slight abduction reflects normal relaxed respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Tumor arises as a high-grade flat lesion with early p53 mutation and subsequent invasion
Tumor arises as a low-grade flat lesion with early p53 mutation that progresses to high-grade and then invades
Tumor arises from urothelial metaplasia to squamous cells due to chronic irritation
Tumor arises as a high-grade papillary lesion due to early p53 mutation and then invades

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with painless hematuria. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Cystoscopy reveals multiple lesions in the bladder. Biopsy of one lesion is shown below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for early p53 mutations. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this patient’s cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor arises as a high-grade flat lesion with early p53 mutation and subsequent invasion

 

  • This 72-year-old man presents with painless hematuria, a classic symptom of urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma, the most common form of bladder cancer. He also has a significant 40-pack-year smoking history, which is a major risk factor for this malignancy.
  • Cystoscopy reveals multiple lesions in the bladder. This aligns with a critical concept in urothelial carcinoma pathogenesis: tumors are often multifocal and recur, a phenomenon referred to as a "field defect".
  • Histologic examination of the bladder biopsy shows a high-grade flat lesion, as illustrated in the image, and the Immunohistochemistry specifies early p53 mutations, both of which point directly to the flat pathway of urothelial carcinoma development.
  • Urothelial carcinoma arises via two distinct pathways:
  1. Flat – This pathway involves development of a high-grade flat tumor that then invades. It is specifically associated with early p53 mutations, consistent with this patient’s presentation.
  2. Papillary – This pathway involves development as a low-grade papillary tumor that progresses to a high-grade papillary tumor and then invades. This route is not associated with early p53 mutations.
  • This patient’s presentation of high-grade flat histology, early p53 mutation, and multifocality fits perfectly with the flat pathway described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tumor arises as a low-grade flat lesion with early p53 mutation that progresses to high-grade and then invades: Incorrect. The flat pathway, as outlined in the document, does not begin as a low-grade lesion. It specifically begins as a high-grade flat tumor, which is already advanced and then invades. Early p53 mutations are only associated with the flat pathway, which starts as high-grade, not low-grade. A progression from low-grade to high-grade is only seen in the papillary pathway, which begins as a low-grade papillary tumor, not flat.

 

Option C. Tumor arises from urothelial metaplasia to squamous cells due to chronic irritation: Incorrect. This describes the pathogenesis of squamous cell carcinoma, not urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma. The stem and the document focus solely on urothelial carcinoma, which arises via flat and papillary pathways, not squamous metaplasia. There is no mention of chronic irritation or metaplasia in this case or in the provided material.

 

Option D. Tumor arises as a high-grade papillary lesion due to early p53 mutation and then invades: Incorrect. The papillary pathway described in the document does not begin as a high-grade lesion, but rather as a low-grade papillary tumor that progresses to high-grade. Moreover, the papillary route is not associated with early p53 mutations. The presence of an early p53 mutation and high-grade flat histology points away from this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma arises via two distinct pathways:

 

  • The flat pathway begins as a high-grade flat tumor and then invades and is associated with early p53 mutations.
  • The papillary pathway begins as a low-grade papillary tumor that progresses to high-grade and then invades and is not associated with early p53 mutations.
  • Additionally, tumors are often multifocal and recur due to a field defect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident that resulted in significant blood loss. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, and shows signs of poor perfusion. You are evaluating his cardiac performance using the Frank-Starling mechanism as shown in the image below. Given the clinical scenario of severe hemorrhage with uncompensated hypovolemic shock, which of the following points on the Frank-Starling curve best represents the shift in stroke volume from point X?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point E

 

  • In severe hemorrhage, there is a marked loss of circulating blood volume, leading to:
    • ↓ Central venous pressure (preload)
    • ↓ Cardiac output/stroke volume
  • In the Frank-Starling curve, the heart’s stroke volume declines when venous return (preload) falls.
  • Point X represents the patient’s baseline function. After severe blood loss, preload drastically drops, shifting the operating point downward and to the left on a lower curve of myocardial performance — Point E, which reflects both reduced central venous pressure and cardiac output.
  • Point A still shows higher output than expected for uncompensated shock.
  • Point B/C suggest increased preload or inotropic support — not applicable here.
  • Point D is closer to X but still above the expected level for severe uncompensated shock.
  • Point E best matches the expected physiological deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the setting of acute severe hemorrhage, the Frank-Starling relationship shifts due to a significant decrease in venous return (preload). 
  • This results in decreased cardiac output, represented by a downward-left shift on the Frank-Starling curve. 
  • Clinical recognition of this shift is essential for prompt fluid resuscitation and hemodynamic stabilization in hypovolemic shock.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has ongoing tonic-clonic seizures for over 25 minutes despite lorazepam. Seizures resume after paralytic wears off. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin fosphenytoin 20 mg/kg IV

 

  • This is generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE). [seizures > 5 mins or 2-3 seizures without gain of consciousness in between]
  • After benzodiazepines, second-line agents like fosphenytoin or valproate should be given. 
  • Paralytics mask seizures but don’t treat them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give Neuromuscular blockers: Do not treat seizures. Can be given if there is a plan to intubate.

 

Option C. Administer pentobarbital bolus: Reserved for refractory seizures. Given in advanced stage.

 

Option D. Initiate isoflurane anesthesia: Last-resort ICU management. Given in ultra-refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Second-line treatment for GCSE includes IV fosphenytoin; paralytics should not be used as definitive seizure control.

choices.text: Presents with ulcers at atypical locations
Metastasis at the time of presentation is extremely rare
The majority of the tumours are seen within the duodenum
Diarrhoea occurs due to excess gastric acid

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metastasis at the time of presentation is extremely rare

 

  • This is a malignancy. More than 50% of time it will be malignant.
  • There will be lymph node mets or liver mets.
  • The majority of gastrinomas have metastasized by the time of presentation, making it a critical factor in the prognosis and management of the disease.
  • Treatment will be radical excision

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presents with ulcers at atypical locations: This is correct. Patients with gastrinoma often present with peptic ulcers in atypical locations like D1/D2/D3/D4, jejunum due to high levels of gastrin leading to excessive gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. The Majority of the tumors are seen within the duodenum: This is correct. While gastrinomas can occur both within and outside the pancreas, the majority are found within the duodenum, particularly within the area known as the gastrinoma triangle.

 

Option D. Diarrhoea occurs due to excess gastric acid: This is correct. Diarrhea is another common symptom, caused by the large volume of gastric acid secretion. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a condition that includes:
    • Fulminating ulcer diathesis in the stomach, duodenum or atypical sites
    • Recurrent ulceration despite ‘adequate’ therapy 
    • Non-β islet cell tumours of the pancreas (gastrinoma)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male athlete presents to the emergency department after injuring his left hand during a football game. He reports that while attempting to tackle an opponent, his finger became caught in the opponent’s jersey, and he felt a sudden “pop” in his finger. On examination, there is inability to flex the distal phalanx of the left ring finger, and there is tenderness over the flexor tendon at the base of the finger. X-rays do not show any fractures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jersey finger

 

  • Caused by forceful extension of a flexed finger, such as when a player grabs a jersey and the finger is pulled back.
  • Most commonly affects the ring finger.
  • Results in rupture or avulsion of the FDP tendon from the distal phalanx.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Inability to flex the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint
    • Pain and tenderness along the volar aspect of the finger
  • Requires urgent surgical repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mallet finger:

 

  • Caused by forced flexion of an extended finger, often from a ball hitting the tip of the finger.
  • Results in rupture of the extensor tendon at the DIP joint.
  • Clinical sign: inability to extend the distal phalanx, but flexion is preserved.
  • This is the opposite of Jersey finger, which affects flexion, not extension.

 

Option C. Boutonnière deformity:

 

  • Results from injury to the central slip of the extensor tendon at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint.
  • Often due to trauma or in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Clinical appearance:
    • Flexion at the PIP joint
    • Hyperextension at the DIP joint
  • Develops over time, not as an acute “pop” injury.
  • Not consistent with inability to flex the DIP joint.

     

Option D. Trigger finger:

 

  • Caused by inflammation and thickening of the flexor tendon sheath, often at the A1 pulley.
  • Results in catching or locking of the finger during flexion or extension.
  • More of a chronic overuse condition, not an acute injury.
  • Typically, painful snapping or locking rather than sudden rupture and loss of motion.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic signs of Jersey finger: traumatic avulsion of the FDP tendon, most often in the ring finger, with loss of flexion at the DIP joint after forceful extension of a flexed finger.
  • This is a surgical emergency to prevent permanent loss of function.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with newly diagnosed Graves disease is in her first trimester of pregnancy. At her 20-week fetal anatomy scan, the ultrasound reveals an absence of skin over the scalp vertex, consistent with aplasia cutis. Which of the following medications taken during early pregnancy is most likely responsible for this fetal anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methimazole

 

  • Methimazole (&/or carbimazole), an antithyroid thionamide used to treat hyperthyroidism, is associated with teratogenic effects when used in the first trimester of pregnancy. One of the characteristic congenital anomalies linked to early gestational exposure is aplasia cutis congenita, most commonly affecting the scalp vertex. This is why methimazole is typically avoided in the first trimester, and propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during early pregnancy to reduce fetal risk.
  • After the first trimester, methimazole may be used again, as PTU carries a higher risk of hepatotoxicity with prolonged use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propylthiouracil: PTU is preferred in the first trimester specifically to avoid methimazole's teratogenic effects. While not risk-free (e.g., risk of hepatotoxicity), PTU has not been linked to aplasia cutis.

 

Option C. Radioactive iodine: Contraindicated in all trimesters of pregnancy. It crosses the placenta and ablates the fetal thyroid, leading to fetal hypothyroidism and goiter, not aplasia cutis.

 

Option D. Levothyroxine: Used to treat hypothyroidism; it is not teratogenic. In fact, adequate maternal thyroxine is essential for normal fetal neurodevelopment, especially in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Avoid methimazole/carbimazole in the first trimester → risk of aplasia cutis
  • Use PTU in early pregnancy, switch to methimazole later to reduce hepatotoxicity risk
  • Radioactive iodine is contraindicated throughout pregnancy
  • Levothyroxine is safe and necessary in hypothyroid pregnant patients

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with COPD and FEV₁ 44% predicted presents for follow-up after frequent exacerbations. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Which therapy is most likely to reduce his future COPD exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Roflumilast 500 μg daily

 

  • Roflumilast, a PDE-4 inhibitor, reduces COPD exacerbations in patients with FEV₁ <50% and chronic bronchitis. 
  • It has anti-inflammatory action and is especially useful in frequent exacerbators not controlled on inhalers alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin 250 mg three times weekly: Acts as an immunomodulator and reduce frequency of infections that may exacerbated COPD. Needs daily dosing of 500 mg once a day for proven efficacy.

 

Option B. Continuous home oxygen therapy: Only indicated for PaO₂ <55 mmHg.

 

Option C. Nocturnal BiPAP: Used in patients with neuromuscular disorders, chronic type II respiratory failure, and chronic hypercapnia, but not as preventive therapy in COPD exacerbation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roflumilast reduces exacerbations in severe COPD with chronic bronchitis and is used in addition to inhaled therapies.

questions.text: A patient with a deep-seated brain tumor is scheduled for radiation therapy. The treatment plan includes using a type of radiation that delivers the highest energy dose at the end of its path, minimizing exposure to the surrounding healthy brain tissue. This technique is advantageous for treating the tumor while preserving as much healthy tissue as possible. Which type of radiation achieves this through the Bragg's peak effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protons

 

  • Bragg's peak effect is seen in proton radiation therapy.
  • Proton therapy exhibits the Bragg's peak effect, wherein protons release most of their energy at a specific depth, corresponding to the tumor location, which is an ideal characteristic for targeting tumors and sparing healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-rays: X-rays deliver a dose along their entire path through the body, which includes both the tumor and healthy tissue, without a distinct peak where the maximum dose is delivered.

 

Option B. Neutrons: Neutron therapy also delivers energy along its path but lacks the precision of the Bragg's peak, leading to more widespread tissue exposure.

 

Option D. Electrons: Electron beams deliver energy relatively superficially and are not used for deep-seated tumors due to the lack of depth penetration compared to proton therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bragg's peak effect is characteristic of proton radiation therapy, where protons deliver the highest dose of radiation at the end of their path, at the tumor site, sparing the surrounding healthy tissues. 
  • This property makes proton therapy an excellent choice for treating localized tumors where precision is paramount.
  • Dose-Depth Curve

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemia

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after suffering a massive myocardial infarction. On day 3 of his hospitalization, his urine output drops significantly. Laboratory studies reveal the following: 

 

  • Serum BUN: 48 mg/dL
  • Serum Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL
  • Urine Sodium: 48 mEq/L
  • Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FENa): 3.1%
  • Urine Osmolality: 320 mOsm/kg
  • Urinalysis: Brown, granular casts

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemia

 

  • This patient has intrarenal acute kidney injury evidenced by:
    • Elevated BUN and creatinine
    • Low BUN: Cr ratio (<15) indicating tubular dysfunction
    • High FENa (>2%) and low urine osmolality (<500 mOsm/kg) suggesting impaired reabsorption
    • Brown granular casts on urinalysis, a hallmark of ATN
  • He suffered ischemic injury due to hypotension post-myocardial infarction, with particular vulnerability of the proximal tubule and medullary thick ascending limb.
  • Importantly, ischemic ATN is often preceded by prerenal azotemia, which is relevant given the myocardial infarction (a cause of decreased renal perfusion) earlier in his hospitalization. 
  • Therefore, all pathophysiological elements and laboratory findings point toward acute tubular necrosis due to ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prerenal azotemia: This is often the preceding event in ischemic ATN, caused by decreased blood supply, such as from a myocardial infarction. However, in prerenal azotemia, the tubular epithelium is still functional, so you'd expect a serum BUN:Cr ratio > 15, FENa < 1%, and urine osmolality > 500 mOsm/kg. This patient has the opposite findings and additionally presents with brown, granular casts, which are not seen in prerenal azotemia. Thus, prerenal azotemia is incorrect, but relevant as a potential prelude to the ischemic injury.

 

Option C. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the interstitium and is often drug-induced. It presents with eosinophils in urine, fever, rash, and white blood cell casts—none of which are mentioned in the case. Additionally, the document makes no reference to interstitial involvement, ruling this out.

 

Option D. Postrenal azotemia due to obstruction: In this condition, obstruction causes back pressure and decreased GFR. However, the hallmark finding of necrotic tubular epithelial cells plugging tubules with brown granular casts is specific to ATN. Moreover, postrenal azotemia typically shows variable FENa and often requires imaging evidence of obstruction, none of which is discussed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is the most common cause of acute renal failure (intrarenal azotemia) and is characterized by injury and necrosis of tubular epithelial cells, leading to brown, granular casts, BUN:Cr ratio < 15, FENa > 2%, and urine osm < 500 mOsm/kg. Ischemia, especially after events like myocardial infarction, often precedes it and primarily affects the proximal tubule and medullary thick ascending limb.

questions.text: What is this type of epithelium shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urinary bladder

 

  • The image shows transitional epithelium (also known as urothelium), which is characteristic of the urinary bladder. 
  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized type of epithelium that can stretch and expand to accommodate fluctuating volumes of fluid, such as urine in the bladder. 
  • This epithelium has a distinctive appearance with multiple layers of cells. When the bladder is relaxed, the surface cells (dome-shaped or umbrella cells) appear rounded. 
  • When the bladder is distended with urine, these surface cells flatten out, allowing the bladder to stretch without tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum is lined with simple columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells for absorption and secretion. It does not exhibit the multilayered and dome-shaped surface cells seen in transitional epithelium.

 

Option B. Esophagus: Incorrect. The esophagus is lined with stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium to protect against mechanical stress during swallowing. It does not have the distensible properties of transitional epithelium.

 

Option C. Vagina: Incorrect. The vagina is lined with stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, which is designed to withstand friction and mechanical stress during intercourse and childbirth. It does not have the elastic properties seen in transitional epithelium, which are essential for the urinary bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is found in the urinary bladder and other parts of the urinary tract, such as the ureters and the proximal urethra. 
  • It is uniquely adapted to stretch and expand in response to varying volumes of urine, allowing the bladder to fill and empty without damage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of bradycardia and essential hypertension requires beta-blocker therapy. The physician selects a medication that exerts beta-blockade but also has partial agonist activity, which minimizes the risk of resting bradycardia. Which of the following beta-blockers has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA) and is therefore most appropriate in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pindolol

 

  • Pindolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that exhibits intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA), meaning it partially stimulates beta-adrenergic receptors while simultaneously blocking the stronger endogenous catecholamine effects. This unique profile results in:
    • Less resting bradycardia
    • Less reduction in cardiac output
    • Useful in patients with bradyarrhythmia or heart block risk
  • Pindolol’s ISA makes it suitable for patients who require beta-blockade but cannot tolerate full antagonism, especially those with baseline low heart rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sotalol: A non-selective beta-blocker with Class III antiarrhythmic properties, used in arrhythmias. It has no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and may worsen bradycardia.

 

Option C. Labetalol: A mixed alpha and beta-blocker, often used in hypertensive emergencies and pregnancy. It does not have partial agonist (ISA) activity.

 

Option D. Propranolol: A non-selective beta-blocker with no ISA. It fully blocks beta-receptors and can cause significant bradycardia, particularly at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pindolol is a beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, making it preferred in patients who need beta-blockade but are prone to bradycardia.

 

Note: Celiprolol, Pindolol, Alprenolol and Acebutolol – contains partial agonistic activity

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Malignant mesothelioma, a rare and aggressive neoplasm, predominantly arises in the pleural cavity but is unrelated to inhalational environmental carcinogens.

 

Reason (R): Mesothelial cells, which form the lining of the pleura, can be exposed to asbestos fibers that migrate from alveoli to the pleural surface, initiating persistent inflammation, DNA damage, and eventual malignant transformation.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is false, but R is true.

 

  • The assertion (A) is false because malignant mesothelioma is, in fact, strongly associated with occupational and environmental exposure to asbestos fibers. This link is well-established epidemiologically and pathophysiologically.
  • The reason (R) is true. It accurately describes the mechanism: mesothelial cells lining the pleura are directly exposed to asbestos fibers, which, once inhaled, migrate from the alveoli to the pleural surface, causing chronic inflammation, reactive oxygen species–mediated DNA damage, and ultimately carcinogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malignant mesothelioma is strongly associated with inhalational exposure to asbestos. 
  • Inhaled asbestos fibers can migrate to the pleural surface, where they induce chronic inflammation, DNA damage, and malignant transformation of mesothelial cells, leading to the development of this aggressive neoplasm.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is evaluated during an outbreak of severe respiratory illness in a daycare setting. Public health officials emphasize the importance of capsular polysaccharide-based vaccines in preventing life-threatening bacterial infections that rely on capsule-mediated virulence. Which of the following pathogens does not rely on a polysaccharide capsule as a major virulence factor responsible for generating a protective antibody response?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bordetella pertussis

 

  • Most encapsulated bacteria use their capsular polysaccharide as a key virulence factor to:
    • Evade phagocytosis
    • Trigger protective antibody responses
    • Serve as targets in conjugate vaccines
  • Haemophilus influenzae type B, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Neisseria meningitidis all possess well-characterized polysaccharide capsules, which are:
    • Critical for virulence
    • Used in vaccine formulations to induce protective immunity
  • In contrast:
    • Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough, does not rely on a capsule for virulence. Instead, its main virulence factors include:
      • Pertussis toxin
      • Filamentous hemagglutinin
      • Adenylate cyclase toxin
      • Tracheal cytotoxin
  • These factors aid in adherence to respiratory epithelium and immune evasion, but a capsular polysaccharide is not central to its pathogenicity or vaccine design.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Incorrect. Its capsule is a key virulence determinant. Over 90 serotypes exist, and the capsule is central to current pneumococcal vaccines (e.g., PCV13, PPSV23).

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Incorrect. Possesses a polysaccharide capsule, essential for invasive disease. Vaccines target serogroup-specific capsular antigens (e.g., A, C, Y, W-135).

 

Option D. Haemophilus influenzae type B: Incorrect. The type b capsule (polyribosylribitol phosphate, PRP) is the target of the Hib vaccine, critical in preventing meningitis and epiglottitis in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bordetella pertussis does not depend on a capsular polysaccharide for virulence or immune protection, unlike other encapsulated bacteria such as H. influenzae type b, S. pneumoniae, and N. meningitidis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hospitalized patient with multidrug-resistant gram-negative sepsis is started on a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic. The physician notes that the selected drug must be co-administered with another agent to prevent its renal degradation by dehydropeptidase-1 (DHP-1) in the proximal tubules. Which of the following antibiotics requires cilastatin for preservation of its efficacy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic that is rapidly degraded in the kidney by the enzyme dihydropeptidase-1 (DHP-1). To prevent this, it is co-administered with cilastatin, a specific inhibitor of DHP-1.
    • Cilastatin prevents renal metabolism, thereby increasing imipenem’s plasma half-life and therapeutic efficacy.
    • Cilastatin also reduces nephrotoxic metabolites, offering renal protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meropenem: Meropenem is also a carbapenem but is not significantly degraded by DHP-1 and therefore does not require cilastatin co-administration.

 

Option C. Piperacillin: A broad-spectrum ureidopenicillin, often combined with tazobactam (a beta-lactamase inhibitor), but it does not require cilastatin.

 

Option D. Cefazolin: A first-generation cephalosporin that is not a substrate for DHP-1 and does not need cilastatin for its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imipenem must be co-administered with cilastatin to inhibit renal dihydropeptidase-1, thereby preventing its inactivation and preserving its antimicrobial efficacy.

choices.text: A constant fraction of the drug is cleared per unit time regardless of concentration
The rate of drug elimination remains unchanged, but the half-life decreases with concentration
The same quantity of drug is eliminated per unit time irrespective of dose
Aspirin exclusively follows first-order elimination under all physiological conditions

questions.text: A patient is prescribed an oral antihypertensive agent that follows first-order elimination kinetics. During a follow-up, a resident is analyzing the drug’s pharmacokinetic profile, particularly how plasma concentration affects elimination and half-life. Which of the following statements is accurate regarding drugs that follow first-order kinetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A constant fraction of the drug is cleared per unit time regardless of concentration

 

  • In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination is directly proportional to the drug concentration. 
  • This means a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time.
  • Importantly, half-life remains constant across varying concentrations because clearance and volume of distribution do not change in this kinetic model. 
  • Most drugs follow this model under therapeutic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The rate of drug elimination remains unchanged, but the half-life decreases with concentration: This describes characteristics more aligned with zero-order kinetics, not first-order. In first order, both the elimination rate and drug concentration change, while the half-life stays constant.

 

Option C. The same quantity of drug is eliminated per unit time irrespective of dose: This is a hallmark of zero-order kinetics, such as with phenytoin or high-dose ethanol, where a fixed amount (not fraction) is eliminated per unit time.

 

Option D. Aspirin exclusively follows first-order elimination under all physiological conditions: Aspirin follows zero-order kinetics at high doses used as anti-inflammatory drug but first order kinetics at low doses. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time, and half-life remains constant regardless of plasma concentration.

choices.text: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts and loss of anterior horn cells
Inflammatory mononuclear infiltration of spinal roots

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has progressive foot drop and hand weakness. Examination reveals tongue fasciculations, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar responses. Which of the following best describes the expected pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneration of corticospinal tracts and loss of anterior horn cells

 

  • The findings suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which affects both upper (hyperreflexia, spasticity) and lower motor neurons (fasciculations, atrophy). 
  • Pathology shows degeneration of corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Demyelination of peripheral nerves: Seen in GBS or CIDP.
 

Option C. Autoantibodies at motor endplates: Seen in myasthenia gravis.
 

Option D. Inflammatory mononuclear infiltration of spinal roots: Found in viral neuritis, not ALS.

 

Educational Objective:
 

ALS involves both UMN and LMN degeneration with corticospinal tract and anterior horn cell loss.

choices.text: The analog becomes covalently bound to the enzyme and inhibits it
There is no 3′ hydroxyl group to form the next phosphodiester bond
The analog can’t hydrogen bond to the DNA template
Incorporation of the analog initiates rapid degradation of the newly synthesized strand

questions.text: A patient is being treated with antiviral therapy targeting reverse transcriptase. The drug used is a nucleoside analogue, specifically a 2′,3′-dideoxynucleotide (e.g., ddATP). How does this class of drug effectively inhibit viral DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is no 3′ hydroxyl group to form the next phosphodiester bond

 

  • 2′,3′-dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs), are used in antiviral therapy (e.g., zidovudine, didanosine) and in Sanger sequencing due to their unique mechanism of action:
    • These molecules lack a hydroxyl group (-OH) at the 3′ position of the sugar ring.
    • During DNA chain elongation, the 3′ OH group is essential for forming a phosphodiester bond with the incoming nucleotide’s phosphate group.
    • Without a 3′ OH, once the ddNTP is incorporated into the growing DNA strand by reverse transcriptase, no further nucleotides can be added, resulting in chain termination.
    • This halts viral DNA synthesis, preventing HIV from replicating effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The analog becomes covalently bound to the enzyme and inhibits it: Incorrect. ddNTPs do not covalently bind to reverse transcriptase. Their action is due to incorporation into the DNA chain, not enzyme inhibition through binding.

 

Option C. The analog can’t hydrogen bond to the DNA template: Incorrect. ddNTPs retain the base pairing capability and can hydrogen bond with complementary bases on the template strand. The issue is with chain elongation, not base pairing.

 

Option D. Incorporation of the analog initiates rapid degradation of the newly synthesized strand: Incorrect. There is no active degradation initiated. The strand is simply terminated prematurely due to the lack of a 3′ OH group, not destroyed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dideoxynucleotides inhibit DNA synthesis by lacking a 3′ hydroxyl group, which is necessary for forming phosphodiester bonds, thus causing chain termination when incorporated by reverse transcriptase during viral replication.

choices.text: It is most commonly seen in the elderly
Oral erosions are very frequently seen
Tense bullae are a characteristic feature

questions.text: A male presents with intensely pruritic blisters on his lower abdomen and flexural aspects of the arms. On examination, tense bullae are seen. Direct immunofluorescence is as shown below with linear deposition of IgG along the basement membrane zone. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral erosions are very frequently seen

 

  • The clinical and histopathologic findings are characteristic of Bullous Pemphigoid, a subepidermal autoimmune blistering disease.
  • It typically affects elderly patients, often above 70 years.
  • Tense bullae are the hallmark feature due to the subepidermal blistering, often appearing on the flexor surfaces of limbs and lower abdomen.
  • Nikolsky sign is negative, unlike pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Oral erosions are rare, not common, which makes option B the incorrect statement.
  • On direct immunofluorescence, a linear pattern of IgG deposition at the dermoepidermal junction (BMZ) is seen in BP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous pemphigoid presents with tense bullae, linear IgG deposition along the basement membrane, and is most common in the elderly; oral erosions are uncommon.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman visits the outpatient clinic seeking help for tobacco addiction. She is looking for a prescription medication to assist in smoking cessation. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate to prescribe in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varenicline

 

  • Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the brain. It is specifically designed to aid in smoking cessation by:
    • Partially stimulating the receptor to reduce withdrawal symptoms
    • Blocking nicotine binding, thereby reducing the rewarding effects of smoking
  • Clinical trials have shown it to be more effective than bupropion or nicotine patches alone in achieving smoking abstinence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disulfiram: Used for alcohol use disorder, it inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing acetaldehyde accumulation and aversive reactions when alcohol is consumed. It has no role in tobacco cessation.

 

Option C. Flumazenil: A benzodiazepine receptor antagonist, used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. It is not indicated for tobacco or nicotine dependence.

 

Option D. Naloxone: An opioid antagonist, used in opioid overdose. It has no effect on nicotine addiction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is a partial nicotinic receptor agonist and the drug of choice for smoking cessation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of early satiety, fatigue, and weight loss. Physical examination reveals marked splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia. A bone marrow aspiration is attempted but yields a "dry tap." A bone marrow biopsy reveals B lymphocytes with cytoplasmic projections that stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell leukemia

 

  • Hairy cell leukemia is a rare neoplastic proliferation of mature B lymphocytes characterized by hairy cytoplasmic projections visible on peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy. 
  • The cells classically stain positive for TRAP (tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase).
  • Key clinical features include:
    • Splenomegaly, particularly involving the red pulp.
    • Pancytopenia due to marrow infiltration and fibrosis.
    • "Dry tap" on bone marrow aspiration because of fibrosis.
    • Lymphadenopathy is typically absent, helping distinguish it from other leukemias/lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): Usually presents with lymphocytosis and generalized lymphadenopathy cells are small mature lymphocytes with "smudge cells" on smear.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Characterized by immature myeloblasts and Auer rods, not mature B cells or TRAP positivity.

 

Option D. Follicular lymphoma: Typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy and t(14;18) translocation not associated with hairy cells or dry tap.
 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hairy cell leukemia is a chronic B-cell leukemia characterized by hairy cytoplasmic projections, TRAP positivity, splenomegaly, and dry tap due to bone marrow fibrosis. 
  • It is important to distinguish this from other hematologic malignancies.

questions.text:
Match each Non-Tuberculous Mycobacterium (NTM) species with its associated clinical condition: 

 

 

Choose the correct matching combination.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4

 

A-2. Mycobacterium marinum → causes swimming pool/fish tank granuloma 

 

B-3. Mycobacterium ulcerans → causes Buruli ulcer, a necrotic skin lesion 

 

C-1. Mycobacterium chelonae (and M. fortuitum) → cause post-injection/post-trauma abscesses 

 

D-4. Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) → causes opportunistic infections in HIV-positive individuals 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different species of non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are associated with specific clinical conditions such as M. marinum with fish tank granuloma, M. ulcerans with Buruli ulcer, M. chelonae with injection abscesses, and MAC with opportunistic infections in HIV.

choices.text: It contains a single-stranded DNA genome
It has an icosahedral capsid structure
Hemorrhagic cystitis is associated with serotypes 11 and 21
Pediatric gastroenteritis is linked to serotype 40

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, conjunctivitis, and dysuria. Urine analysis shows hematuria without pyuria, and stool culture is negative despite episodes of non-bloody diarrhea. Based on clinical suspicion, Adenovirus infection is considered. Which of the following statements regarding Adenovirus is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It contains a single-stranded DNA genome

 

  • Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with the following important features:
    • It possesses an icosahedral capsid, which is a symmetric protein shell.
    • Serotypes 11 and 21 are well-known causes of hemorrhagic cystitis, particularly in young boys.
    • Serotype 40 and 41 are associated with pediatric diarrheal illness, especially in infants and young children, and can be detected in stool samples.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has an icosahedral capsid structure: True. Adenoviruses have a naked icosahedral capsid, which helps in environmental stability and transmission.

 

Option C. Hemorrhagic cystitis is associated with serotypes 11 and 21: True. These serotypes are uropathogenic and linked to acute hemorrhagic cystitis, mostly in boys.

 

Option D. Pediatric gastroenteritis is linked to serotype 40: True. Adenovirus serotypes 40 and 41 are enteric types that cause diarrhea in young children, especially in daycare or hospital settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoviruses are double-stranded DNA viruses with an icosahedral capsid; certain serotypes cause hemorrhagic cystitis and pediatric diarrhea, but they do not possess a single-stranded DNA genome.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department after an intentional overdose of an unknown substance. The toxicology team is considering hemodialysis as part of the management. For which of the following substances is hemodialysis least likely to be beneficial due to pharmacokinetic properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Digoxin

 

  • Digoxin has a very large volume of distribution (Vd) and is extensively bound to tissue proteins, especially in the myocardium. Due to this high tissue binding and low serum levels, hemodialysis is ineffective in removing significant amounts of digoxin from the body. 
  • Management of digoxin toxicity instead relies on digoxin-specific antibody fragments (digoxin immune Fab) and supportive care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salicylates: Hemodialysis is highly effective in salicylate poisoning, especially in severe toxicity, because salicylates are water-soluble, low protein bound, and have a small Vd, making them readily dialyzable.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is a small ion, not protein-bound, and has a small Vd, making it an ideal candidate for removal via hemodialysis, particularly in severe or chronic toxicity.

 

Option D. Methanol: Very small molecule, water-soluble, not protein-bound, and low Vd (~0.6 L/kg). It is rapidly metabolized to formic acid, which causes toxicity (metabolic acidosis, optic neuropathy). Hemodialysis is highly effective to remove both methanol and its toxic metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemodialysis is not effective for substances like digoxin due to high tissue binding and large volume of distribution.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with a 2-month history of headaches, morning vomiting, and unsteady gait. Neurologic exam reveals ataxia. MRI of the brain shows a cystic lesion with a mural nodule in the cerebellum. Surgical resection is performed. Histopathologic examination of the tumor is shown below. Tumor cells stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pilocytic astrocytoma

 

  • This patient has a classic presentation of pilocytic astrocytoma, which is a benign tumor of astrocytes. It is the most common CNS tumor in children and typically arises in the cerebellum.
  • Neuroimaging often shows a cystic lesion with a mural nodule, a radiologic hallmark of this tumor. Biopsy findings are diagnostic and include:
    • Rosenthal fibers – Thick, eosinophilic processes of astrocytes
    • Eosinophilic granular bodies
    • GFAP positivity – Confirming the astrocytic origin of the tumor
  • Despite its location and potential to cause symptoms (due to mass effect), pilocytic astrocytoma is benign and has a good prognosis with surgical resection.

 

 

Other Options:
