Option A. Medulloblastoma: While also a pediatric cerebellar tumor, medulloblastoma is malignant, shows small round blue cells, and often causes drop metastases via CSF. It does not have Rosenthal fibers or the described imaging features.

 

Option C. Ependymoma: More commonly arises in the 4th ventricle and may present with hydrocephalus. Histology typically shows perivascular pseudorosettes, not Rosenthal fibers or GFAP+ astrocytic cells.

 

Option D. Glioblastoma multiforme: A high-grade astrocytoma seen in adults, not children. Typically arises in the cerebral hemispheres, and histology shows necrosis with pseudopalisading cells, not cystic mural nodules or Rosenthal fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign tumor of astrocytes, and the most common CNS tumor in children. 
  • It usually arises in the cerebellum, appears as a cystic lesion with a mural nodule on imaging, and shows Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies, and GFAP positivity on biopsy.

choices.text: Comparing prevalence of diabetes in three different ethnic groups
Evaluating vaccine response (positive/negative) across four hospitals
Comparing height categories in children (short, normal, tall) across genders
Using Chi-square to assess mean blood pressure across treatment groups

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would most likely invalidate the use of the Chi-square test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Using Chi-square to assess mean blood pressure across treatment groups

 

  • Chi-square test is specifically designed to analyze qualitative (categorical) variables. It is used to assess the association between two or more categorical variables or compare proportions between groups.
  • Mean blood pressure is a quantitative (continuous) variable. You cannot use a chi-square test to compare means. Instead, you'd need a t-test (for two groups) or ANOVA (for more than two groups) to compare continuous outcomes across groups.
  • Thus, attempting to use Chi-square in a scenario involving mean blood pressure, a parametric continuous variable, violates the core assumptions of the test and makes its use statistically invalid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Comparing prevalence of diabetes in three different ethnic groups: Valid use of Chi-square. Prevalence (yes/no) is categorical, and ethnic groups are also categorical. The Chi-square test is appropriate for comparing proportions across more than two groups.

 

Option B. Evaluating vaccine response (positive/negative) across four hospitals: Valid. Both variables are categorical (response: positive/negative; hospital: 4 groups). Chi-square is suitable for testing association in such cross-tabulations.

 

Option C. Comparing height categories in children (short, normal, tall) across genders: Valid. Height categories are qualitative (even though height itself is continuous), and gender is binary categorical. The comparison of categorical variables is appropriate for Chi-square.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Chi-square test is valid only for categorical variables. It is used to test associations or compare proportions between groups. 
  • Using it to compare continuous numerical outcomes like mean blood pressure is invalid and requires parametric tests like the t-test or ANOVA.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of right-sided ear pain for the past two weeks. He denies any hearing loss, discharge from the ear, or history of trauma. Otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane and external auditory canal. However, he reports a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tonsillitis

 

  • The patient presents with referred otalgia (ear pain) and throat symptoms. Since there are no positive findings in the ear (normal tympanic membrane and external auditory canal), the ear pain is likely referred. Referred otalgia can occur due to shared nerve supply. 
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), via its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve), supplies both the throat and the middle ear, explaining the referred pain to the ear. 
  • The patient's sore throat and difficulty swallowing suggest tonsillitis, where the inflamed tonsils irritate the glossopharyngeal nerve, leading to referred ear pain.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media presents with ear pain accompanied by otoscopic findings, such as a bulging tympanic membrane, erythema, or fluid behind the eardrum. This patient's ear exam was normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option B. Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder: TMJ disorders can cause referred pain to the ear, but they are typically associated with jaw pain, clicking sounds, or restricted jaw movement, none of which are mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Trigeminal neuralgia: Trigeminal neuralgia typically causes severe, stabbing pain along the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (face, jaw, or forehead). It does not cause sore throat or swallowing difficulties and is not associated with referred otalgia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia in the absence of positive ear findings may result from irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve, as seen in conditions like tonsillitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical findings may be seen on examination of an active agent in sodomy?

 

  1. Abrasions and contusions on the glans penis.
  2. Tearing of the frenulum or prepuce.
  3. Presence of fecal traces or lubricants around genitalia.
  4. Constriction ring at the base of glans in habitual offenders.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

1. Abrasions and contusions on the glans penis: Due to forceful penetration against resistance, the glans may develop friction injuries.

 

2. Tearing of the frenulum or prepuce: Common in forceful anal penetration, especially if no lubricant is used.

 

3. Presence of fecal traces or lubricants around genitalia: Fecal matter or lubricant residues may remain around the penis or groin after the act.

 

4. Constriction ring at the base of the glans in habitual offenders: Chronic cases develop twisting and constriction deformity due to repeated anal sphincter compression during habitual penetration.
 

  • Thus, all four findings may be seen on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sodomy investigations, active agents may show abrasions, frenulum tears, fecal traces, and chronic constriction deformity of the penis due to repeated forceful anal penetration.

 

Specimens to Be Preserved for Passive and Active Agent (in Sodomy Cases)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency department with irritability, poor appetite, and abdominal pain. Physical examination shows pallor, developmental delay, and a bluish pigmentation at the gingival margin (Burton's line). Laboratory evaluation reveals microcytic hypochromic anemia and an elevated blood lead level of 75 µg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dimercaprol (BAL) + Calcium disodium EDTA

 

  • This child has severe lead poisoning. Key clinical clues include:
    • Burton’s line (bluish gum line)
    • Microcytic hypochromic anemia
    • Neurocognitive symptoms (e.g., irritability, cognitive delay)
    • Blood lead level >70 µg/dL, which constitutes severe toxicity
  • In such cases, combined chelation therapy with Dimercaprol (BAL) and CaNa₂EDTA is recommended:
    • Dimercaprol (BAL) is administered intramuscularly and mobilizes lead from tissues.
    • CaNa₂EDTA is given intravenously to chelate and enhance renal excretion of lead.
  • This dual approach is especially necessary in symptomatic children or when lead levels exceed 70 µg/dL, due to the risk of neurologic complications (e.g., encephalopathy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium disodium EDTA (CaNa₂EDTA) alone: This may be used in moderate lead toxicity (45–69 µg/dL) in asymptomatic children. However, in levels >70 µg/dL or symptomatic cases, BAL must be added.

 

Option C. Penicillamine: An oral chelator used for mild to moderate lead poisoning, but it is less effective and not indicated for severe poisoning.

 

Option D. Deferoxamine: A chelating agent specific for iron overload, not used in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with symptomatic lead poisoning or blood lead levels ≥70 µg/dL require immediate chelation therapy with Dimercaprol (BAL) plus Calcium disodium EDTA for effective lead removal and prevention of neurological damage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman experiences profuse vaginal bleeding and hypotension approximately 30 minutes after delivery of a healthy infant. The placenta was expelled intact, but abdominal examination reveals a boggy uterine fundus. Ultrasound confirms the presence of retained placental tissue within the uterine cavity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiata

 

  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a type of morphological abnormality of the placenta in which one or more accessory lobes of placental tissue are present and connected to the main placenta via fetal blood vessels. 
  • These accessory lobes may remain inside the uterus after delivery of the main placenta, resulting in retained placental tissue, which can lead to postpartum hemorrhage, boggy uterus, and hemodynamic instability.
  • In this case, although the main placenta was expelled intact, the ongoing bleeding, hypotension, boggy uterus, and ultrasound evidence of retained tissue strongly suggest that an accessory lobe was retained, making placenta succenturiata the most likely diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circummarginate placenta: This variant is characterized by a flattened transition between the chorionic plate and the placenta without a prominent fold or ridge. It is generally clinically insignificant and not associated with retained placental tissue or postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Placenta membranacea: This is a rare condition in which the placental villi develop over a large area of the membranes, often covering most or all of the gestational sac. Although it can be associated with retained placenta, it would have been noticed during delivery as an abnormally large and thin placenta, not an intact normal placenta as noted in the case.

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta: In this condition, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, leading to rolled or raised edges of the placenta. It is associated with adverse outcomes like preterm labor and abruption, but it does not cause retained placental tissue in the way accessory lobes in placenta succenturiata do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is a placental abnormality with one or more accessory lobes that may be retained after delivery, leading to postpartum hemorrhage and requiring ultrasound confirmation.

questions.text: Match the following GLUT transporters with their primary physiological functions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–4, B–2, C–3, D–1

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Different GLUT transporters facilitate facilitated diffusion of glucose or fructose across membranes with tissue-specific roles. 
  • GLUT 1 and 3 provide basal uptake, GLUT 2 acts as a sensor in liver/pancreas, GLUT 4 is insulin-regulated, and GLUT 5 is specific for fructose.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the Mapleson F circuit are correct? 

 

  1. It is a modification of the Ayre’s T-piece and includes a reservoir bag.
  2. It is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia due to low resistance and minimal dead space.
  3. It is suitable for controlled ventilation but not for spontaneous ventilation.
  4. It does not have an expiratory valve and fresh gas flow rate is 2-3 times the minute ventilation in spontaneous ventilation.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. It is a modification of the Ayre’s T-piece and includes a reservoir bag: True. Mapleson F is a Jackson-Rees modification of the Ayre’s T-piece with the addition of a reservoir bag for positive pressure ventilation.

 

 

Statement 2. It is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia due to low resistance and minimal dead space: True. It is ideal for pediatric patients due to its low resistance and low dead space.

 

Statement 4. It does not have an expiratory valve and fresh gas flow rate is 2-3 times the minute ventilation in spontaneous ventilation: True. It is a valveless circuit and fresh gas flow rate is 2-3 times the minute ventilation in spontaneous ventilation.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. It is suitable for controlled ventilation but not for spontaneous ventilation: False. The Mapleson F circuit can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mapleson F (Jackson-Rees) circuit is a pediatric-friendly breathing system used in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation. 
  • It is important to recognize its structure, uses, and limitations—especially the lack of expiratory valves and implications for gas scavenging.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Enoxaparin does not require regular aPTT monitoring for anticoagulation management.

 

Reason (R): Enoxaparin is an antithrombin activator that has specific antidote as protamine sulphate.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

 

  • Assertion (A) is true: Enoxaparin, a low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), has a predictable pharmacokinetic profile and longer half-life than unfractionated heparin (UFH). It primarily inhibits factor Xa (and to a lesser extent factor IIa) via antithrombin activation, but due to its predictable dose–response relationship, routine aPTT monitoring is not required in most patients.
  • Reason (R) is also true: Enoxaparin works by enhancing antithrombin III activity, inhibiting factor Xa. While protamine sulfate can partially reverse the effects of enoxaparin, it is less effective compared to its action on unfractionated heparin.
  • However, R is not the correct explanation of A: The lack of need for aPTT monitoring is due to the predictable pharmacokinetics and bioavailability of enoxaparin—not merely because it has an antidote or because it activates antithrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enoxaparin is a low-molecular-weight heparin that does not require routine aPTT monitoring due to its predictable dose–response relationship. 
  • It acts by activating antithrombin III, inhibiting factor Xa, and can be partially reversed with protamine sulfate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of persistent foul-smelling vaginal discharge and irregular per vaginal bleeding for 4 months. Pelvic examination reveals a large exophytic cervical mass extending to the lower third of the vagina. MRI shows involvement of adjacent parametrial tissues, and PET-CT reveals metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes without evidence of distant organ metastasis. Both kidneys appear normal on imaging. What is the FIGO 2018 stage of cervical carcinoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage III C2

 

  • According to the FIGO 2018 staging system:
    • Stage III includes disease that has spread to the lower third of the vagina (Stage IIIA), pelvic wall involvement or hydronephrosis (Stage IIIB), or lymph node involvement (Stage IIIC).
    • Stage IIIC1: Pelvic lymph node metastasis (confirmed radiologically or pathologically).
    • Stage IIIC2: Para-aortic lymph node metastasis, regardless of primary tumor size or extent.
  • This patient has para-aortic lymph node involvement without distant metastasis, classifying her as Stage IIIC2.
  • FIGO 2018 Staging of Carcinoma Cervix
  • Stage I – Disease confined to the cervix
  • Stage I A – Microscopic disease only
    • IA1: Stromal invasion ≤ 3 mm in depth
    • IA2: Stromal invasion > 3 mm and ≤ 5 mm in depth
  • Stage I B – Clinically visible lesion or microscopic lesion > IA2
    • IB1: Stromal invasion > 5 mm, tumor size ≤ 2 cm
    • IB2: Tumor size > 2 cm but ≤ 4 cm
    • IB3: Tumor size > 4 cm
  • Stage II – Extension beyond cervix but not to pelvic wall or lower 1/3 of vagina
  • Stage II A – No parametrial invasion
    • IIA1: Tumor ≤ 4 cm
    • IIA2: Tumor > 4 cm
  • Stage II B – Parametrial involvement
    • Tumor invades into the parametrial tissue but not up to the pelvic wall.
  • Stage III – Involvement of lower third of vagina and/or pelvic wall
  • Stage III A
    • Tumor involves lower 1/3 of the vagina only
  • Stage III B
    • Extension to pelvic wall and/or causes hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C – Lymph node involvement
    • IIIC1: Pelvic lymph nodes involved (on imaging or pathology)
    • IIIC2: Para-aortic lymph nodes involved (irrespective of size or extent of tumor)
  • Stage IV – Extension beyond true pelvis or involvement of adjacent/distant organs
  • Stage IV A
    • Tumor invades adjacent pelvic organs (e.g., bladder or rectum)
  • Stage IV B
    • Distant metastasis (e.g., lung, liver, distant lymph nodes)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FIGO Stage IIIC2 cervical cancer indicates involvement of para-aortic lymph nodes, which can be detected through imaging (CT, PET-CT, MRI) or pathology. 
  • It is a key determinant for prognosis and treatment planning, even when pelvic organs or parametria are not grossly involved. 
  • Distinction between pelvic node (IIIC1) and para-aortic node (IIIC2) metastasis is crucial for staging and therapeutic approach.

choices.text: JC virus is responsible for progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
Measles virus causes subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
Prion-related disease leads to spongiform encephalopathy
Cytomegalovirus causes bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised man presents with progressive neurological decline. MRI of the brain reveals white matter changes, and CSF PCR detects a polyomavirus. In reviewing CNS infections, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytomegalovirus causes bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction

 

  • This question tests your knowledge of distinct neuropathological patterns caused by specific infectious agents:
    • JC virus: Causes Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS). It leads to demyelination without inflammation.
    • Measles virus: In rare cases, especially in children infected at a young age, can lead to Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), a progressive, fatal degenerative CNS disease years after initial infection.
    • Prions: Cause spongiform encephalopathies like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, characterized by neuronal vacuolization, astrocytosis, and absence of inflammation.
  • The false statement is "Cytomegalovirus causes bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction"
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) does not cause bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction. That pattern is classically seen in Herpes Simplex Virus type 1 (HSV-1) encephalitis. 
    • CMV tends to affect periventricular areas, especially in neonates and immunocompromised adults, causing periventricular calcification but does not cause hemorrhagic infarction of the temporal lobes.
    • Bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction is caused by herpes simplex virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. JC virus is responsible for progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy: True. JC virus infects oligodendrocytes, causing multifocal demyelination and neurological deterioration.

 

Option B. Measles virus causes subacute sclerosing panencephalitis: True. SSPE is a late complication of measles, caused by persistent defective measles virus in the CNS.

 

Option C. Prion-related disease leads to spongiform encephalopathy: True. Prions (misfolded proteins) result in vacuolar degeneration of the brain (i.e., spongiform changes) and are fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction is characteristic of HSV-1 encephalitis, not CMV infection. CMV primarily affects periventricular regions, especially in neonates.

questions.text:
Match the following clinical findings with their diagnosis. 

 

Clinical findings:

  1. Delayed passage of Meconium 
  2. Red currant Jelly Stools 
  3. Peri anal rash with acidic stools 
  4. Metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria 

 

Diagnosis:

  1. Intussusception
  2. Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  3. Hirschsprungs disease
  4. Lactose intolerance
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2
 

  • Let’s match each clinical finding to its corresponding diagnosis:

 

A-3. Delayed passage of meconium → Hirschsprung’s disease: 

 

  • Hirschsprung’s disease is a congenital condition characterized by absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon. 
  • This leads to functional obstruction and delayed passage of meconium, typically beyond 48 hours after birth.

 

B-1. Red currant jelly stools → Intussusception: 

 

  • Intussusception is a medical emergency in infants where a segment of the intestine telescopes into another, leading to ischemia. Classic presentation includes:
    • Intermittent colicky abdominal pain
    • Vomiting
    • “Red currant jelly” stools due to blood and mucus in the stool

 

C-4. Perianal rash with acidic stools → Lactose intolerance:

 

  • In lactose intolerance, undigested lactose is fermented in the colon, leading to:
    • Acidic stools
    • Frequent diarrhea
    • Resulting in perianal excoriation or rash due to stool acidity

 

D-2. Metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria → Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

 

  • Pyloric stenosis leads to persistent non-bilious projectile vomiting in infants. This causes:
    • Loss of hydrochloric acid → metabolic alkalosis
    • Due to volume depletion and aldosterone activity, the kidneys reabsorb sodium by exchanging potassium and hydrogen → resulting in paradoxical aciduria

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed meconium suggests Hirschsprung’s, red currant jelly stools point to intussusception, acidic stool rash indicates lactose intolerance, and metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria is classic for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

choices.text: The dorsal horn of the right side of the spinal cord
The dorsal horn of the left side of the spinal cord

questions.text: For a sensory nerve fiber that is connected to a Pacinian corpuscle located on the palmar surface of the right hand, the first synapse in the corresponding sensory pathway occurs at which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right dorsal column nucleus

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles are mechanoreceptors responsible for detecting vibration and pressure.
  • These are classified as part of the dorsal column–medial lemniscus (DCML) pathway, which conveys fine touch, vibration, and proprioception.
  • Pathway of the DCML system:
    • First-order neuron: Begins at the receptor (Pacinian corpuscle), travels via large myelinated Aβ fibers, enters the dorsal root ganglion, and ascends ipsilaterally in the fasciculus cuneatus (for upper limb).
    • It does NOT synapse in the spinal cord (eliminating options C and D).
    • It ascends and synapses in the dorsal column nuclei—in this case, the right nucleus cuneatus in the medulla oblongata, because the sensation is from the right hand.
    • Second-order neurons decussate in the medulla (internal arcuate fibers) and ascend in the medial lemniscus to the contralateral thalamus (VPL).
    • Third-order neurons project from the thalamus to the primary somatosensory cortex.

 

 

  • Thus, the first synapse occurs in the right dorsal column nucleus (nucleus cuneatus).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway conveys fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the body. 
  • For upper limb sensations like those from Pacinian corpuscles in the right hand, the first synapse occurs in the ipsilateral dorsal column nuclei (nucleus cuneatus) in the medulla, not the spinal cord.

choices.text: Hepatocyte necrosis due to iron overload and hemosiderin deposition
Acetaldehyde-induced injury with formation of Mallory bodies and inflammation
Cholesterol crystal deposition triggering granulomatous inflammation

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with right upper quadrant pain and fatigue. He reports frequent episodes of binge drinking, especially on weekends. Physical examination reveals tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show:

  • AST: 248 U/L
  • ALT: 104 U/L
  • Total bilirubin: Mildly elevated
  • Alkaline phosphatase: Slightly elevated

Ultrasound shows a heavy, greasy liver. Findings from the Liver biopsy is given in the image below. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of liver injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetaldehyde-induced injury with formation of Mallory bodies and inflammation

 

  • This patient has alcoholic hepatitis, a component of alcohol-related liver disease, which is the most common cause of liver disease.
  • There are three key stages:
    • Fatty liver: Reversible accumulation of fat in hepatocytes leading to a heavy, greasy liver (resolves with abstinence).
    • Alcoholic hepatitis: Occurs after chemical injury, usually due to binge drinking.
    • Acetaldehyde, a toxic metabolite of alcohol, mediates hepatocyte injury.
  • Histologically characterized by:
    • Hepatocyte swelling
    • Mallory bodies (damaged cytokeratin filaments)
    • Necrosis and acute inflammation
  • Clinically presents with painful hepatomegaly, elevated AST > ALT, and may be fatal.
  • Cirrhosis (not mentioned in the source but typically follows chronic injury).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A Hepatocyte necrosis due to iron overload and hemosiderin deposition: Describes hemochromatosis, not alcohol-induced damage.

 

Option B. Autoimmune-mediated destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts: Seen in primary biliary cholangitis, not alcohol-related liver disease.

 

Option D. Cholesterol crystal deposition triggering granulomatous inflammation: Occur in xanthogranulomatous inflammation, not relevant to alcohol.
 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alcoholic hepatitis occurs due to acetaldehyde-mediated injury to hepatocytes, leading to Mallory body formation, necrosis, and inflammation.
  • It typically follows binge drinking, presents with painful hepatomegaly and AST > ALT, and is a component of alcohol-related liver disease.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with right calf pain that occurs during walking and is relieved by rest. He denies swelling, redness, or trauma to the leg. On examination, there are diminished right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, and the skin appears cool but intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial Doppler

 

  • The most appropriate first investigation in a patient presenting with intermittent claudication—a hallmark of peripheral arterial disease (PAD)—is an arterial Doppler ultrasound, often combined with an ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement.
  • Arterial Doppler is non-invasive, inexpensive, and effective for:
    • Detecting blood flow reduction
    • Calculating ABI to quantify the severity of PAD
    • Localizing vascular insufficiency (proximal vs. distal)
  • An ABI < 0.90 confirms PAD and helps in staging and guiding further imaging or intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digital subtraction angiogram (DSA): Incorrect. While DSA is the gold standard for vascular imaging, it is invasive and used for definitive preoperative planning or when intervention is planned. It is not used as the initial investigation due to cost and invasiveness.

 

Option B. Venous Doppler: Incorrect. Venous Doppler is used for evaluating venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis, neither of which is consistent with intermittent claudication, which is a symptom of arterial insufficiency.

 

Option D. CT angiogram: Incorrect. CT angiography is excellent for vascular mapping, especially when surgical or endovascular therapy is being considered. However, it requires contrast and radiation and is not the first-line investigation. It is used after Doppler confirms arterial disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial Doppler with ankle-brachial index is the first-line investigation for suspected peripheral arterial disease presenting with intermittent claudication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb for the past five years. Examination shows non-pitting edema. The skin over the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic lymphedema

 

  • Chronic lymphedema presents with progressive, non-pitting swelling of the limb due to impaired lymphatic drainage.
  • Key clinical features: 
    • Buffalo hump appearance on the dorsum of the foot.
    • Loss of the normal contour of the ankle due to submalleolar filling.
    • Square toes due to fibrotic thickening.
    • Stemmer’s sign positive (inability to pinch the skin over the dorsum of the toes due to fibrosis).
  • Etiology: Can be primary (congenital/hereditary) or secondary (filariasis, malignancy, trauma, post-surgical/radiation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Venous Insufficiency (CVI):

 

  • Edema worsens throughout the day and improves with leg elevation.
  • Brawny discoloration, lipodermatosclerosis, and venous ulcers (medial malleolus).
  • Edema spares the dorsum of the foot, unlike in lymphedema.
  • Stemmer’s sign is not present. We see dilated veins

 

Option B. Lipedema:

 

  • Lipedema is seen in obesity
  • Symmetrical fat deposition in the lower limbs sparing the feet.
  • Painful, non-pitting swelling but without Stemmer’s sign.
  • No buffalo hump appearance or fibrosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis:

 

  • Cellulitis will show inflammation
  • Acute painful swelling, erythema, warmth, and fever due to infection.
  • Unilateral, with tenderness and systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic lymphedema presents with progressive, non-pitting edema, buffalo hump deformity of the foot, square toes, and a positive Stemmer’s sign due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the emergency department with signs of neonatal sepsis. Blood cultures yield a Gram-positive cocci forming β-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The organism is resistant to bacitracin and demonstrates a positive CAMP test. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • The organism described in this neonatal sepsis case is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus or GBS). Key distinguishing features include:
    • β-hemolysis on blood agar
    • Resistance to bacitracin (unlike S. pyogenes, which is sensitive)
    • Positive CAMP test, which enhances hemolysis when grown adjacent to Staphylococcus aureus
    • A common cause of neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis
  • These features together point definitively toward S. agalactiae, particularly in the context of infant sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes: Also shows β-hemolysis, but it is bacitracin-sensitive and CAMP test negative. It causes pharyngitis, impetigo, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever, but is not the primary cause of neonatal sepsis.

 

Option B. Enterococcus faecalis: This organism is non-hemolytic or weakly α-hemolytic, bacitracin-resistant, but CAMP test negative. It can cause nosocomial infections, but not β-hemolysis as seen in this case.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Shows α-hemolysis, is optochin-sensitive, and CAMP negative. Though a cause of pneumonia and meningitis, it does not match the β-hemolytic and CAMP-positive profile seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and is identified by β-hemolysis, bacitracin resistance, and a positive CAMP test.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes a radical mastectomy with extensive axillary dissection. Postoperatively, she presents with difficulty pushing against a wall and is noted to have scapular winging on physical examination. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  • Nerve marked as A is the lateral pectoral nerve, which innervates the pectoralis major.
  • Nerve marked as B is the suprascapular nerve, which innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus.
  • Nerve marked as D is the thoracodorsal nerve, which innervates latissimus dorsi.
  • The long thoracic nerve (marked as C) arises from the C5, C6, and C7 spinal nerves and innervates the serratus anterior.
  • The serratus anterior muscle plays a crucial role in scapular stabilization by holding the scapula against the thoracic wall and assisting in scapular protraction.
  • Damage to the long thoracic nerve during axillary dissection results in winging of the scapula, particularly when the patient pushes against resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pectoral nerve: Incorrect. The lateral pectoral nerve innervates the pectoralis major muscle, which is involved in shoulder flexion and adduction, not scapular stabilization.

 

Option B. Suprascapular nerve: Incorrect. This nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which contribute to shoulder abduction and external rotation. It is not involved in scapular protraction or stabilization.

 

Option D. Thoracodorsal nerve: Incorrect. The thoracodorsal nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, which assists in shoulder extension, adduction, and internal rotation but does not stabilize the scapula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which stabilizes the scapula against the thoracic wall. 
  • Injury to this nerve during procedures such as axillary dissection can result in scapular winging, a characteristic clinical finding.

questions.text: A 2.5 kg baby born through LSCS cried immediately after birth. On the routine visit pediatrician noticed that baby has macroglossia with hemihypertrophy of limbs. What is your best possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome

 

  • The image shows an infant with macroglossia (enlarged tongue). Along with the clinical finding of hemihypertrophy (asymmetrical limb overgrowth), this is strongly suggestive of Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome (BWS).
  • Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is a congenital overgrowth disorder involving abnormalities on chromosome 11p15, affecting imprinted genes such as IGF2.
  • Key Features of BWS:
    • Macroglossia
    • Hemihypertrophy
    • Omphalocele or umbilical hernia
    • Neonatal hypoglycemia
    • Macrosomia (increased birth weight)
    • Increased risk of embryonal tumors (e.g., Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infant of diabetic mother: Incorrect. These babies may be macrosomic, and present with neonatal hypoglycemia, but macroglossia and hemihypertrophy are not typical features. These findings are more specific to BWS.

 

Option C. Prader-Willi syndrome: Incorrect. Presents with hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood. Macroglossia and hemihypertrophy are not features of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option D. Angelman syndrome: Incorrect. Associated with developmental delay, seizures, ataxia, and frequent laughter/smiling. This syndrome also does not include macroglossia or hemihypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome presents with macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and neonatal hypoglycemia, and carries a risk of embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor.

questions.text: Match the following codons with the correct amino acid they code for or their function in this specialized context:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

1-B. UGA → Selenocysteine:

  • Normally: A stop codon.
  • Special context: With a specific SECIS element (Selenocysteine Insertion Sequence), UGA is redefined to insert selenocysteine.

 

2-A. UAG → Pyrrolysine:

  • Normally: A stop codon.
  • Special context: In certain bacteria, UAG can code for pyrrolysine, the 22nd amino acid.

 

3-D. AUG → Methionine:

  • Always: The standard start codon and codes for methionine.

 

4-C. UCA → Serine:

  • Always: Codes for serine under the standard genetic code.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the standard genetic code and recognize exceptions like:
    • UGA coding for selenocysteine in the presence of SECIS.
    • UAG coding for pyrrolysine in some organisms.
    • AUG as the universal start codon for methionine.
    • UCA coding for serine in standard contexts.

 

3 stop codon – UGA, UAG and UAA

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with knee pain after a football injury. He reports that he was tackled and twisted his knee while it was planted on the ground. On physical examination, there is significant swelling around the knee joint, along with instability when performing the Lachman test. The patient also experiences pain and restricted motion when attempting to extend the knee. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) O’Donoghue triad

 

  • The O'Donoghue triad typically includes injury to:
    • Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)
    • Medial collateral ligament (MCL)
    • Medial meniscus (originally described); some sources now note the lateral meniscus can also be involved
  • Caused by a valgus force + rotational injury, often when the knee is planted and twisted, like during a football tackle.
  • Findings:
    • Instability (ACL involvement → Lachman positive)
    • Medial joint line tenderness (MCL/meniscus)
    • Swelling (from ACL tear and hemarthrosis)
    • Pain with extension (possible meniscal tear)

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury:

 

  • MCL injuries occur with valgus stress to the knee, but usually in isolation, they:
    • Cause medial knee pain
    • Do not cause significant swelling
    • Do not result in instability on the Lachman test (since that evaluates the ACL)
  • This patient has more than an isolated MCL injury (Lachman positive + joint instability).

 

Option C. Patellar dislocation:

 

  • Typically occurs in young athletes with a direct blow or twisting.
  • Classic signs:
    • Lateral displacement of the patella
    • Inability to extend the knee
    • Possible visible deformity
  • After spontaneous reduction, there may be tenderness on the medial patella and swelling.
  • However, it does not cause a positive Lachman test, and instability would be patellofemoral, not ligamentous.

 

Option D. Quadriceps tendon rupture:

 

  • Usually occurs in older adults, or in patients with chronic tendon disease.
  • Presents with:
    • Sudden pain above the patella
    • Inability to actively extend the knee
    • Palpable gap above the patella
  • Rare in a healthy 22-year-old and would not cause a positive Lachman test or joint instability.

 

Educational objective:

 

The mechanism (twisting injury with planted foot), positive Lachman test, swelling, and functional impairment suggest a multi-structure injury — classically the O'Donoghue (unhappy) triad involving the ACL, MCL, and meniscus.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: A woman in her third pregnancy is in the second stage of labor, which has lasted for two hours. She has adequate uterine contractions, and on examination, the cervix is fully dilated. The fetal head is at station 0, with 2+ molding and 2+ caput succedaneum noted. The sagittal suture lies in the right occipito-transverse position, and the fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • This clinical scenario describes a prolonged second stage of labor in a multigravida woman (G≥2) lasting more than 2 hours, with adequate contractions, full cervical dilation, and fetal head at station 0. 
  • The presence of 2+ molding and 2+ caput indicates that descent is not progressing, and there is already some degree of cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD). 
  • Additionally, the sagittal suture in the right occipito-transverse position suggests that the fetal head has not rotated anteriorly, a key step required for vaginal delivery.
  • This is classical presentation Deep transverse arrest. If DTA is there with signs of obstruction then we will do caesarean section.
  • These findings collectively suggest obstructed labor at the mid-pelvis, with the fetal head failing to descend beyond station 0 despite adequate contractions. 
  • In such cases, the safest and definitive management is lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). 
  • This prevents prolonged labor, reduces fetal risk from pressure and hypoxia, and avoids trauma from a failed instrumental delivery attempt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum delivery is not appropriate in this scenario. It is contraindicated in the presence of caput and molding, which suggest malposition or CPD. Applying vacuum at this high station carries a high risk of failure and trauma to the fetus and maternal tissues.

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Expectant management is not advised here. The patient has already been in the second stage for 2 hours, which is the upper limit for a multigravida with adequate contractions. Further delay may lead to fetal and maternal complications, particularly with ongoing molding and caput, which are signs of obstructed descent.

 

Option D. Mid pelvic forceps: Forceps delivery at the mid pelvis (station 0) is contraindicated without proper rotational alignment. The occipito-transverse position means that the head has not completed internal rotation, and attempting forceps in this malposition can cause trauma and failure. Furthermore, molding and caput suggest resistance to descent, making instrumental delivery unsafe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with prolonged second-stage labor, station 0, moulding and caput, and failure of fetal head rotation, the appropriate management is lower segment cesarean section.

choices.text: Raised intracranial pressure is still an absolute contraindication to ECT
There are no absolute contraindications to ECT in current clinical practice
Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication to ECT
ECT should be avoided in all cases of cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with severe suicidal depression is being considered for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). The resident is concerned due to her history of raised intracranial pressure (ICP), previously considered an absolute contraindication. Which of the following statements best reflects the current understanding regarding contraindications to ECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There are no absolute contraindications to ECT in current clinical practice

 

  • According to modern clinical guidelines, there are no absolute contraindications to ECT. 
  • Even conditions previously considered absolute contraindications — such as raised intracranial pressure or pregnancy — are now considered relative risks and are managed with appropriate precautions. 
  • In life-threatening psychiatric conditions, such as severe suicidal depression, ECT may be lifesaving and still appropriate with proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Raised intracranial pressure is still an absolute contraindication to ECT: Incorrect. It is a relative contraindication, not absolute, and may be treated with special precautions like corticosteroids or mannitol if necessary.

 

Option C. Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication to ECT: Incorrect. ECT is safe in pregnancy, especially in severe cases, with obstetric consultation and fetal monitoring.

 

Option D. ECT should be avoided in all cases of cardiovascular disease: Incorrect. ECT can be used with cardiology clearance; monitoring and management of BP and arrhythmias is routine during ECT.

 

Educational Objective:


There is no absolute contraindication for ECT.

questions.text: What is the most likely indication for the use of this cream?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scabies

 

  • The cream shown in the image is Permethrin 5%, which is a first-line topical treatment for scabies, a parasitic infestation caused by Sarcoptes scabiei. 
  • It presents with intense nocturnal pruritus, especially in web spaces, flexural areas, and the trunk. Close contacts are usually affected due to its contagious nature.
  • Permethrin acts by disrupting sodium channels in the scabies mite, causing paralysis and death.

 

Note: 

  • The oral treatment given in scabies is Ivermectin. 
  • Permethrin 1% is used in the treatment of lice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, often on the extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, scalp).
  • Permethrin has no role in psoriasis treatment.
  • Treatments include topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs (e.g., calcipotriol), phototherapy, or systemic agents like methotrexate or biologics in severe cases.

 

Option B. Contact Dermatitis:

 

  • This is a hypersensitivity reaction caused by direct contact with irritants or allergens (e.g., nickel, cosmetics, latex).
  • Presents as itchy, red, vesicular or lichenified lesions in the area of exposure.
  • Treated with avoidance of the trigger, topical corticosteroids, and oral antihistamines for symptom relief.
  • Permethrin is not used in this condition.

 

Option C. Tinea corporis (Ringworm):

 

  • This is a superficial dermatophyte fungal infection of the body caused by Trichophyton species, presenting as annular, scaly, red plaques with central clearing.
  • Treated with topical antifungals (e.g., clotrimazole, terbinafine) for localized infections.
  • In extensive or recurrent cases, oral antifungals may be used.
  • Permethrin is ineffective against fungal infections like tinea.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Permethrin 5% cream is the treatment of choice for scabies and should be applied overnight to the entire body from the neck down and repeated after one week. 
  • Close contacts must also be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfestation.

choices.text: Urea breath test exposes to low-dose radiation
Stool antigen is best for cure confirmation
Serology is preferred for confirming eradication
NSAIDs cause false-negative urea breath test results

questions.text: A 60-year-old man reports epigastric pain relieved by meals. His doctor suspects H. pylori and plans noninvasive testing. Which of the following statement is correct regarding H. pylori diagnostics in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urea breath test exposes to low-dose radiation

 

  • The urea breath test uses C-14 (radioactive) or C-13 (non-radioactive). 
  • While accurate, the C-14 version exposes patients to a minimal radiation dose. 

  • NSAIDs do not affect results—PPIs and antibiotics do.

     

Other Options:
 

Option B. Stool antigen is best for cure confirmation: Useful for diagnosis but less accurate post-treatment.
 

Option C. Serology is preferred for confirming eradication: Remains positive after eradication, so not used.
 

Option D. NSAIDs cause false-negative urea breath test results: Do not interfere with breath testing. PPI and sucralfate causes false negative urea breath test. 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Urea breath test is highly sensitive and specific for H. pylori detection; radiation exposure occurs only with C-14 isotope.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man visits a pharmacy in India to purchase a medication for hypertension. The pharmacist informs him that the drug is a prescription-only medication and cannot be dispensed without a valid doctor’s prescription. Under which of the following drug schedules is this medication most likely classified as per Indian drug regulations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schedule H

 

  • In India, Schedule H drugs are medications that can only be sold by retail with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. This category includes most prescription-only medications, such as antibiotics, antihypertensives, antidiabetics, and many others used in clinical practice.
  • They are not meant for over-the-counter sale, and improper dispensing is legally prohibited.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schedule G: Schedule G drugs must be taken under medical supervision, and the label bears a warning to that effect. However, not all Schedule G drugs are strictly prescription-only.

 

Option B. Schedule X: Schedule X includes narcotic and psychotropic substances (e.g., barbiturates, benzodiazepines) with high abuse potential. These require duplicate prescriptions and strict record-keeping.

 

Option D. Schedule Y: Schedule Y pertains to clinical trial regulations in India, including rules for import, manufacture, and approval of new drugs, not the categorization of prescription medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, Schedule H drugs are classified as prescription-only medications and can be dispensed only with a valid medical prescription.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

Column A (Mallampati Class)

  1. Class I
  2. Class II
  3. Class III
  4. Class IV

 

Column B (Visible Structures)

  1. Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible
  2. Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible
  3. Soft palate, hard palate visible
  4. Soft palate not visible
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–1, B–2, C–3, D–4

 

A-1. Class I → Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible: Complete visualization of soft palate, fauces, and uvula.

 

B-2. Class II → Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible: Soft palate and fauces are visible, but the tip of the uvula is not.

 

C-3. Class III → Soft palate, hard palate visible: Only the base of the uvula is visible.

 

D-4. Class IV → Soft palate not visible: Only the hard palate is visible; soft palate is not visible at all.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class I: Complete visualization of soft palate, fauces, and uvula.
  • Class II: Soft palate and fauces are visible, but the tip of the uvula is not.
  • Class III: Only the base of the uvula is visible.
  • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible; soft palate is not visible at all.

questions.text: In a Nutritional Rehabilitation Center (NRC), a child previously admitted with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is now clinically alert, free from major complications, and ready to begin energy-dense feeding. At which intervention phase is the child currently placed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transition Phase

 

  • The management of SAM in NRCs follows phased care:
    • Stabilization Phase: Initial phase (1-2 days) when the child is critically ill. Focus is on managing infections, hypoglycemia, hypothermia, and electrolyte imbalance. Starter diet like F-75 therapeutic feed (low protein and low energy) is used because the child cannot tolerate high calories yet.
    • Transition Phase: Starts when the child is clinically stable, alert, and without major complications (2-3 days). The focus shifts to nutritional recovery. This is when energy-dense feeds (catch-up diet) like F-100 or energy-dense local foods are introduced to support catch-up growth.
    • Discharge Phase: Occurs once the child gains sufficient weight (usually >15% weight gain or MUAC >12.5 cm), and appetite and activity are normalized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stabilization Phase: Not correct because energy-dense feeds are avoided initially to prevent refeeding syndrome and complications.

 

Option B. Emergency Care Phase: Not a formal NRC-defined phase; refers more generally to acute management.

 

Option D. Discharge Phase: This follows the transition phase and is not when energy-dense feeding is first introduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transition phase in SAM management is the point where the child is stable and begins high-calorie nutritional rehabilitation, a key step before discharge.

questions.text:
In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces? 

 

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves and vessels
  4. Deep fascia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

  • The roof of intermuscular spaces (e.g., cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box) is made up of several anatomical layers:
    1. Skin: The outermost protective covering of the body and hence the first component of the roof.
    2. Superficial fascia: Lies directly underneath the skin and houses subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves, and blood vessels.
    3. Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves, and vessels: These components lie within the superficial fascia, providing cushioning, insulation, innervation, and vascular supply.
    4. Deep fascia: A dense fibrous connective tissue layer located beneath the superficial fascia, covering and supporting the muscles. It completes the roof structure by adding rigidity and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The roof of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, subcutaneous fat with cutaneous nerves and vessels, and deep fascia. 
  • All these layers are important during surgical dissection and anatomical orientation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of restlessness at night and intense itching around the anal area, especially during the night. The parents report seeing the child scratching the perianal region frequently, and he appears irritable with disturbed sleep. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enterobius vermicularis

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis (also known as the pinworm) is the most common helminthic infection in children in developed and developing countries. 
  • The hallmark feature is Intense perianal pruritus, especially at night, caused by female worms migrating to the perianal area, and laying eggs on the perianal skin
  • This leads to itching, sleep disturbances, and autoinoculation due to scratching.
  • Diagnosis is made by the "scotch tape test" (perianal cellulose tape swab demonstrating ova).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichiura (whipworm): Causes trichuriasis, often asymptomatic or with mild abdominal pain; does not cause perianal pruritus. May cause rectal prolapse in heavy infections.

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm): Causes iron-deficiency anemia due to blood loss from intestinal mucosa. No perianal itching is associated.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Typically causes intestinal obstruction or pulmonary symptoms during larval migration (Löffler's syndrome). No perianal itching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes intense perianal pruritus, especially at night, due to deposition of eggs around the anus, and is diagnosed using the scotch tape test.

questions.text: A 9-week pregnant woman presents with a request for pregnancy termination. On evaluation, she is found to be hemodynamically stable with no contraindications to available medical or surgical options. A first-trimester medical termination is planned. Which of the following is not an appropriate method for terminating pregnancy during the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used in the first trimester for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). 
  • This technique involves introducing ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space, typically via a Foley catheter, to stimulate uterine contractions. 
  • However, this method is specifically designed for second-trimester termination due to its slower onset of action and reduced efficacy in early gestation. 
  • It is neither effective nor recommended for pregnancies under 12 weeks.
  • In the first trimester, the preferred and evidence-supported methods include medical abortion (e.g., mifepristone and misoprostol) and surgical techniques (e.g., manual vacuum aspiration and dilatation and curettage). Ethacridine lactate does not provide the rapid, predictable effect needed in the first trimester and carries a higher risk of complications when used too early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Manual vacuum aspiration: A recognized and commonly used method for terminating a first-trimester pregnancy. MVA is minimally invasive, effective, and can be performed under local anesthesia. It uses a handheld syringe to apply suction for removing uterine contents.

 

Option B. Dilatation and curettage: A surgical procedure involving cervical dilation followed by uterine evacuation using a curette. It is indicated in the first trimester, especially when vacuum aspiration is not feasible or when pathological examination of the tissue is necessary.

 

Option C. Mifepristone followed by misoprostol: The standard and most effective medical regimen for first-trimester abortion. Mifepristone blocks progesterone receptors, leading to endometrial breakdown, and misoprostol induces uterine contractions. This combination is safe and effective for pregnancies up to 10 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is inappropriate for first-trimester pregnancy termination and is used for second-trimester MTP due to its delayed onset of action.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She did not sustain any serious physical injuries, but she appears drowsy and states that she is feeling very sleepy. Emergency medical staff collected several open medication bottles from the floor of her automobile. Although the contents of two of the bottles could not be determined, the patient's recently filled bottle of diazepam was almost empty. The patient quickly becomes unresponsive and stops breathing. Administration of which of the following agents will reverse these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flumazenil

 

  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines. 
  • It competitively inhibits the action at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, thereby reversing the sedative, hypnotic, and respiratory depressant effects of benzodiazepines. 
  • It is the appropriate choice for reversing the symptoms caused by a benzodiazepine overdose such as that suggested by the nearly empty diazepam bottle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon is primarily used to treat severe hypoglycemia in diabetes patients. It can also increase heart rate and force of contraction and is sometimes used in β-blocker overdose. However, it has no role in reversing benzodiazepine-induced sedation or respiratory depression.

 

Option C. Midazolam: Midazolam is another benzodiazepine, used for sedation, anxiolysis, and anesthesia induction. Administering midazolam to a patient with a suspected benzodiazepine overdose would exacerbate the sedation and respiratory depression, not reverse it.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose symptoms, including respiratory depression caused by opioids. While naloxone is effective in reversing opioid effects, it would not be effective in reversing the effects of a benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flumazenil is the appropriate reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • Flumazenil works by competitively inhibiting benzodiazepines at their binding site on the GABA-A receptor, which can reverse the central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepines, including sedation and respiratory depression. 
  • It is crucial to choose the specific antidote based on the type of drug overdose to effectively reverse the symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was found unresponsive at the scene with no signs of external bleeding. On arrival, he is in extremis, and resuscitative efforts are initiated. Despite immediate intervention, he succumbs to his injuries within minutes. Based on trauma-related causes of early mortality, which of the following injuries is most likely to result in the most rapid death if not promptly addressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Airway injury

 

  • Airway injury is the correct answer because it is the most rapidly fatal condition following trauma if not immediately recognized and managed. A complete or near-complete airway obstruction can result in death within minutes due to hypoxia. 
  • Common causes include laryngeal fracture, tracheobronchial tear, or soft tissue swelling, all of which compromise oxygen delivery. Airway patency must be assessed and secured as the first priority in trauma care (as per ABCs of resuscitation).
  • Failure to maintain an open airway leads to rapid hypoxia, loss of consciousness, bradycardia, and cardiac arrest, often within 3–5 minutes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural hematoma (EDH): Incorrect. While an epidural hematoma can be life-threatening, it usually presents with a lucid interval before rapid deterioration due to arterial bleeding (commonly middle meningeal artery). Death can occur over hours, not immediately, making it slower than airway obstruction.

 

Option C. Tension pneumothorax: Incorrect. A tension pneumothorax can lead to rapid hemodynamic collapse due to compression of the vena cava and heart, impairing venous return. However, this progression typically occurs over several minutes, and immediate needle decompression can be lifesaving. It is slightly slower than airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Cardiac tamponade: Incorrect. Cardiac tamponade, especially post-blunt trauma, leads to restricted ventricular filling due to accumulation of pericardial blood. It causes hypotension and pulseless electrical activity, but deterioration occurs over minutes to tens of minutes, slower than with airway compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Airway injury is the most rapidly fatal traumatic injury, as complete airway obstruction can lead to death within minutes unless prompt airway management is performed.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive painless proptosis of the right eye for the past 3 months. He also complains of occasional double vision and a sense of pressure in the orbit. There is no history of trauma. On examination, there is non-tender fullness in the superonasal quadrant of the orbit with downward and lateral displacement of the globe. An axial CT image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethmoidal mucocele

 

  • Ethmoidal mucoceles are expansile lesions resulting from the chronic obstruction of the ethmoidal sinus ostia, leading to accumulation of mucus. Over time, the lesion can erode the lamina papyracea and cause medial orbital displacement or proptosis. 
  • They may develop spontaneously or after sinus surgeries. Non-tender, progressive proptosis with imaging showing sinus expansion supports this diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orbital cavernous hemangioma: Usually presents in middle-aged women with painless, slow-growing axial proptosis. CT shows a well-circumscribed, homogenous intraconal mass.


Option C. Optic nerve glioma: Seen in children, associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Causes progressive visual loss, not primarily proptosis.


Option D. Tolosa-Hunt syndrome: Painful ophthalmoplegia due to idiopathic granulomatous inflammation in the cavernous sinus; pain is a prominent feature.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Ethmoidal mucocele commonly presents with non-axial proptosis, diplopia, and a history of chronic sinus pathology. 
  • CT typically shows an expansile, homogenous lesion causing orbital displacement.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating a potential link between a newly discovered chemical contaminant in groundwater and the occurrence of congenital anomalies in a rural population. To establish a relationship, particularly focusing on the temporality aspect of Hill’s criteria, which of the following study designs would be the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Concurrent cohort study

 

  • Temporality is the most critical of Hill’s criteria for establishing causation—it requires that the exposure clearly precedes the disease or outcome. Among all epidemiologic study designs, a concurrent (prospective) cohort study is best suited to fulfil this criterion because it starts by identifying exposed and non-exposed individuals before the disease has occurred.
  • These individuals are then followed over time to observe the development of the outcome.
  • This allows the researcher to directly observe the temporal relationship between exposure and outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-sectional study: Measures exposure and disease at the same time, offering a "snapshot" of the population. Cannot establish temporality or direction of causation.

 

Option B. Case-control study: Begins with the outcome and looks backward for exposure. Temporality may be inferred, but not definitively proven, especially due to recall or selection bias.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Uses group-level data rather than individual-level, which may lead to ecological fallacy. Temporality cannot be confirmed, and causation is poorly supported.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporality is the most essential Hill’s criterion for causality. It is best established through prospective cohort studies, where the exposure is observed before the outcome occurs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being assessed due to a history of multiple consecutive pregnancy losses. A recent pelvic ultrasound raises suspicion of a Müllerian anomaly. She is otherwise healthy with regular menstrual cycles and no prior history of pelvic surgery. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy + Laparoscopy

 

  • Recurrent pregnancy loss, particularly successive miscarriages, should prompt evaluation for Müllerian anomalies, as these are structural abnormalities of the female reproductive tract that can compromise uterine function. 
  • While initial suspicion often arises from imaging studies like ultrasound, definitive diagnosis and classification require more detailed assessment.
  • The combination of hysteroscopy and laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for evaluating Müllerian anomalies. 
  • This dual approach allows for direct visualization of both the uterine cavity (hysteroscopy) and the external uterine contour and adnexal structures (laparoscopy). 
  • This is especially critical for differentiating between anomalies such as septate and bicornuate uteri, which can appear similar on other imaging but have different treatments and implications for fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopy: While laparoscopy provides valuable information about the external contour of the uterus and associated pelvic structures, it cannot visualize the endometrial cavity. Therefore, it is inadequate alone to confirm a Müllerian anomaly.

 

Option B. Transvaginal sonography: Transvaginal ultrasound is a first-line screening tool for uterine anomalies. However, it lacks the specificity and spatial detail needed to accurately classify complex anomalies, and its diagnostic value is operator dependent. It cannot reliably distinguish between types of anomalies such as bicornuate vs. septate uterus.

 

Option D. Hysterosalpingography: HSG offers information about the shape of the endometrial cavity and tubal patency, but it provides limited or no insight into the external uterine contour. Thus, it may miss or misclassify anomalies, especially in distinguishing between septate and bicornuate uteri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of hysteroscopy and laparoscopy is the gold standard for confirming Müllerian anomalies, particularly in patients with recurrent pregnancy loss.

questions.text:
Match the Following: 

 

Column A – Diagnostic Test

 

  1. Casoni’s test
  2. Schick test
  3. Patch test
  4. Dick’s test

 

Column B – Disease Detected

 

  1. Streptococcal infection
  2. Hydatid disease
  3. Diphtheria susceptibility
  4. Filariasis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–3, C–4, D–1

 

A-2. Casoni’s test → Hydatid disease: This is an intradermal hypersensitivity test using hydatid fluid, formerly used for Echinococcus infection (hydatid disease).

 

B-3. Schick test → Diphtheria susceptibility: An intradermal test to determine susceptibility to diphtheria toxin. A positive test indicates lack of immunity.

 

C-4. Patch test → Filariasis: Used to demonstrate delayed hypersensitivity to filarial antigens, helpful in diagnosing tropical eosinophilia/filariasis.

 

D-1. Dick’s test → Streptococcal infection: An intradermal skin test to detect susceptibility to erythrogenic toxin of Streptococcus pyogenes (scarlet fever).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each hypersensitivity skin test has specific diagnostic or epidemiological significance: Casoni's for hydatid disease, Schick for diphtheria, Patch for filariasis, and Dick's for streptococcal toxin response.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with complaints of vaginal discharge and a fishy odor. After taking a history and performing a pelvic examination, a wet mount preparation shows a "clue cell" pattern. The pH of the vaginal fluid is found to be above 4.5. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made. Which of the following is the recommended first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the recommended first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis. It can be administered either orally or topically and has been proven effective for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is primarily used for treating fungal infections such as vaginal candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option B. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for bacterial vaginosis, but it is not the first-line choice.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic mainly used for treating urinary tract infections and certain types of bacterial diarrhea but is not recommended for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, which presents with vaginal pH > 4.5, clue cells, and fishy odor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with primary progressive MS has had multiple relapses despite interferon β therapy. Which monoclonal antibody is best suited for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ocrelizumab

 

  • Ocrelizumab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody approved for both relapsing-remitting and primary progressive MS. 
  • It reduces relapse rate and MRI lesion burden. 
  • It works by depleting B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dimethyl fumarate: Less effective; used in RRMS.

 

Option B. Fingolimod: S1P modulator; not first-line in PPMS.

 

Option C. Natalizumab: Highly effective for RRMS but not approved for PPMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocrelizumab is approved for both RRMS and PPMS and is highly effective in reducing progression and relapse frequency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a complaint of post-coital bleeding. A Pap smear result is positive, indicating possible cervical epithelial abnormality. She has no significant prior gynecologic interventions. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Colposcopy directed biopsy

 

  • In a 45-year-old woman with post-coital bleeding and a positive Pap smear, the primary concern is cervical pathology, including cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) or invasive cervical cancer. 
  • A positive Pap smear warrants further evaluation to establish the diagnosis and determine severity.
  • The most appropriate next step is colposcopy with directed biopsy, which allows direct visualization of the cervical epithelium under magnification and enables the clinician to target suspicious lesions for histopathological sampling. 
  • This is the standard diagnostic approach following an abnormal Pap smear, especially in the presence of clinical symptoms like post-coital bleeding, which raises concern for significant cervical disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cone biopsy: Cone biopsy is an excisional diagnostic procedure that removes a cone-shaped portion of the cervix. It is usually done after colposcopic biopsy confirms high-grade CIN or if the transformation zone is not fully visualized. It is not the first step after a positive Pap smear; histologic confirmation via colposcopy-directed biopsy must come first.

 

Option C. Repeat Pap smear: Repeating the Pap smear delays necessary evaluation and is not appropriate in a symptomatic woman with a positive result and post-coital bleeding. A repeat test is only considered in cases of inadequate or equivocal prior cytology, and even then, it is done according to screening guidelines—not in the setting of symptoms and positive cytology.

 

Option D. Endocervical curettage: Endocervical curettage (ECC) is used to sample the endocervical canal, particularly when colposcopic visualization is unsatisfactory. However, it is not the first-line next step after a positive Pap smear and symptomatic presentation. It may supplement colposcopy but not replace it as the initial evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colposcopy with directed biopsy is the next step after a positive Pap smear, particularly in women with symptoms such as post-coital bleeding, to confirm the presence and grade of cervical pathology.

questions.text: A 64-year-old hospitalized patient develops fever, leukocytosis, and purulent sputum after 7 days of mechanical ventilation. Culture of tracheal aspirate reveals Pseudomonas aeruginosa, known for its intrinsic resistance mechanisms and limited treatment options. The medical team is reviewing antibiotic choices. Which of the following agents is not appropriate for treating Pseudomonas infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vancomycin

 

  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is highly effective against gram-positive organisms, particularly methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Clostridioides difficile (oral route). 
  • However, vancomycin has no activity against gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, because it cannot penetrate the outer membrane of gram-negative organisms. 
  • Therefore, it is not used in the treatment of Pseudomonas infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tobramycin: Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside with potent anti-Pseudomonal activity. It is often used in combination therapy for serious infections like ventilator-associated pneumonia or bacteremia caused by Pseudomonas.

 

Option C. Piperacillin-tazobactam: This combination includes a broad-spectrum antipseudomonal penicillin (piperacillin) and a beta-lactamase inhibitor (tazobactam). It is frequently used as a first-line agent in hospital-acquired Pseudomonas infections.

 

Option D. Rifampicin: While Rifampicin is not used as monotherapy for Pseudomonas, it has some synergistic activity when combined with other antibiotics in biofilm-associated infections (e.g., prosthetic device infections). It is not the drug of choice, but it can be used adjunctively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin lacks activity against gram-negative bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is not used in its treatment.

choices.text: Chronic HU therapy should be considered
He is experiencing acute chest syndrome
Maintaining Hct above 30% is part of acute management

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with sickle cell disease presents with fever, severe chest pain, limb pain. Oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily sildenafil improves pulmonary hemodynamics 

 

  • This is acute chest syndrome (ACS), a major complication of sickle cell disease. 
  • Sildenafil was tested for pulmonary hypertension in SCD but was discontinued due to increased pain crises. 
  • Management includes oxygen, transfusion, and hydroxyurea for prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic hydroxyurea therapy should be considered: Indicated for ≥3 crises/year or recurrent ACS. Not recommended for acute treatment. Works by increasing HbF (HbF is protective for sickling).

 

Option B. He is experiencing acute chest syndrome: The patient’s symptoms (fever, chest pain, hypoxia) and the presence of a new pulmonary infiltrate fulfill the diagnostic criteria for Acute Chest Syndrome. This is a common cause of ICU admissions and a leading cause of death in patients with sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Maintaining Hct above 30% is part of acute management: Helps oxygen delivery during acute events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute chest syndrome is a leading cause of morbidity in sickle cell disease and requires urgent supportive care, transfusion, and long-term hydroxyurea therapy. 
  • Sildenafil is not recommended.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with hypertension presents after a routine visit reveals 5.4 g/day proteinuria. Biopsy of the kidney is shown below. Similar changes were seen in 45% of glomeruli at the corticomedullary junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

 

  • FSGS presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria and segmental glomerular scarring, especially at the corticomedullary junction. 
  • Secondary causes include obesity and hypertension. 
  • Unlike minimal change disease, FSGS is evident on light microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Normal light microscopy; more common in children.

 

Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis: Causes global sclerosis and less proteinuria.

 

Option D. Membranous nephropathy: Uniform thickening, not segmental sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FSGS is a common cause of nephrotic-range proteinuria in adults with histologic segmental scarring, especially in those with obesity or hypertension.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding dysgerminoma are incorrect?
