  1. Dysgerminoma is composed of small cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, arranged in glandular structures
  2. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary
  3. The testicular counterpart of dysgerminoma is seminoma, a common germ cell tumor in males
  4. Histologically, dysgerminoma resembles oocytes, showing large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei
  5. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is typically elevated in dysgerminoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 5

 

Statement 1. Dysgerminoma is composed of small cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, arranged in glandular structures: Incorrect. Dysgerminoma is not composed of small, hyperchromatic cells in glandular patterns. Instead, it consists of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, arranged in sheets or nests. The description given fits a different type of tumor, such as certain adenocarcinomas.
 

Statement 5. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is typically elevated in dysgerminoma: Incorrect. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not elevated in dysgerminoma. LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is the typical tumor marker that may be elevated. AFP is more commonly elevated in yolk sac tumors.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary: Correct. Dysgerminoma is indeed the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, particularly in adolescents and young women.

 

Statement 3. The testicular counterpart of dysgerminoma is seminoma, a common germ cell tumor in males: Correct. The testicular counterpart of dysgerminoma is seminoma, which is a relatively common malignant germ cell tumor in males.

 

Statement 4. Histologically, dysgerminoma resembles oocytes, showing large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei: Correct. The hallmark histologic appearance of dysgerminoma is large cells with clear cytoplasm and centrally placed nuclei, which resemble oocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, composed of large clear cells resembling oocytes, and is associated with elevated LDH but not AFP.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–5, B–1, C–4, D–3, E–2

 

  • Different genital ulcers have distinct causative organisms:
    • Genital herpes: HSV-2 (more common) or HSV-1
    • Syphilitic chancre: Treponema pallidum
    • Donovanosis: Klebsiella granulomatis
    • Chancroid: Hemophilus ducreyi
    • LGV: Chlamydia trachomatis (L1–L3)
  • Correct identification is key to diagnosis, appropriate testing, and treatment selection.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genital herpes: HSV-2 (more common) or HSV-1
  • Syphilitic chancre: Treponema pallidum
  • Donovanosis: Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Chancroid: Hemophilus ducreyi
  • LGV: Chlamydia trachomatis (L1–L3)

choices.text: Presence of schistocytes and markedly reduced ADAMTS13 activity

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with confusion, mild fever, anemia (Hb 8.8), thrombocytopenia (15,000 platelets per microliter), and creatinine 2.6 mg/dL. UA shows proteinuria and RBCs. Which of the following findings supports the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of schistocytes and markedly reduced ADAMTS13 activity

 

  • The presentation is classic for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), a thrombotic microangiopathy with hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms, and renal injury. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by schistocytes and low ADAMTS13 activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody positivity: Seen in Goodpasture’s, not TTP.

 

Option C. Positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test: Negative in TTP; positive in AIHA.

 

Option D. Peripheral smear showing spherocytes: Seen in hereditary spherocytosis or autoimmune hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TTP presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and organ dysfunction. 
  • Schistocytes and low ADAMTS13 activity are diagnostic.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressant medications is least likely to cause weight gain as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bupropion

 

  • Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that acts as a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). 
  • It is the least likely among the listed options to cause weight gain. 
  • In fact, bupropion is often associated with modest weight loss in many patients, making it a preferred choice for patients concerned about weight gain with antidepressant therapy or for those who have experienced weight gain with other antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Incorrect. While fluoxetine (an SSRI) may be weight-neutral initially or even cause slight weight loss in the short term, it can lead to weight gain with long-term use. Though its weight gain potential is lower than TCAs, it still has a higher likelihood of causing weight gain compared to bupropion.

 

Option C. Venlafaxine: Incorrect. Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that can cause weight gain, particularly with long-term use. While its weight gain profile is not as significant as TCAs, it is more likely to cause weight gain than bupropion.

 

Option D. Amitriptyline: Incorrect. Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), has one of the highest propensities for causing weight gain among antidepressants. This is due to its antihistaminic (H1) effects, increased appetite, carbohydrate craving, and metabolic changes. It has a significantly higher risk of weight gain compared to bupropion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among antidepressants, bupropion (NDRI) is least likely to cause weight gain and may even promote modest weight loss, making it a favorable option for patients who are concerned about weight gain as a side effect of antidepressant therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Uttar Pradesh presents with intermittent fever, progressive pallor, and massive hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia. A buffy coat smear reveals macrophages containing intracellular organisms with a kinetoplast. Which of the following is the most likely vector involved in the transmission of this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

  • This clinical picture is classic for visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), caused by Leishmania donovani, which is endemic in Uttar Pradesh, India. 
  • The presence of Fever, pallor, and splenomegaly, pancytopenia and macrophages laden with kinetoplast-bearing amastigotes (Leishman-Donovan bodies) points clearly toward this diagnosis.
  • Transmission of Leishmania donovani occurs through the bite of the female Phlebotomus sandfly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Vector for Trypanosoma brucei, the cause of African sleeping sickness, not endemic in India.

 

Option C. Ixodes tick: This is the vector for Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease) and Babesia, neither of which present with amastigotes or are endemic to India.

 

Option D. Culex mosquito: Vector for Japanese encephalitis virus, not involved in transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leishmania donovani causes visceral leishmaniasis and is transmitted by the sandfly. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by finding kinetoplast-containing amastigotes inside macrophages on smear.

choices.text: Mass blast wind displacing the wall
Reflection and wrapping of the blast wave around barriers
Projectiles from wall fragmentation causing secondary trauma
Seismic transmission of shock via ground vibration

questions.text: During a terrorist bomb attack, a victim taking shelter behind a concrete wall still sustains tympanic membrane rupture and pulmonary contusions. Which phenomenon best explains the injury despite shielding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reflection and wrapping of the blast wave around barriers

 

  • Blast waves behave similarly to sound waves. They travel through the air at high speeds and can reflect, refract, and diffract (bend) around solid structures.
  • When a blast wave encounters a wall:
    • Part of the wave is reflected back, creating areas of higher pressure.
    • Part of the wave wraps around the obstacle, continuing past the shelter.
  • Tympanic membrane rupture (seen at pressures above ~150 kN/m²) and blast lung injuries can still occur because of the pressure changes from reflected and wrapped blast waves, even without direct exposure.
  • Thus, hiding behind a wall does not fully protect against primary blast injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass blast wind displacing the wall: Blast wind (the mass air movement) can knock over structures but would cause blunt trauma (tertiary injuries) — not isolated tympanic rupture or pulmonary contusions.

 

Option C. Projectiles from wall fragmentation causing secondary trauma: Wall debris can cause penetrating injuries (secondary injuries), but not pure blast wave effects like air-pressure ruptures without shrapnel wounds.

 

Option D. Seismic transmission of shock via ground vibration: Ground shock can cause fractures or collapse injuries (tertiary injuries) but does not typically cause isolated tympanic membrane rupture or pulmonary contusion from blast overpressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary blast injuries are caused by the pressure wave itself, not flying debris or collapse.
  • Blast waves can wrap around barriers and injure people behind cover.
  • Tympanic membrane rupture and blast lung are hallmark primary blast injuries — indicating that pressure effects reached the victim despite apparent shelter.

choices.text: The fistula is larger than 2 cm in diameter
The catheter is maintained for at least 8 weeks
The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter
The fistula is associated with pelvic radiation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with continuous leakage of urine following a prolonged and complicated vaginal delivery two weeks ago. On physical examination and further imaging, she is found to have a genitourinary fistula. She is managed conservatively with continuous bladder drainage using a Foley catheter. Which of the following characteristics is most associated with increased likelihood of spontaneous closure of the fistula under this conservative approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter

 

  • In patients with genitourinary fistula, especially post-obstetric injury, conservative management with continuous bladder drainage using a Foley catheter may allow for spontaneous closure, particularly in small, fresh fistulas.
  • A fistula measuring 2 to 3 mm in diameter has a higher chance of spontaneous healing because:
    • The smaller the fistula, the less tissue breakdown and the greater the likelihood of apposition of the edges.
    • Continuous bladder drainage reduces urine pressure at the fistula site, facilitating tissue repair.
  • Spontaneous healing is most likely when the fistula is:
    • Small (<5 mm)
    • Not associated with infection or prior radiation
    • Not caused by malignancy or severe ischemic damage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fistula is larger than 2 cm in diameter: Fistulas larger than 2 cm are less likely to close spontaneously with bladder drainage due to the significant tissue defect, which often requires surgical repair. Larger defects reduce the chance of edge approximation and effective healing.

 

Option B. The catheter is maintained for at least 8 weeks: While catheter drainage is essential, prolonged use beyond 4–6 weeks has not been shown to significantly increase closure rates and may increase the risk of urinary tract infections or bladder irritation. Healing is more influenced by fistula characteristics (size, cause) than just duration of catheterization.

 

Option D. The fistula is associated with pelvic radiation: Fistulas resulting from pelvic radiation indicate ischemic, fibrotic, and poorly healing tissues, which significantly reduce the likelihood of spontaneous closure. These cases typically require surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small fistulas (2–3 mm) following obstetric trauma have the highest likelihood of spontaneous closure with continuous bladder drainage using a Foley catheter.

questions.text: Calculate my ponderal index-I am 1200 grams and length of 42 cm and also tell me which type it fits into?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.6 with asymmetrical IUGR

 

  • The Ponderal Index (PI) is a key anthropometric measurement used to assess fetal growth patterns and distinguish between symmetrical and asymmetrical intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).
  • The formula for Ponderal Index is:

 

 

  • Substituting the values provided:
    • Weight = 1200 grams
    • Length = 42 cm

 

 

  • Rounding to one decimal point gives PI ≈ 1.6
  • Interpretation:
    • PI < 2.0 generally indicates asymmetrical IUGR
    • PI normal or >2.0 with low birth weight and proportionate reduction in all measurement’s points toward symmetrical IUGR
  • In asymmetrical IUGR, fetal weight is disproportionately low compared to length (head-sparing growth), often due to placental insufficiency in late gestation.
  • Thus, the infant has:
    • PI = 1.6
    • Consistent with asymmetrical IUGR

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ponderal index less than 2.0 indicates asymmetrical IUGR, which is typically due to placental insufficiency and presents with relatively preserved length and head size but reduced weight.

questions.text: A young adult male reports experiencing abdominal distension, frequent gas, and diarrhea every time he consumes dairy products. He notes that these symptoms are absent when he consumes other types of food. Which of the following enzymes is he most likely deficient in, based on this specific dietary intolerance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-galactosidase

 

  • The patient’s symptoms—bloating, flatulence, and diarrhea after dairy consumption—are classic signs of lactose intolerance. This condition results from a deficiency in the enzyme beta-galactosidase, more commonly known as lactase.
  • Lactase (β-galactosidase) is responsible for breaking down lactose (a disaccharide found in milk) into glucose and galactose, which can be absorbed in the small intestine.
  • In the absence of sufficient lactase, undigested lactose reaches the colon, where it is fermented by gut bacteria, leading to the production of gas and cause osmotic diarrhea.
  • The restriction of symptoms to stopping dairy intake strongly supports lactase (β-galactosidase) deficiency as the root cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-glucosidase: This enzyme breaks down complex carbohydrates such as maltose and other α-linked oligosaccharides into glucose. Deficiency would affect digestion of starches, not specifically dairy, and would not cause dairy-specific symptoms.

 

Option C. Sucrase: Sucrase splits sucrose (table sugar) into glucose and fructose. A deficiency would lead to issues with sweet foods, not with dairy, and symptoms would appear after consuming sugary foods, not lactose.

 

Option D. Alpha-amylase: Alpha-amylase is involved in starch digestion, breaking down large polysaccharides into smaller units like maltose. It is found in saliva and pancreatic secretions. A deficiency here would lead to starch malabsorption, not lactose intolerance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Beta-galactosidase (lactase) deficiency is the cause of lactose intolerance, which leads to gas, bloating, and diarrhea specifically after consuming dairy products, due to the inability to digest lactose in the small intestine.

choices.text: It is the procedure of choice for gastric ulcers
The pyloric nerves of Latarjet are sacrificed
A drainage procedure is not required
It has the lowest recurrence rate

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A drainage procedure is not required

 

  • No need for a drainage procedure (unlike truncal vagotomy), as pyloric innervation remains intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the procedure of choice for gastric ulcers: Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV) (also called parietal cell vagotomy) is a surgical procedure for chronic or intractable duodenal ulcers.

 

Option B. The pyloric nerves of Latarjet are sacrificed: Selective denervation of acid-producing parietal cells while preserving the Nerves of Latarjet, which maintain gastric motility. 

 

Option D. It has the lowest recurrent rate: Higher recurrence rate compared to other vagotomy techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV) is a preferred surgical treatment for chronic duodenal ulcers, preserving gastric motility and eliminating the need for a drainage procedure.

choices.text: Yes, partial incentive for completed visits
No, all six visits are mandatory for incentive
Yes, if she provides a valid reason for the missed visit
No, incentive is only for home deliveries

questions.text: An ASHA conducts postnatal visits on Days 3, 7, 14, 21, and 28 for a newborn delivered in a health facility. She misses the 42nd-day visit. Is she eligible for the HBPNC incentive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) No, all six visits are mandatory for incentive

 

  • Under the Home-Based Postnatal Care (HBPNC) guidelines by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), ASHAs are eligible for an incentive of ₹250 for conducting six mandatory postnatal visits for each institutional delivery. These visits are scheduled on Days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42.
    • All six visits must be completed to receive the incentive.
    • Missing even one visit—even the last—disqualifies the ASHA from receiving the incentive.
    • This strict adherence ensures continuity of care throughout the neonatal period (first 42 days), a critical time for preventing complications.
  • If there is home delivery she has to undertake 7 visits to the house of delivered female. An additional visit to the house of delivered female is conducted on the day of delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yes, partial incentive for completed visits: There is no provision for partial incentives in HBPNC. Full completion is required.

 

Option C. Yes, if she provides a valid reason for the missed visit: There is no exception or clause for compensating based on justification for missing visits.

 

Option D. No, incentive is only for home deliveries: Incorrect. Incentives are available for institutional and home deliveries—only the number of required visits differs (6 for institutional, 7 for home deliveries).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ASHAs receive HBPNC incentives only upon completion of all required postnatal visits—6 for institutional deliveries and 7 for home deliveries. 
  • This system ensures consistent and uninterrupted postnatal care, vital for neonatal health and maternal support.

choices.text: The respiratory minute volume equals the amount of air inspired per minute.
Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort
Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration
Physiological dead space is the amount of air not equilibrating with blood.

questions.text: Which one of the following definitions is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration.

 

  • Vital capacity (VC) is defined as the maximum amount of air a person can exhale after a maximal inhalation, not after a normal inspiration. 
  • VC includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). 
  • It is a measure of the largest possible breath one can take and then fully exhale, used in assessing lung function. 
  • Thus, the statement that VC is the air that can be expired after a normal inspiration significantly underestimates its actual volume and physiological definition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The respiratory minute volume equals the amount of air inspired per minute: This statement is correct. Respiratory minute volume (also called minute ventilation) is calculated by multiplying the tidal volume (the amount of air inspired or expired during normal breathing) by the respiratory rate (breaths per minute). It represents the total volume of air inspired (or expired) per minute.

 

Option B. Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort: This is also correct. Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs even after a person exhales as forcefully as possible. This volume prevents lung collapse and allows continuous gas exchange between breaths.

 

Option D. Physiological dead space is the amount of air not equilibrating with blood: This is a correct definition. Physiological dead space includes both anatomical dead space (air in the conducting airways) and alveolar dead space (air in alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused). Therefore, it represents the portion of inspired air that does not participate in gas exchange, i.e., air not equilibrating with blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vital capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiration — not after a normal inspiration.

choices.text: Application of a cold compress can lead to temporary improvement in eyelid position
Pupillary size and reactivity are typically preserved
The initial extraocular muscle most often affected is the medial rectus
The eye peek phenomenon occurs due to partial levator palpebrae dysfunction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fluctuating eyelid drooping that worsens throughout the day. He also reports difficulty moving his eyes in multiple directions. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The initial extraocular muscle most often affected is the medial rectus

 

  • The presentation described is characteristic of myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune disorder marked by antibodies targeting the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. 
  • This results in fluctuating skeletal muscle weakness, especially in ocular muscles, leading to ptosis and diplopia.
  • The medial rectus is not the most commonly or first-involved extraocular muscle. Rather, myasthenia affects extraocular muscles in a variable and non-predictable manner. 
  • Therefore, option C is not true and is the correct answer to the question asking for the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Application of a cold compress can lead to temporary improvement in eyelid position: This is true. The ice pack test is a diagnostic maneuver for myasthenia gravis. Cooling inhibits acetylcholinesterase activity, increasing acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction and improving neuromuscular transmission temporarily, resulting in transient improvement of ptosis.

 

 

Option B. Pupillary size and reactivity are typically preserved: This is true. Pupils are not involved in myasthenia gravis because they are controlled by autonomic fibers, not skeletal muscle. Thus, pupils are unaffected, as stated.

 

Option D. The eye peek phenomenon occurs due to partial levator palpebrae dysfunction: This is also true. The peek sign is seen when a person tries to keep the eyes closed, but due to levator palpebrae muscle fatigue, the eyelid begins to open gradually, exposing the sclera. This reflects the skeletal muscle fatigue that underlies myasthenia gravis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In myasthenia gravis, extraocular muscle involvement is variable and not confined to one specific muscle such as the medial rectus; therefore, no single muscle is predictably first affected.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the closure of fetal circulatory structures are correct? 

 

  1. The ductus venosus functionally closes after the removal of the placenta and anatomically closes by 7 days.
  2. The foramen ovale undergoes functional closure at birth due to pressure changes after breathing is initiated and anatomically closes by 21 days.
  3. The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 10–15 hours and anatomically closes within 10–21 days.
  4. Anatomical closure of the foramen ovale may take several months to years.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Statement 1. The ductus venosus functionally closes after the removal of the placenta and anatomically closes by 7 days: True. Ductus venosus functionally closes after placental removal and anatomically by around 7 days.

 

Statement 3. The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 10–15 hours and anatomically closes within 10–21 days: True. The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 10–15 hours of birth due to increased oxygen and reduced prostaglandins, with anatomical closure by 10–21 days.

 

Statement 4. Anatomical closure of the foramen ovale may take several months to years: True. Foramen ovale anatomical closure is variable, taking months to years in some infants, and may remain patent in some adults.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. The foramen ovale undergoes functional closure at birth due to pressure changes after breathing is initiated and anatomically closes by 21 days: False. The foramen ovale does functionally close at birth due to increased left atrial pressure, but its anatomical closure is not within 21 days; it often takes months to years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal circulatory structures such as the ductus venosus, foramen ovale, and ductus arteriosus undergo functional closure soon after birth due to physiological changes such as the removal of placental circulation and initiation of pulmonary respiration. 
  • Anatomical closure, however, takes a variable amount of time: from days (ductus venosus, ductus arteriosus) to months or even years (foramen ovale), which is important in understanding normal adaptation and potential congenital anomalies.

questions.text: Identify traction in below image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smith’s traction

 

  • Smith’s traction is a type of skin traction used for forearm fractures, especially distal radius or Colles’ fractures.
  • It involves elbow flexion to 90 degrees, with the forearm in a vertical position and weights hanging off the forearm to provide traction and alignment.
  • It helps realign the distal radius by counteracting muscle forces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Buck’s Traction:

 

  • A form of skin traction typically used for lower limb injuries, especially:
    • Femoral fractures
    • Hip fractures
    • Preoperative pain relief in hip dislocations
  • The leg lies flat, and a pulling force is applied longitudinally using weights attached to the leg via skin tapes.
  • Not used for upper limbs.

 

 

Option C. Gallow’s Traction:

 

  • Also called Bryant’s traction.
  • Typically used in pediatric patients under 2 years or under 12–15 kg.
  • Both legs are suspended vertically with hips flexed to 90° to treat:
    • Congenital hip dislocation
    • Femoral fractures in infants
  • Does not involve the arm, and the setup is quite different.

 

 

Option D. Dunlop’s Traction:

 

  • Used for supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children.
  • The elbow is flexed, and the forearm is supported in either skin or skeletal traction.
  • The arm is positioned horizontally or at an angle, and traction is applied along both the humerus and forearm.
  • While similar in appearance to Smith’s, Dunlop’s is specifically for humerus fractures and involves both upward and longitudinal traction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman reports ongoing lower abdominal pain and progressive bloating over the past several weeks. She has a documented history of a molar pregnancy that was managed by dilatation and curettage six months ago. Recent investigations show persistently elevated beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) levels. A chest X-ray reveals multiple rounded opacities resembling cannonball lesions scattered throughout the lung fields. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

  • The patient's clinical picture is consistent with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) following a molar pregnancy, given the persistently elevated β-hCG levels and lung metastases presenting as cannonball opacities on chest X-ray. 
  • Despite the presence of metastases, not all such cases are classified as high-risk.
  • According to the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) scoring system, which incorporates time since pregnancy, β-hCG levels, metastasis location, size, and prior treatment, a score of 6 or below is considered low-risk.
  • Even in the presence of pulmonary metastases, patients may still fall under this low-risk category depending on other parameters.
  • In low-risk GTN, the treatment of choice is single-agent chemotherapy, and methotrexate with folinic acid (leucovorin) is commonly used. 
  • Folinic acid serves to rescue normal cells from methotrexate toxicity without affecting the efficacy against neoplastic trophoblastic cells. 
  • This approach is curative in the majority of low-risk GTN cases, even when metastases to the lungs are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine) is reserved for high-risk GTN (FIGO score ≥7). This aggressive multi-agent therapy is unnecessary and potentially toxic in low-risk patients, even with pulmonary metastases, when a single-agent regimen is sufficient.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone is an option in low-risk GTN; however, adding folinic acid reduces adverse effects, particularly mucositis and bone marrow suppression. Thus, methotrexate with folinic acid is preferred over methotrexate monotherapy in current protocols.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Surgical removal of the uterus does not address distant metastases such as those in the lungs. Furthermore, chemotherapy is highly effective, and hysterectomy is only considered in selected cases, such as refractory uterine bleeding or women who do not desire fertility and are unresponsive to chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid is the treatment of choice for low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, even in the presence of pulmonary metastases, provided the FIGO score remains ≤6.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding cells marked in the image below are correct? 

 

 

  1. They are flask-shaped and located in a single layer within the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  2. The axons of the cells form the only efferent output from the cerebellar cortex and terminate in cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  3. Each of these cells gives rise to a single axon that enters the white matter after crossing the granular layer.
  4. The dendrites of these cells do not enter the molecular layer.
  5. These cells are excitatory and release glutamate as their primary neurotransmitter.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3 only

 

  • The given image shows the 3 histological layers of the cerebellum:
    • Molecular layer 
    • Purkinje layer 
    • Granular layer 
  • The arrow-marked nucleus-like structure in the purkinje layer are the purkinje neurons. 

 

Correct statements regarding these cells are:

 

Statement 1. They are flask-shaped and located in a single layer within the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex: True. Purkinje cells are flask-shaped and lie in a single layer between the molecular and granular layers of the cerebellar cortex.

 

Statement 2. The axons of the cells form the only efferent output from the cerebellar cortex and terminate in cerebellar or vestibular nuclei: True. They are the only efferent neurons of the cerebellar cortex and project to cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.

 

Statement 3. Each of these cells gives rise to a single axon that enters the white matter after crossing the granular layer: True. Each Purkinje cell gives off a single axon that travels downward, crossing the granular layer into the white matter.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 4. The dendrites of these cells do not enter the molecular layer: False. The dendrites of Purkinje cells ascend into the molecular layer, where they arborize into a dendritic tree.

 

Statement 5. These cells are excitatory and release glutamate as their primary neurotransmitter: False. Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter, not glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory GABAergic neurons of the cerebellar cortex. 
  • They form a single output line from the cortex, with axons projecting to the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei. 
  • These flask-shaped cells have extensive dendritic trees in the molecular layer and serve as a critical relay in motor coordination and cerebellar function.

questions.text: A global health policy student is preparing for a model WHO simulation. She is assigned to represent the organization’s primary decision-making body responsible for reviewing the annual work of the organization, approving the budget, and setting global health priorities and policies. Which of the following WHO bodies is she most likely part of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The World Health Assembly

 

  • The World Health Assembly (WHA) is the supreme decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO). It comprises delegations from all WHO Member States and meets annually in Geneva.
  • Key functions include:
    • Reviewing the work of WHO over the past year
    • Determining global health policies and programs
    • Approving the organization's biennial budget
    • Appointing the Director-General
    • Amending international health regulations and treaties
  • The WHA plays a critical governance role, ensuring that WHO stays aligned with evolving global health needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Executive Board: Composed of 34 technically qualified members, the Executive Board implements decisions and policies made by the WHA and advises it, but it does not set the primary agenda or approve the budget.

 

Option B. The Secretariat: This is the technical and administrative arm of WHO, headed by the Director-General. It executes programs and provides support but does not make policy decisions.

 

Option D. The Director-General’s Taskforce: This is not a formal decision-making body of WHO. Taskforces are typically ad-hoc and focused on specific issues under the DG’s authority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The World Health Assembly is WHO’s governing and decision-making body, responsible for setting global health policies, approving the budget, and reviewing organizational performance annually.

choices.text: Baby is crying because the diaper is wet
The quality of the mother’s feed is not good
Baby is getting only foremilk, the satiety value is missing
We should rule out neonatal sepsis

questions.text: A 3-day old baby’s mother came to the pediatric OPD. She is concerned that whenever she breast feeds her baby, her baby sleeps comfortably but after every 30 minutes the baby wakes up and starts crying. On further evaluation, you find that the mother has been breastfeeding the baby correctly, however the baby feeds for just 5-10 minutes after which he goes to sleep. What could be the possible cause of frequent awakening in the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Baby is getting only foremilk, the satiety value is missing

 

  • In this scenario, the mother reports that the baby breastfeeds for only 5–10 minutes and then falls asleep but wakes up crying every 30 minutes. This suggests inadequate feeding, despite correct breastfeeding technique.
  • Breast milk is produced in two phases during a feed:
  1. Foremilk – the initial milk that is watery, lower in fat, and quenches thirst
  2. Hindmilk – released later in the feeding session, it is rich in fat, calories, and provides satiety
  • If a baby feeds for only a short time (e.g., 5–10 minutes), they may receive mainly foremilk and miss the hindmilk, leading to:
    • Hunger recurrence
    • Frequent awakening
    • Inadequate weight gain
  • Thus, the baby is not getting the high fat hindmilk, which leads to lack of satiety despite frequent feeding.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Baby is crying because the diaper is wet: Incorrect. While a wet diaper may cause occasional discomfort, crying every 30 minutes like clockwork is more consistent with feeding-related issues, not just a wet diaper.

 

Option B. The quality of the mother’s feed is not good: Incorrect. The concept of “quality” of breast milk is misleading. Human milk composition is biologically optimal and adjusts according to infant needs. The issue here is not the quality but the duration and completeness of each feed (i.e., missing hindmilk).

 

Option D. We should rule out neonatal sepsis: Incorrect. Neonatal sepsis typically presents with fever, poor feeding, lethargy, or hypothermia, not regular, timed crying after short feeds. In this case, the feeding pattern and timing clearly indicate feeding insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foremilk is low in fat and does not provide satiety babies who feed only briefly may not receive hindmilk, resulting in frequent hunger and crying.

choices.text: Switch from prostaglandin analogue to a beta-blocker
Add a second intraocular pressure-lowering medication
Consider filtration surgery such as trabeculectomy

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 6-year history of open-angle glaucoma presents for a routine follow-up. He has been on latanoprost monotherapy since diagnosis. His intraocular pressure is currently 16 mmHg. However, visual field testing now shows an arcuate scotoma, which has progressed from a previous paracentral defect. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Add a second intraocular pressure-lowering medication

 

  • This patient is already using latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, for primary open-angle glaucoma, and his IOP is within target range (16 mmHg). However, he shows progression of glaucomatous visual field loss (from paracentral to arcuate scotoma), indicating that IOP control is not sufficient to prevent optic nerve damage in his case.
  • Even with "normal" IOP, continued progression of field loss is a strong indication to further reduce IOP.
  • The next best step is to add a second medication (e.g., beta-blocker, carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, or alpha agonist) to further reduce IOP and slow disease progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Switch from prostaglandin analogue to a beta-blocker: Switching classes rather than adding a second agent would not provide additional IOP lowering. Prostaglandins are typically the most effective monotherapy, so replacing them rather than combining would be suboptimal. Switching can be opted if there is a side effect which is intolerable or if the efficacy of drug is low.

 

Option B. Perform prophylactic peripheral laser iridotomy: Laser iridotomy is used for angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma. This patient’s condition is clearly labeled as open-angle, and IOP is not acutely elevated, making this inappropriate.

 

Option D. Consider filtration surgery such as trabeculectomy: Trabeculectomy is typically reserved for cases unresponsive to maximal medical therapy or when target IOP cannot be reached pharmacologically. This patient has only tried monotherapy so far and should first be escalated with medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with open-angle glaucoma who show visual field progression despite controlled intraocular pressure on monotherapy, the next step is to add another IOP-lowering agent to prevent further optic nerve damage.

questions.text: A patient with a history of gallstones is now presenting with jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. Which imaging modality is considered most reliable for diagnosing Mirizzi syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

  • MRCP is the most reliable imaging modality for diagnosing Mirizzi syndrome because it provides high-resolution images of the biliary tree without the need for invasive procedures. 
  • It allows excellent visualization of the bile ducts and any obstructions, strictures, or stones, which are hallmark features of Mirizzi syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal Ultrasonography (USG): USG is often the first-line imaging test for biliary pathologies because it is non-invasive and widely available. However, it is operator-dependent and may miss certain features of Mirizzi syndrome, especially subtle ductal obstructions or stones in anatomically complex regions.

 

Option B. Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) Scan: Although a HIDA scan can evaluate biliary function and detect obstruction, it is less useful for visualizing the structural anomalies or stones in the bile duct associated with Mirizzi syndrome. 

 

Option C. Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): While ERCP is highly effective for diagnosing and managing biliary diseases, it is an invasive procedure that comes with risks, such as pancreatitis. It is often reserved for therapeutic purposes rather than first-line diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirizzi syndrome is a rare condition in which gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, leading to compression of the common bile duct. 
  • This results in obstructive jaundice. Imaging modalities like ultrasound, CT, and particularly MRCP are crucial for diagnosis. MRCP provides detailed visualization of the biliary tree, identifying stones, ductal compression, and other abnormalities.

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-month-old child Saheli for a routine visit. She complaints that her child is having chronic diarrhoea for more than a month and has failure to thrive. On examination, Saheli had abdominal distension and facial pallor. Routine CBC revealed the presence of severe anemia. On asking history, the mother informed that these symptoms started when she wean her off from the breast milk and started on supplementary feeds. On further evaluation, she is found to have hypersensitivity to gliadin in her foods. Which of the following is not allowed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • The child in the scenario presents with:
    • Chronic diarrhea
    • Failure to thrive
    • Abdominal distension
    • Severe anemia
    • Onset after introduction of supplementary feeds
    • Hypersensitivity to gliadin
  • These features are classic for Celiac disease, a gluten-sensitive enteropathy caused by an autoimmune response to gliadin, a component of gluten.
  • Foods that contain gluten (and thus gliadin) include:
    • Wheat
    • Barley
    • Rye
    • Oats (usually cross-contaminated unless labeled gluten-free)
  • Consumption of these grains leads to:
    • Villous atrophy in the small intestine
    • Malabsorption
    • Symptoms like diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, and nutrient deficiencies (e.g., iron → anemia)
  • Hence, all of the above options contain or are contaminated with gluten and must be strictly avoided in Celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease must avoid all gluten-containing grains, including wheat, rye, barley, and oats (unless certified gluten-free), due to hypersensitivity to gliadin.

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the kidney acts as a countercurrent multiplier?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

 

  • The loop of Henle functions as a countercurrent multiplier. This mechanism relies on:
    • Water permeability in the thin descending limb via aquaporin-1.
    • Active Na⁺/Cl⁻ transport in the thick ascending limb and passive Na+ Cl- transport via thin ascending limb, which is crucial to establishing the osmotic gradient in the medulla. 
    • Tubular flow from proximal to distal segments.
  • The vasa recta serves as the countercurrent exchanger, preserving the gradient by passive exchange of solutes and water.
  • The Distal convoluted tubule is not a key component in this process, as it lacks active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The countercurrent multiplier system in the kidney, driven by the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, is essential for establishing the medullary osmotic gradient that enables urine concentration. 
  • In contrast, the vasa recta preserves this gradient through passive exchange, acting as the countercurrent exchanger. 
  • This division is crucial for interpreting renal concentrating defects and diuretic mechanisms.

choices.text: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) DNAemia monitoring in a liver transplant recipient
BK virus load monitoring in a renal allograft recipient
Herpes simplex virus detection in suspected viral encephalitis
Hepatitis B viral load measurement in a patient receiving tenofovir therapy

questions.text: A hospital lab is reviewing the clinical utility of Real-Time PCR-based viral load testing in different patient populations. For which of the following infections is quantitative viral load monitoring by PCR not routinely useful or necessary for diagnosis or therapeutic monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes simplex virus detection in suspected viral encephalitis

 

  • While PCR is an essential tool for diagnosing many viral infections, it is important to distinguish between qualitative detection (presence/absence) and quantitative viral load monitoring.
  • In the case of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis, PCR of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the test of choice, but it is a qualitative test — it simply confirms the presence of HSV DNA.
  • Viral load measurement (quantitative PCR) does not guide treatment or monitoring in HSV encephalitis. Thus, Real-Time PCR for viral load has no role here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) DNAemia monitoring in a liver transplant recipient: Real-time PCR is routinely used to monitor viral load, guide antiviral therapy, and detect CMV reactivation in immunocompromised individuals, especially transplant recipients.

 

Option B. BK virus load monitoring in a renal allograft recipient: BK viremia is monitored via quantitative PCR to assess risk of nephropathy in renal transplant recipients. Viral load guides immunosuppression adjustment.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B viral load measurement in a patient receiving tenofovir therapy: In chronic hepatitis B, quantitative PCR is critical for monitoring treatment response, detecting viral resistance, and guiding therapy decisions, including in patients on tenofovir.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement by real-time PCR is not used in HSV encephalitis, where qualitative PCR from CSF is sufficient for diagnosis; in contrast, viral load testing is essential for HBV, CMV, and BK virus management.

questions.text: A viral sample from a child with fever, conjunctivitis, cough, and a spreading maculopapular rash is inoculated into cell culture. After 7–10 days, cytopathic changes are observed under microscopy. The cells exhibit multinucleated giant cells containing both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. What is the most likely virus isolated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measles virus

 

  • Measles virus, a paramyxovirus, is known to produce a distinctive cytopathic effect (CPE) in cell cultures 7–10 days post-inoculation.
  • The hallmark feature includes the formation of Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which are:
    • Multinucleated giant cells
    • Containing both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions
  • These CPE findings reflect the syncytium-forming ability of the measles virus due to its fusion (F) protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella virus: Does not produce multinucleated giant cells or characteristic inclusion bodies. Cytopathic effects are less prominent.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): Associated with atypical lymphocytes in blood, not multinucleated giant cells in culture.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Produces owl’s eye intranuclear inclusions, but not multinucleated giant cells with dual inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus produces characteristic cytopathic effects in cell culture within 7–10 days, including Warthin-Finkeldey cells—multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions.

choices.text: Rifampicin enhances OCP metabolism leading to contraceptive failure
Antitubercular drugs increase the teratogenic risk of OCPs
Oral contraceptives impair rifampicin absorption causing treatment failure
Rifampicin inhibits hepatic metabolism of oral contraceptives

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis is started on standard antitubercular therapy including rifampicin. She has been using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) as her primary method of birth control. At her follow-up, she is advised to use an additional barrier method of contraception. Which of the following best explains the rationale for this recommendation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rifampicin enhances OCP metabolism leading to contraceptive failure

 

  • Rifampicin is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 enzyme system, particularly CYP3A4. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), which typically contain estrogens and progestins, are metabolized by the liver via these enzymes. When rifampicin is introduced, it increases the rate of metabolism of the hormones in OCPs, leading to reduced plasma concentrations and thereby decreasing their contraceptive efficacy.
  • This interaction may result in contraceptive failure and unplanned pregnancy, which is why patients are advised to use an additional barrier method during rifampicin therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antitubercular drugs increase the teratogenic risk of OCPs:
OCPs are not teratogenic, and their combination with antitubercular drugs does not lead to increased teratogenicity. The concern here is not about fetal anomalies, but reduced efficacy of contraception.

 

Option C. Oral contraceptives impair rifampicin absorption causing treatment failure: OCPs do not interfere with rifampicin absorption or its effectiveness. The issue lies in rifampicin affecting OCP metabolism, not vice versa.

 

Option D. Rifampicin inhibits hepatic metabolism of oral contraceptives: This is incorrect. Rifampicin is a hepatic enzyme inducer, not an inhibitor. It increases metabolism of drugs like OCPs, thereby reducing their effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rifampicin induces hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes, which accelerates the metabolism of oral contraceptive hormones, leading to reduced efficacy and increased risk of contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with sudden-onset severe abdominal and flank pain. On physical examination, he is hypotensive and has a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region. A CT scan confirms a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atherosclerosis

 

  • This patient has a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), which classically occurs:
    • In male smokers > 60 years old
    • Most commonly below the renal arteries and above the aortic bifurcation
    • Atherosclerosis is the most common underlying cause
  • Atherosclerosis contributes by:
    • Increasing the diffusion barrier to the media layer of the aorta
    • Leading to atrophy and weakening of the vessel wall
    • Resulting in balloon-like dilation
  • Presentation:
    • Pulsatile abdominal mass
    • Flank pain
    • Hypotension (suggestive of rupture when the aneurysm > 5 cm)
  • Complications:
    • Rupture (life-threatening, surgical emergency)
    • Compression of adjacent structures (e.g., ureter)
    • Thrombosis or embolism

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Syphilitic aortitis: Typically affects the thoracic aorta, not abdominal; associated with tertiary syphilis.
 

Option C. Takayasu arteritis: Typically affects young women and involves the aortic arch and branches, not the abdominal aorta.
 

Option D. Marfan syndrome: Associated with ascending aortic aneurysms due to cystic medial degeneration, not with abdominal aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is most often due to atherosclerosis and presents in older male smokers with hypertension. 
  • It occurs below the renal arteries, and rupture presents with a triad of hypotension, pulsatile abdominal mass, and flank pain.
